reviewText:
Short review

If you are a die-hard fan, you will have bought, played and judged this anyway, so you can stop reading. If you're not a die-hard fan, make sure you've played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City before this, and if you are then still hungry for more Batman and can't wait for Arkham Knight, consider getting this only on a good sale.

Long review

Arkham Asylum was great.

Arkham City was even better, even though the story did get convoluted at times just to fit in all the content.

Arkham Origins... is just something to tide us over until Arkham Knight is finally released.

If, like me, you are a massive fan of the Arkham series, it's likely that you've already bought and played Origins, so I don't need to review it for you. If you are someone who merely liked Arkham City rather than playing it to death, and who's wondering if you should pick up Origins: probably not. You've already seen (almost) all the gameplay there is in Arkham City, and done better at that. Yes, Origins has a bigger map -- but it doesn't manage to fill that map with sufficiently interesting stuff, so that, paradoxically, it somehow feels smaller than Arkham City. Yes, Origins adds a story that qualifies as a prequel (even though, in spite of the title, there is very little there that could be called an origin of anything), but it's ultimately inconsequential.

The story is both better and worse than City. It definitely has more focus than City, which started off simple but had an incredibly convoluted build-up to the end, certainly compared to Asylum. By contrast, Origins simply has Batman targeted by a bunch of assassins because Black Mask put a price on his head, and most of the story is just Batman taking them all down in order. There's one thing that could be called a twist, but it happens pretty early on, and actually (and unfortunately) makes the story less interesting since we trade a new villain for an old one. But with the increase in focus also comes a loss of depth, and there's nothing in Origins that compares to the daring ending of City. True, Origins hardly has room for something like that given that it's a prequel, but more could have been done with the premise. As it is, most of the characters you encounter in Origins undergo no development -- Batman included.

The gameplay is definitely worse, in both small things and bigger things. There are glitches where Batman can get stuck or enemies suddenly stop registering as enemies and just stand there looking goofy, ground takedowns seem to work only when they feel like it, and sometimes necessary encounters simply don't happen until you leave an area and come back. Mind you, this is with all the patches and fixes that are likely to ever be applied -- this is as good as it gets. It never gets so bad that it makes Origins unplayable, but it's just not as polished as City.

Upgrades are now partially tied to achievements in the form of the Dark Knight system, and this manages to do little more than unbalance things. The fatal flaw of this system is that it requires you to do certain things in order, so unless you're carefully keeping track of what exactly you're supposed to do next, you may find yourself short of an upgrade you want with no easy way of getting it, or doing something silly you've already done dozens of times in the game which only now counts as an achievement. I spent the majority of the game without the disarm & destroy" move because you can only get this if you complete a side mission that's extremely easy to miss until you've already finished the story (and in fact it doesn't unlock until a good way in). And if you haven't completed the Predator track by the time the story finishes

reviewText:
NOTE:A 'Not Recommended' Rating does not mean its a bad game  (it's an average game in my opinion). I just can't recommend it since its basically a copy/paste of Arkham City but buggier and made with little understanding on what made Asylum and City great.

TL:DR? See CONCLUSION
INTRODUCTION:Batman Arkham Origins is the third instalment to the Arkham franchise. Although the original Arkham Games were made by UK based developers Rocksteady, this game (Arkham Origins) was made by Warner Bros. Games Montréal with Rocksteady acting merely in an advisory capacity.

The story takes place roughly 5 years before the events of Arkham Asylum, in a time where Batman was only 1-2 years into his career as a superhero and is highly regarded as an urban myth. Play as Batman and fight for your survival because Black Mask has offered a $50 Million bounty on your head. Defend against the assassins, put Black Mask behind bars and uncover a new mysterious and dangerous villain calling himself, “The Joker”

PROS:+ Good Story which has a lot of great moments. Recognized as canon by Rocksteady
+ Improved and Challenging Boss Fights (although not all *cough* Electrocutioner)
+ New Enemy Types (the Martial Artist thug is a fun new addition)
+ Voice Acting by Troy Baker (Joker), Roger Craig Smith (Batman) and all of the voice actors did exceptionally well. Not the best, but for 'younger' versions of the characters they did well.
+ Substantial amount of side missions (although very poorly paced)
+ Visit the Batcave and Alfred

CONS:- Copy/Paste of ARKHAM CITY
- No innovation or change from Arkham City in terms of combat mechanic
- No innovation or change from Arkham City in terms of gadgets which are still basically the same with new names but does the same thing
- Bigger Map but somehow very boring and has a fair amount of glitches
- Annoying screen flicker effect while reading
- Severe Performance drops because of excessive use of PhysX and poor optimization
- Unnecessary Multiplayer to a game which was clearly intended for a Single Player experience
- Too much Combat and only a few (and easy) Stealth missions
- Too much characters which resulted in less screen-time for each of them
- Too much sources of Exp that results in fast level ups which results in...(see below)
- Too much upgrades that removes the challenge in both Combat and Stealth play (Electric Gloves)
- Bugs, glitches and errors plague the game, still unpatched because the devs said that they were focusing more on the DLC than fixing their game
- Limited Batman Costumes

CONCLUSION:I would RECOMMEND this game for people who's in it for the STORY, otherwise, Its best AVOIDED. If you were expecting innovation on the gameplay mechanics, smooth frame-rates and with a properly paced progression, sorry but you won't find it here.

WORTH IT?:NOT Worth a full price purchase, best bought in a SALE.

RANT (Not necessary for the review):There is a saying which goes: “Too much of a good thing is BAD”, Arkham Origins is a prime example of it. Too much Combat made it repetitive and a chore with not enough stealth, Too big of a map that made it boring, Too much upgrades that made the game easy, Too much villains that resulted in little screen-time, Too much PhysX effects that caused FPS to tank badly, Too easy Riddler challenges, Too much attention to DLC while ignoring multiple bugs and glitches and many many more.

I just can't recommend it since its basically a copy/paste of Arkham City but buggier and made with little understanding on what made Asylum and City great.

---------------------------------------------------------

http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is a prequel to Arkham Asylum and a sequel to The Land Before Time.

You play as a younger and less handsome Batman, when he was just starting his career of ILLEGAL vigilantism and his parents were slightly less dead. But still very dead by normal human standards. The game takes place on Christmas eve, a time for celebration and also a time when the diner turns on its heater in the alley and I can be warm at night. A man called Roman Sionis,  Negrodomis aka: the Black Mask and totally the main villain for the entire game has hired several assassins to come make Batman like his parents for the low low price of 50 million Vietnamese Dongs. These villains include Bane, Deathstroke, Deadshot, and several villains you've never actually heard of.

The combat is much the same as it was the last two games, only with a few more features, such as electric gloves that also double as a nifty way to power your cellphone. Much like a microwave. It also adds a few new enemy types, such as discount Jet Li, and roid-monsters. But old enemies return as well like the random mook, and of course those creatures I am deathly of: girls.

Stealth is pretty much the same, only this time you also get an upgrade to your spider-man web in the form of a gun that allows you to strap people to gargoyles so you can wrap them up and suck out their juicy goo like the evil man-spider you are. You awful, awful monster.

The collectible riddler side-mission returns, only this time it reminds me of my high-school years: long and heartbreaking. The riddles and Batman trivia is gone in favor of collecting datapacks that I spent more time doing than I care to admit. There are also these invisible icons left behind by some chump called Anarky, and much like the gay agenda, they are everywhere.

The game itself is rather jarring compared to the first two Arkham games. While Rocksteady made a rather loving tribute to the Dark Knights in comic and cartoon, Arkham Origins feels much like the movies, taking many assets from the Dark Knight trilogy and clashing themes together much like the skin tone between me and my African twin. Though you can use one of the many skins for Batman after you complete the game, most of them tend to not fit with the theme the game is going for, so you're left out like a DnD nerd at a Fantasy Football meet up.

The game also gives you the option of playing as Deathstroke in the challenge maps, a character that is rather easy to beat even on the hard difficulty and only shows up maybe twice through the entire thing. And even then, he's just a re-skin of Robin from Arkham City. So you're basically just playing as Robin during his rebellious teenage years.

This all being said, would I actually recommend Batman's third crusade through the streets of Angsty Metropolis? I guess, if you liked the first two. The side missions are unfulfilling and the Riddler missions make me want to rethink my life choice as a professional street Luchadore. But the game still held my attention for longer than I care to admit, and I still like to look at Bruce's chisled jaw and amazing abs.
That still doesn't make me gay.

6/10. Did you know that the M on Mario's hat stands for Mario?

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Deja vu - that old feeling
As gamers we have come to understand the nature and accept the curse that often accompanies games generated from films or licensed material. While most of them look exactly like a thinly veiled attempt at getting you to part with your hard earned cash there are some that are genuinely enjoyable or good fun in small doses. However, the general consensus carried by most is to just avoid them completely and if you must pick them up - grab them when they are in the bargain bin a month later. I realize this can be an excruciating thing when you have been a life-long fan who refuses to give up hope that your hero will finally feature in something worthy of his heroic stature and stop slumming it with the shallow money men and celebrity hand-holders.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=260967665
Rocksteady, taking cues from Frank Millers version of The Dark Knight, were finally thankfully able to put down a title that not only did the source material justice but also expanded upon it in its own unique ways. Batman: Arkham Asylum was also one of those rare licensed-based games that ended up being a winner as the tormented and battle-scared Batman went head to toe with his nemesis du jour, The Joker. If you have not yet taken the time to play Arkham Asylum I implore you stop reading right now and go install, play and finish the game immediately before returning to finish reading this. With an incredibly well written and engaging story (that acknowledges the lore and back-story of Gotham City and its characters) it featured gameplay that was incredibly fast, dynamic, enjoyable and fluid. It even faithfully recreated a Gotham Universe many immediately identified with. It looked like Rocksteady, a then little know company that developed the first and second game, were on hand to give the fans of Batman a game most wanted to see him in.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=253772811
For the third installment all is not so clear on the (Gotham) waterfront. With Warner Bros. Montreal taking over the reigns from Rocksteady, Batman's worst enemies though are not the assassins lying in wait to claim his head for their bounty prize but the bone-crunching and back-breaking bugs the game was released with and in most cases still suffers from (like your save game getting corrupted which forces you then to restart and has been an issue since day dot). This time around the adventure suffers from a severe case of uneven pacing and you will often find this new Batman veering from one charged encounter to a Batman that looks like he is about to fall asleep on his own two feet. Batman: Arkham Origins introduces us to a much younger Batman who is more prone to sudden aggressive outbursts on the one hand and on the other hand in danger of almost turning into a small-town private-eye rather than the bright-lights-big-city crime and punishment enforcer that he actually is.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=260947748
Even fighting against seven of his deadly comic book nemesis is not nearly as exciting as it must have sounded on paper with some of these boss battles not even registering a 1 on the boss-battle meter which has the unfortunate effect of turning most of them into a non-event. Once again the game is played from a third-person perspective and focuses on Batman's combat and stealth abilities, detective skills, and gadgets for combat and exploration. Batman: Arkham Origins is also the first game in the series with multiplayer capability. However, a lot of the areas covered in Arkham Origins honestly feel like a cut-and-paste job from Arkham City and the more I played the more I began to feel like this was ground that had already been well covered.

I really wanted to love Batman: Arkham Origins and while there is indeed a lot to love (the combat is as fluid as ever) and some of the areas you get to explore like Madhatter's Domain are exceptionally creative but it all gets bogged down by the hit and miss plot and gameplay on display, some seriously dodgy bugs that almost a year into release have still not yet been fixed despite being know about and then the usual sandbox favorite - lifeless, boring and generic altercations with the cities criminal underbelly. If Rocksteady is to continue in this vein with The Dark Knight I sincerely hope they look to Arkham Asylum for more inspiration as I am not so sold when it comes to the open-world sandbox versions.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
‘On the Shoulders of Giants’
‘Batman: Arkham Origins’ is a taut, immersive, if iterative installment in the legendary ‘Arkham’ series of games – which unfortunately comes in for more criticism than it ultimately deserves. Boasting a strong narrative, an expansive and atmospheric open world, and all the classic gameplay elements from the earlier titles, it is just about everything one might traditionally expect from a sequel.

Campaign: Released by ‘Warner Brothers | Montreal’ in late-2013, ‘Arkham Origins’ is the third game in a series that revolutionized the super-hero Action-RPG genre and it does not stray from type. A prequel, set five years prior to 2009’s ‘Arkham Asylum’, it features a younger, more vulnerable Bruce Wayne, one still largely unknown to the citizens, criminals and constabulary of Gotham. The opening credits detail a mysterious break-in at Blackgate prison by local crime-boss ‘Black Mask’ who subsequently announces an open bounty of $50 Million dollars for the masked vigilante’s (Batman’s) head, drawing some of the world’s deadliest assassins to Gotham. An engrossing, well crafted campaign of twists and turns will take you across a broodingly atmospheric and expansive, open-world, filled to the brim with side-quests, collectibles, and cold-cases, amongst a veritable who’s-who of criminals, psychopaths and super-villains.

Gameplay | Graphics | Sound: Gameplay is from a third-person perspective, aligned around the game’s 4 main pillars of Flight and Stealth | Combat | Detective Mode | RPG elements (of character upgrades and customization), and these are largely unchanged from the well developed mechanics from earlier entries in the series. Besides the XP-based upgrades to obtain new armor, skills and weapons, a challenge system tasks the gamer with accomplishing targets of scaling difficulty to unlock new takedowns and abilities. ‘Origins’ also introduces two new gameplay features - 1. Crime Scene Investigations and 2. A Multiplayer Component - ‘Crime Scenes’ is an innovative concept triggered at various points during the campaign wherein you are tasked with studying a crime scene, and identifying ballistics, DNA and forensic evidence in an attempt to recreate/solve the incident in a mini-game format. While novel, it is unfortunately somewhat shallow in implementation and thereby predictable, and has to count as a real missed opportunity in driving the series’ gameplay forward. Multiplayer features the ability to play as Batman, Robin, The Joker and Bane as well as various gang-members in a good variety of game modes which while completely serviceable, again seems largely tacked on and unnecessary. Finally, completion of the main campaign unlocks higher difficulty challenges with ‘New Game Plus’ and ‘Worst Nightmare’ modes, and good visuals, strong voice-acting and responsive controls (for both K&M | Controller) round out a well designed, feature-rich offering.

Flaws: Quibbles include average graphics and poor textures in areas, stuttering framerates in others, and a confounding inability to grapple freely onto any surface during flight – a seemingly general lack of the ol’ spit and polish, and a sense that this is more ‘Arkham City v1.5’, than an entirely new game.

Overall, ‘Batman: Arkham Origins’ succeeds in maintaining the legacy of the ‘Arkham’ series by capturing the essence of what it means to be the Dark Knight – be it through brooding atmosphere, an exceptionally strong narrative, a who’s-who cast of villains, a fun and effective combat system, fantastic boss fights, varied gameplay elements and all the toys and gadgets one would expect. Yes, it is iterative and quite similar to ‘Arkham City’, but keep in mind that it stands on the shoulders of two nearly perfect games, and fans of the series should enjoy it thoroughly nonetheless. Generally Well Recommended! – Rated (8.3/10)

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is an action adventure game developed and published by Warner Bros that was released on PC, PS3, Wii U, and Xbox 360 in October 2013.  This is the third main game in the Arkham Series which has been running since 2009.

Gameplay is basically the same as any other of the Arkham series of games. The same fluid and easy to grasp combat system is still the same, allowing you to string together some serious combos; I’m talking sometimes in the regions of 2000+! On top of the combat system, Batman comes prepared with his arsenal of gadgets to help him fight the bad guys, with plenty of returning favourites like the batarang and claw, but also some new additions such as Shock Gloves, and Concussion Detonator. Normally in past games, you are able to get by most situations without having to use too many of your tools, but you have a good range of moments throughout the main story to use everything here.

Something else which has been introduced is a fast travel system, since Gotham is so big, you really do need to take advantage of the fast travel system, but you can only use it once you take out certain control towers to free up the signal in that area. Another really welcome addition to the game.

After just completing the game about an hour ago, I am honestly finding it difficult to think of any aspect of the game play that I did not enjoy. I thoroughly enjoyed Arkham City and this really quenched my thirst for continuing the series.

Graphically whilst it was one of the latter big releases of the last generation of games, the game does look really impressive. I couldn’t quite push out the game on 4k resolution but was able to play at 1440p without any problems and it just looks gorgeous. I particularly like the snow effects in game, along with the really impressive textures across Gotham.   The game is run using the Unreal Engine 3, so you can expect some really good looking scenes in a well fleshed out environment.

The game does present some fairly tricky boss fights, each has their own style and way of beating them which is different from the last. If you want to get your combo streaks really high, you have to learn your combination attacks, and flow your counters and attacks together almost perfectly. It took me a while to get it down perfectly, but the rewards are certainly worth it when you can get combos of 500+ on some fights.

What the past Arkham game and this game really focus on, is the open world aspect of the Gotham. Yes you have the 10 hour long main story, but a lot of the game’s content comes in the optional side missions and tasks. There are a number of other well-known bad guys that you can take on and aim to take down. These can be anything from destroying chemical containers to disarming crates of weapons.  Whilst they mainly a lot of “follow the quest marker” style missions, they still have their own story and resolution which defiantly makes them worth your time to complete.    As you can see from the amount of hours I have been playing Origin’s, there is an awful lot of content to see and experience, and I would highly recommend people take the time to do so.

I didn’t have any technical issues whilst playing. I wasn’t running the game on SLI, purely off a single graphics card at 1440p with all of the settings maxed out. The game runs smoothly at 60fps without any glitches or stutters. This is a game I would strongly advise you play with a controller, given the way the Arkham style combat system works, you get the best movement and accuracy from using a controller over keyboard and mouse unfortunately, but it does play very well on a Steam controller.

In conclusion, I honestly can say Arkham Origin’s continues the trend of action packed and fun to play Batman games up to this point in the series. This game has often been criticized for lack of content and originality, I say they aren’t all fully true as there is so much content in this game, and why break something that’s not broken? Batman Arkham Origins is definitely worth the regular retail price of £14, 99 but you can get it a heck of a lot cheaper if you wait for sales. For me, this is a must play Batman game.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins opens with no intention of being anything but what is expected from it. In fact I was dropped into Blackgate Prison with such little fanfare and context that it almost felt as if I'd jumped back into Arkham City by mistake.

This was after all the same Gotham I had run through before, familiar architecture giving way to reflexive movements honed over my time with the first two Arkham games. All of Batman’s high-tech toys were still with him, disrupting Origins’ prequel status though at least allowing my to skip collecting them for yet a third time, and by and large everything would appear to be in its rightful place eager for another excursion into Gotham’s criminal underworld (though by now I’m willing there’s a warrant out for at least 90% of the city’s population).

But, therein lies the problem doesn’t it. That for whatever Origins’ is itself, it’s the third of its kind in five years, and what was once revolutionary is now mundane and ordinary. Arkham Asylum came out of nowhere as one of the best games of 2009, and easily the best Batman game ever released. Arkham City soon followed, blowing the series up into an open world and bringing with it some welcome improvements to Asylum’s mechanics, even if that came at the cost of being rather bloated with content it didn’t have any idea what to do with. So where does that leave Origins’ to take the franchise?

Well, it doesn’t really take it anywhere. Origins’ is alarmingly similar to the games that came before it, only without enough confidence to carry itself well enough to at least be comparable to them. Which, OK, it’s being handled by a new developer so perhaps some rough edges are to be expected as a new team attempts to take over the Arkham series until Rocksteady is able to finish their next game. But Origins’ failings extend beyond minor bugs or the occasional bad level design, into an overwhelming feeling that this is all just busywork to keep people busy until the “real” third Batman game arrives. And that makes it hard to appreciate Origins’ on its own merits, when even it seems to have accepted its role as a filler game.

It feels sloppy and rushed, in little and big ways that snowball into one another as the game seems to progressively care less and less about how it eventually turns out. Combat is identical to past games using the same attack/counter freeflow system, but it fumbles over itself far more often than in past games. I was constantly having combos break when I was attacked from off screen or had the camera fail to center on the next enemy, slipping up on counter timing that never felt right, or just having attacks fail to register properly as Batman shuffled in place as confused as I was. Encounter designs enhance these issues by popping up constantly and having no focus or balance to them. I was tossed into rings of dozens of guys with random weapons or armor, and these weird combinations made it difficult to create any kind of rhythm in the combat because it was constantly being broken by a random enemy with a knife or a car door or some other special attribute that might pop up once or a dozen times during a fight.

The Arkham fighting system is one of my favorites in any game, but less than halfway through Origins’ I was already becoming annoyed anytime I walked into a fight and knew even if I played perfectly I was still at the mercy of the game doing what I told it to do. There is a lot less stealth in Origins’ than either of the past games, which was at first disappointing until I finally arrived at a predator mission and then wished they had been omitted entirely. City had already began to stumble a bit in following up Asylum’s impeccable level designs, but Origins’ up and throws in the towel right from the start with levels that are both far too complicated yet feel significantly less tactical than past games. There are still grates you can hide in and gargoyles to hang from, but levels never account for your need to quickly move from cover to cover as you close the distance between you and a guard and just haphazardly place hiding spots throughout a room with no thought as to how you might use them in conjunction with one another.

Every stealth section felt like I was the one who was trapped, rather than the guards I was hunting, leaving me scrambling to take them out as soon as possible instead of anything more methodical and coordinated. I died more times in Origins’ than I ever did in either of the past two games, and it almost always was because I had attempted to takedown an enemy in any way other than hanging upside down and waiting for them to walk underneath. These sections became very boring almost immediately, when previously they had been my favorite parts of the Arkham games.

Maybe this is simply the result of being spoiled by Rocksteady’s games, but Origins’ doesn’t exist in a vacuum and even seems to assume to player will already be familiar with the formula. It doesn’t bother to explain mined gargoyles or enemies with sonar goggles, because if you have played City you already know how they work. It’s entirely aware of its heritage, so treating it as a self contained work feels pointless and disingenuous. It doesn’t feel like a step forward for the series though, being closer to b-roll content cut from City rather than something original.

Where the Arkham series had the most ground to make up though, and where Origins’ even had the capacity to do so was its narrative, and to its credit this is far and away the most engaging and cohesive plot the series has ever known. The cast has been trimmed down from City’s over indulgent buffet of characters, which allows Origins’ to spend more time developing them into interesting, complicated characters I wanted to know more about. Many of the assassins called in to collect a five million dollar bounty placed on Batman’s head don’t get as much time as they deserve, but they’re compensated by a far deeper, disturbed Batman who is still early in his career as a vigilante and less prepared to face the villains he’s after. At times his sense of justice and methods for carrying it out border on sociopathic, a side of him that’s not lost on those he comes in contact with and which eventually comes to a head as he is forced to come to terms with whether or not his actions are actually justified.

It’s familiar ground for Batman as a character, but its a part of him I never grow tired of exploring and which brilliantly accompanies Troy Baker’s fantastic performance as The Joker. I thought I was ready to be done with the deranged clown, but the interactions between him and Batman are so compelling I simply wish Origins’ didn’t take so long getting to them, upon which it quickly changes the subject again. The narrative as a whole is still inconsistent, but it’s Origins’ one true advancement for the series which I hope will be continued with future Arkham games.

I have a hard time flat-out calling Arkham Origins a “bad” game, but it’s saved almost solely on the strengths of what has been brought over from past games (and then butchered) and carries with it a very qualified recommendation to anyone but the most devoted fans of the series. This is still an Arkham game deep down somewhere, with some exceptional characterization that sadly isn’t given enough time to shine, and by now the rhythms of the series have become so natural to me that it wasn’t difficult to get into a simple groove and fly through the game despite how unimpressive it was. I guess what I find most unpleasant is just that in only five years and three games it already feels like Batman has already shown us all he has to offer, and I’ve only reruns to look forward to in the bi-annual future.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText: Basically Arkham City with a new story. I still hate the boss fights, but love taking out rooms of enemies without being detected and  gliding around the city finding things. Maybe one day we'll get a Batman game that offers the Dishonored approach of multiple ways to complete objectives, but until that fantasy comes true, this is good fun.\nEdit: After finishing the game, I can say it feels more tedious than Arkham City did. The combat's not as smooth, and I think it's because there were some changes to the button combinations for special attacks, although it's been awhile since I played AC, so I might be remembering incorrectly. There are also numerous small obstacles that for unknown reasons you're unable to step on/over, which really throws off the flow of moving around the city. I mostly used fast travel, once it was unlocked, because they made travel by running, grappling, and gliding too much of a pain. Finally, there are several small bugs. Nothing completely game breaking, but I had to reload a checkpoint on at least three separate occasions because of n enemy getting stuck somewhere I couldn't reach, or the option to interrogate not triggering.\nOverall, still worth playing if you loved the previous games, but if you weren't completely sold on them, this will be even less fun, and should be avoided.

reviewText:
Note before reading the review
--------------------------------------------
Keep in mind, the recommendation/non-recommendation of the game is NOT an indication of the game being good or not (it's a great game). I just can't recommend it because, in its current state, the game is a bug-riddled mess. I myself did manage to beat the game, and I enjoyed (almost) every minute of it. Fantastic game. When it works, it is definitely the best Arkham game out there, but I can't, in good conscience, recommend a triple A, 50 dollar title that doesn't work for a major portion of the playerbase. If these bugs are fixed, the game's an easy recommendation. 9/10 game. Phenomenal. Incredible atmosphere, incredible gameplay, and the best writing in an Arkham game (sorry Paul Dini). But right now, this game, in its current state, simply cannot be recommended.
-------------------------------------------

Batman: Arkham Origins is one of the best examples of a fantastic game riddled by bugs. Great story (probably the best in an Arkham game), and great gameplay marred by atrocious problems. Bugs so far include a bug that prevents people from launching the game, game crashes (preventing the game from being completed), and keyboard/mouse control problems (where you can't land critical hits). There are even reports of people being unable to attack! Some bugs are minor, like Batman jerking up and down while gliding (kind of funny, actually). Overall, I can't recommend the game, in particular because of the gamebreaking bugs that can occur.

Gameplay-wise, the game is great. It's not as good as Arkham City, because of major balancing issues with certain gadgets. For example, the Remote Claw is incredibly overpowered in Predator missions. Painfully overpowered, because of the Remote Claw Takedown, for example. It's basically a ranged, silent, inverted takedown. The Electrocutioner Gloves, in combat, grant you 2x per punch (3x per crit) on your Combo Counter, and can punch through shields/armor/stun batons, allow you to counter any enemy attacks. The gameplay is fun overall though. The new Crime Scene feature is cool, even if it holds your hand. The new gadgets do prove for interesting gameplay.

If you're gonna drop $50 on a game, it better damn well work, and right now, WB Games can't guarantee even that. If you can run it, I promise you that you're in for a damn treat, but there's a relatively high chance that you can't.

UPDATE: There are reports with people having issues booting the game still, a whole month after release. Sadly, this is unacceptable. I can't comment on the multiplayer for the game, as I've only played 3 or 4 matches. In terms of multiplayer problems, I've heard that after the recent update, player levels got reset without warning. Also, I was able to beat the game without encountering anything gamebreaking, but I also know that some of my friends can't even launch the game in its current state -- some FATAL ERROR OZZY thing. It's quite saddening, really.

UPDATE 2: I want to expand a bit on the graphics and sound design of the game, since I barely touched on it. The game runs rather well on max settings (apart from PhysX), using DX11 features at 1920x1080 on my setup -- with an i5-3470, and an AMD Radeon HD 7950 -- specifically between 40 and 80 frames per second depending on the area, it's perfectly playable, and it looks good for a game working around the limitations of Unreal Engine 3. The visual and sound design in the game together is absolutely amazing. It was good enough to make me believe it was Christmas, if not just for a moment in October. Roger Craig Smith, and Troy Baker are absolutely fantastic at reprising their roles as Batman and the Joker respectively. Brilliant stuff.

UPDATE 3: Aaaand Warner Bros has no plans to fix Arkham Origins bugs, apart from some keyboard/mouse functionality with Deathstroke challenge missions. ...Maybe.

http://ca.ign.com/articles/2014/02/10/wb-games-has-no-plans-to-fix-numerous-glitches

UPDATE 4: Critical Hit on KBM bug was fixed some time ago, not sure when.

reviewText:
There are definitely some similarities between Origins and its predecessors.  The action buttons are almost entirely the same, which was nice since I didn't have to learn an entirely new system.  There is a ton of content, we still have The Riddler as a background story, there are many optional side-quests and distractions, but it felt like there were *too* many distractions in this one.

In Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, I never lost track of the main storyline, despite my frequent forays into side-quest territory.  Not so with Origins.  I can't count how many times I came back to my computer with absolutely no idea what I was supposed to be doing.  It felt aimless and repetitive, even when I was working towards a side-goal.

One of the things I REALLY enjoyed about the first two games is the riddles we had to figure out.  Oh we still have two hundred data packs to find (the predecessor to the Riddler trophies we saw in Asylum and City,) but no actual riddles to figure out.  I really missed them, and the data packs simply don't hold enough of my interest to make up for the lack of riddles -- I'm not even going to try to get them all.

The in-game achievements would sometimes work, most times not.  I literally flew from one end of Arkham to the other, and never got the flying achievements.  It took four or five tries to get the notification that I'd taken down two criminals in a slide.  Just frustrating.

Besides the irritation of not remembering where and what I was supposed to be doing, there was also the frustration of not being able to grapple places that clearly should have been accessible.  It was very obvious where we could and couldn't grapple in the previous games, so I don't feel like it's asking too much for this third game.  We DO have a quick-transportation option, which is nice, but I still would have liked it to be clear where we could and couldn't grapple just by looking.

There *are* some improvements over the first two games.  For instance, when we are locating the extra special" criminals (those holding information we need
date: etc) we don't have to save them for last in order to get the information.  If we want to
recommended: we can take them out first
hoursPlayed: then go back and interrogate them when the fight is over.  Another improvement is the crime scene investigation.  They've really added an element of interest to it

reviewText: As a fan of Batman, I had to get this. The game is mostly fine, good graphics and sound and such. Fun story and of course the fighting mechanics are still the main attraction here. However, I cannot recommend this title due to serious game breaking bugs. I managed to avoid most of them thanks to some research, but I've now fallen to one nearly 55% through the game. Currently stuck in a void and no amount of restarting or changes will fix it and thanks to the single save auto-saving system, there's no way to revert to an older save... This is clearly the sort of thing that should be found in QA. Now I have no choice but to restart the whole game. So, if you desperately want to play this game, just be sure you know there are many game breaking bugs that can completely wipe out your save. It's like playing Russian Roulette with your time. I lost 20+ hours. How much will you lose? And a good sarcastic thanks WB Games and the developers for not bothering to fix these terrible gamebreaking bugs.

reviewText:
Extremely Glitchy. However, when it's not glitching out, it's a very fun game and I'm loving the story. It's just that I've become very impatient with it and worrying every few minutes over how it's going to screw up.

I've fallen through the map so many times, had enemies fly into space when I tried to interrogate, groups of enemies on the streets become static, sometimes keybindings won't register, got stuck inbetween places, game crash/freezes while gliding, certain items won't work until restart, clicking would suddenly change to throw a batarang for some reason... and I've had to restart the game so many times.

So I would not recommend it if you're expecting smooth gameplay. If it weren't for all those constant issues, I would say that it is a great game with an enjoyable story.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham OriginsDeveloper: WB Games Montreal, Splash Damage
Publisher: Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment

Introduction
==========
Arkham Origins is the third game in the Arkham series, and is a prequel to Arkham Asylum. It's also developed by a different team from the other games. Overall it still retains most of the features from the previous 2 games, Asylum and City, but it's noticably different. It's still the same great gameplay you'd expect from Batman and the Arkham series, and it every bit as good as the other titles, despite the differences.

Gameplay
==========
Arkham Origins plays largely the same as Arkham Asylum and Arkham City did. Batman still has all his gadgets, in addition to a few new ones: the remote claw, the shock and thermal gloves, the disruptor, and the glue grenade...just to name a few. He can still grapple around the city and glide everywhere he goes. He can still throw the most beautiful punches and kicks you've come to expect from the Arkham series, with a few fresh new moves. Despite being from a different developer, Origins pretty much looks and feels exactly like an Arkham game should. WB Montreal did a really good job at implementing the battle system, UI (for the most part), and experience systems we've all come to know and love. Once you get into the flow of the game and in a good stride, you'll forget that a different studio made the game. It's still an Arkham game, and for the most part it still has all the features and mechanics you'd expect. Combos, Takedowns, gadgets and environment interactions...it's all here.

One of the biggest things Origins adds to the formula in this entry is the Crime Scene Scanning and Rewind features. When presented with a crime scene, Batman goes into evidence scanning mode. As you scan pieces of evidence scattered throughout a crime scene, the events are slowly pieced together bit by bit, until eventually what happened at the crime scene can be played back with complete control. You can fast forward and rewind to specific moments of the crime to help locate hidden pieces of evidence. These scenes are spread throughout the game, and help to offer a sort of puzzle element to the game.

Quite possibly the most useful feature added in this installment is Fast Travel. Scattered throughout the city are radio towers under enemy control. Once liberated, these towers serve as Fast Travel Points. At anytime while outside in the city, Batman can call the Batwing to come pick him up and drop him off at any of the unlocked radio towers. This is immensely useful in getting around in such a large city.

You still have your usual fare of side quests and Riddler challenges, and quite a bit of your time will probably be spent doing these.

Batman: Arkham Origins is the first game in the Arkham series to include multiplayer. Unfortunately it did not appear to last long. I went into Multiplayer Mode at least a few times and only saw about 2-3 people online hosting their own games. It's safe to say that multiplayer is dead. That's too bad, as going head-to-head with other players in different modes would have been a blast for me to try out.

Graphics
==========
This entry in the Arkham series looks just a tad different from the others, but it looks great. The city is what really shines here. It's Christmas Eve in-game, so it's snowing all over the city. One of the details I noticed is if you are on a snow-covered rooftop, Batman leaves footprints in the snow everywhere. These didn't fade away after a few seconds like in other games, but they do go awat after an area transistion though.

Gotham City is dark. Secrets are hidden everywhere. All character models are sharp and extremely detailed. Batman still gets tears in his cape and damaged spots on his body armor as the adventure progresses.

Sound and Music
==========
The biggest thing you will probably notice in this area is that Origins features a different set of voice actor for the main characters. Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill are not reprising their roles of Batman and the Joker in this entry. For hardcore fans, this may be a turn-off. The voice actors they have sound really close though! The soundtrack is, again, the kind of fare you'd expect from Batman. Dark, dramatic, ambient. The kind of music that sets a dark mood fitting for Batman. The kind that says 'Don't mess with the Bat'.

Performance
==========
In all my hours of play, I didn't run into a single performance issue. The game ran at a near flawless 60 FPS at all times, even during combat with many enemies on screen or when I was zipping around the city using the grapple gun. I also used a controller the entire time, and it felt so responsive and intuitive. I had zero issues doing everything with a controller.

One small gripe I had was with the online aspect. When you boot up the game, it automatically logs you into your WB Account (once you sign up for one, which gives you a bonus skin for Batman btw), before going to the main menu. At a few different points the game got hung up on the logging in part. It took me switching Steam to Offline Mode to start playing again. I don't know if this issue was due to the WB servers being down or what, but I could not find anything pertaining to it through at least 20 minute of Google searching and the few minutes I spent scanning the game's news and updates section on Steam. Apparently others have had this issue a few times over the past couple of years.

Final Thoughts
==========
Arkham Origins is every bit as good as it's predecessor. It's what we've come to expect from the Arkham series. It still puts you right into the shoes of the Caped Crusader and offers a unique experience and an original story. Very well worth a purchase, and it belongs in every fan's game catalog. Expect a great single player campaign full of twists and turns, plenty of combat scenarios, and lots of detective work. Expect...Batman!

Gameplay Demo
==========
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1GRQfixbWDc

Nerd House Verdict:
==========
Highly Recommended

Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText: The PC version of Batman: Arkham Origins is absolutely the best in terms of detail, smoothness, drawing distance and particle effects, though it suffers from a series of annoying glitches.For being a prequel to the Arkham series, this really kicks things off with a bang.Best story telling out of the series. Phenomenal voice acting.There's definitely some re-tread going on with Batman: Arkham Origins, but the combat, the relatively good story, the powerful feeling of being Batman in video game form has only increased my enthusiasm for the franchise.You can't go wrong with sticking to Rocksteady's Bat-formula, however it is starting to feel a little played out.Arkham Origins is a very good but very familiar game.It lacks the spice of originality that made the previous two games great.If you’re a Batman fan you should already have Batman: Arkham Origins.

reviewText:
While Origins doesn't add much over its predecessor, there are a few new gadgets and enemy types, the boss battles are consistently better, and the story is arguably better than Asylum's story. If you were hoping for a drastic change in the formula, you'll likely be disappointed, but this is easily the best Batman Arkham game to date!

reviewText:
This game is great.  It seems to have more negative reviews and scores compared to the Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, and there are a few reasons for it, but in a lot of ways this one seems better too.

This game has some bugs and some people might have certain performance issues.  As far as I can tell, that is what most of the negativity comes from.
- The cutscenes (not the cinematic ones, those are fine) can be pretty laggy.
- I've had weird glitches with my cape while flying.  While not gamebreaking, it will definitely ruin your immersion.
- I had some lag issues while fighting the very lovely female Copperhead.
- Many people have had a bug while fighting the end boss that doesn't allow you to counter some of his attacks.  Because it is a quick time event fight, this will keep you from progressing.  The only way to get around this, is to reduce your resolution by quite a bit.  Why does that work, I don't know.
- I've had some people that I needed to interrogate, where the interrogate option would not work at all.  I relaunched the game and then it was fine, but we shouldn't have to do that.

This game is still great though, even if you do encounter these issues.  Besides that it ran smoothly for me.  The base game is tons of fun.  It is a prequel to the previous Arkham games, where Batman is somewhat new to Gotham.  Assassins have been hired to kill you.  You don't really have any friends aside from Alfred.  The cops are after you just as much as the assassins and the gangs are, and other enemies besides them as well.  There is DLC for this game that has a story centered around Mr. Freeze as well which is quite cool (ha...ha...ha...).  The map is very large, and there's quite a bit to do.  Aside from the bugs, this is great, and you can pick it up at fairly cheap prices when on sale.

The game also has a multiplayer mode that pits Batman and Robin, the Joker and his crew, and Bane and his thugs all against each other.  It's a lot of fun.

You may be the world's greatest assassin
recommended: but Joker always gets the last laugh!" -The Joker"

reviewText:
Single Player Mode:

The game starts on the end of year 3, when everyone in gotham is starting to realize that the batman isn't a hoax, but real.

On the height of Christmas Eve, Black Mask sends contract killers to find and kill the bat before dawn.

Over the course of the game, More and more villains enter the fray and do battle with the bat, Including the police force headed by the corrupt Police Commissioner Loeb and S.W.A.T officer Brandon.

This game depicts the batman's rise from hoax to legend in one night.

Multi-Player Mode:

After enduring the generic insanity that is the COD and BF franchise, I congratulate splash damage for making something really original.

While i admit there are some stupid things about multi-player, Like progress not saving or credits not giving out which happens rarely, (I still haven't had that happens to me yet, Thank god!) The Multiplayer mode is pretty fantastic!

And then there's the gaming community who don't know how teamwork works or just don't care about it, Ragequitting in anger when shot or taken down multiple time's.

Story: 9 out of 10

The game starts off pretty slow until the steel mill, Then it kicks into overdrive!

Controls: 7 out of 10

While the controls are the same as the previous games, they feel a little sticky and sluggish.

Gameplay: 6 out of 10

Despite being the same from the previous games, WB Games Montreal decide to make the combat harder, Sending large groups of normal thugs at you even at low level, Making the Electrocutioners's glove's a top priority if you wan't to survive longer in the game, (And don't get me started on the sniper's in the diamond district!) The Boss Battle's are really fun and engaging refreshing pace from the dull combat we are used too.

Extra Content: 10 out of 10

The Sidequests and the optimal Challenge mode makes for replayability, But the real meat on the bone is New Game Plus and I Am The Knight mode. (Never did that one, Because i'm too scared to try.)

Overall Score: 8 out of 10


Final Thoughts: After a pretty unstable release, Its still a pretty good addition to the franchise, It might not be better than Arkham City, But then again i never expected it too.

Now to wait for the next game..................................soon

reviewText:
Batman Arkham Origins doesn't fix what already worked in the previous games, so Warner Bros. is playing it safe really.

The last 2 Batman games were awesome, especially the first. The second one was a bit too ambitious, throwing you into the deep way too soon. Arkham Origins fortunately doesn't do this, but it doesn't hold your hand either, which is a good thing. But the city is a bit too similar to Arkham City, and yes, even though it is Christmas time, it also feels way too empty, with hardly a civilian to be found anywhere and empty cars standing on the middle of the road.

Thankfully, there's plenty of content, with lots of sidequests and collectibles and a beefy storyline. Just like the other 2 games. And there's more than enough variety as far as the villains are concerned. Just like the other 2 games.

And, of course, there are plenty of gadgets. ... Just like the other games... Sure, there are a few new ones but most of them work the same way as some of the gadgets found in the previous games (like the glue gun).

Graphically it all looks amazing, with that dark Batman vibe dating back to Batman Returns on the SNES. The voice acting and music are also all very solid and gameplay wise it all works very well.
It's just that Origins doesn't show enough innovation. It all feels and looks very similar. They should really try and expand the game for possible sequels. Give us something new, something to get excited about.

Anyway, you will, once again, get plenty of content for your money by buying this. That's also not the thing that you should be worried about. The thing is, can you look past its flaws and enjoy a game that's basically Arkham City 2.5 ?

[Rating: 82/100]

reviewText:
Arkham Origins is a great game with a very bad launch which makes it underrated. Different studio on an Arkham game means a different aproach, which in this case turned out to be a solid job. The gameplay is less good, there are more gadgets, the city is bigger and colder, the story feel more alive and the soundtrack helps making it all epic. The story is well written, has many epic moments and does it job at keeping you entertained and keeping your interest in, which is great considering it's a prequel. In this game, Batman is in his early days, fighting both criminality and law. In the night you're playing, 8 assassins mean to kill, all organized by the man behind a mask. There are characters like Joker, Bane, but new even unheard ones from the past games like Deathstroke, Firefly and Shiva. The main story is great and the sidequests are a joy to do (only there you'll confront some of the assassins).

Advantages of the game:There are more gadgets
The city is larger than the previous two games
Good epic moments
Interesting location
Interesting boss battles
Memorable personalities like superheroes and villains
Fascinating history

Negative in the game:
Fighting system is easier than in Batman: Arkham City
Series of annoying glitches
The graphic is not level as in the previous two games

reviewText:
Do you know how Batman introduced himself to Gotham? How he engaged his foes for the first time?

Answering these questions Batman: Arkham Origins continues succeding of previous titles. New better graphics and story tailored exactly for batman games fans is what caught me. Sadly except from this the game has nothing more then previous games to offer. Still solving riddles beating criminals and revealing secrets is what entertained me for hours. Predator mode, where you pick guarding enemies one by one silently, is still one of the best features of the game enhanced of some new gadgeds.

8.5 /10

Some of you would think I overrated this game, but I think the story is pretty impressive and outweighs minor inconviniences of other aspects of the game.
If you are considering buying season pass I advise you to do not, only one I think worth it is Cold Cold Heart story pack.

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, I love batman games, but this one just felt insanely cheap.
Combat is exactly the same except for an extremely overpowered powerup you get about halfway through the game, which completely destroys the purpose of special enemies.
As far as the main story goes, it took me just under 10 hours to complete, and felt insanely boring the whole way through.
The whole way through this just felt like an arkham city DLC, with the only difference being slightly better graphics and different enemies.
The side missions aren't very exciting at all and the collectibles are just too boring to collect (coming from someone who collected every single riddler trophy and riddle in arkham city) and are not rewarding at all.
This game is not worth the full price, and you shouldn't play this with very high expectations.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is a commercial release of a total conversion mod for Batman: Arkham City.  That is not to say the game is bad by any means, it is however absolutely devoid of any innovation and serves as little more than a reskin with an altered map.

By setting the game years earlier than the previous two Arkham titles one would expect less gadgets and more low-tech solutions and puzzles in the game, instead all the same tools present in City have returned in Origins, even Mr. Freeze's ice grenades, which are retextured to be glue grenades instead but function identically.  The exact same hacking, the exact same remote controlled batarang...  It is all more of the same.  Some of the Riddler's puzzles are taken directly from City and used over again with only minor tweaks.

Again, not a bad game, but when you put out a new game the player should be able to expect a few interesting new things to see and do.  There are a few new bugs that I had not encountered in City present in Origins, so they got that going for them, which is nice I guess.

Yes, it is a game worth playing, but no, it is not a full game, so don't ever get it for a full price.

reviewText:
Ok, first off I'm going to warn you guys that there are SPOILERS in my review, so if you don't want to know, then don't read. Otherwise, in a nutshell, the game was a huge disappointment and, in my opinion, wasn't even worth 5 bucks. I truly wish I could get a refund.

NOW THE REASONS WHY:

First off, the game is extremely glitchy/bugged, which tells me that the company/developers behind the game put out an unfinished and/or untested product on the market, probably because they were in a hurry to get their money.

The fact that I couldn't even get through the first boss fight (which doesn't even take that long to get to ingame) without experiencing an almost game breaking glitch is just pathetic honestly. The fact that the glitch was SO BAD that the music was disappearing, Killer Croc was turning invisible, and then shortly after that the screen went black is probably some of the worst glitching I've seen in a while. The only fix was for me to have to lower my resolution and FX JUST TO GET THROUGH THE FIGHT. Might I mention that I left my settings the same for the rest of the game and had no problems, and this is a well known bug on the internet forums, some people stating they still couldn't fix it, so I'm one of the lucky ones. This is just one game breaking glitch among PAGES UPON PAGES on internet forums that you should probably take into consideration before even bothering with this crappy game.

Now, I'm a person who owns and has played/beaten the other Arkham games, and I can honestly say that the controls and combat are way slower/stiffer/clunkier than the predecessors. There were times where I was going to pull my hair out because the game would alter my settings without me knowing and would invert the camera angles, or my character would activate a gadget I didn't even have selected which would cost me in a fight.

AND FYI, the company behind the game hasn't bothered to fix these glitches at all and from the sounds of it they've practically abandoned the game by now so there won't BE any fixes unless you want to do the freakin programming yourself. BUT OH WAIT IT GETS BETTER

You can't access the ingame built in console (F10) in the vanilla version of the game xD *facepalm*. Wow. So good luck fixing the game. I'll get back onto this subject in a bit, but lets move onto the next issues.

Second, if you're a  batman nerd and know your batman trivia, this game is going to drive you insane, especially on the chronological level. The writing for the game was terrible and in my opinion put a number of the characters in situations or saying certain things that I personally felt was not accurate for their character development. Gordon would NEVER be willing to send his men into a dangerous situation, KNOWING Firefly has the bombs set up and threatened to blow up everyone but the vigilante, simply just to SPITE Batman because I follow the law and you don't". Batman would not destroy the Gotham christmas tree simply to be a jerk to a petty insignificant criminal for no necessary/logical reason

reviewText:
Extremely underrated game.
This may be the worst Batman: Arkham game in terms of gameplay, mechanics, and polish (haven't played Knight yet), but that doesn't mean it isn't just as great of a game as the others. Sure, there are a few minor glitches and the design isn't as polished as the other Arkham games, but it was still loads of fun and the story kept me coming back. Speaking of the story, Origins' story may be the best story in the Arkham series and is definitely the best thing about this game. The writing is phenomenal and serves as a fantastic origin story to the Arkham series. I immediately bought Roger Craig Smith's portrayal of a young Bruce Wayne. Although Troy Baker's Joker took a little getting used to due to my obsession with Mark Hamill's Joker, Baker's Joker grew on me and I now love him (almost) as much as Hamill's Joker. Additionally, this game easily had the best boss fights in the Arkham series up to this point.

Don't let this game's reputation as the worst Arkham game stop you from buying this game. It's just as enjoyable as the others, and I highly reccomend it, especially for the story and boss fights.

The open-world design feels empty and unrealistic.

reviewText:
Single player	This game has a good story, a slightly similar combat system of arkham city with a few new added gadgets , new enemy types, and about 9 villains you get to face off and fight. Unlike arkham knight boss battles, this installment brings back the feeling of what its like to fight actual bosses who could kill you if your not too careful for example bane, deathstroke, cooperhead and others.

Multiplayer	The multiplayer in this game is also good. There are 3 teams Jokers gang, Bane's gang and batman and robin .You get to play as one of the elite henchmen who work for either the joker or bane and you get to play as batman and robin, sort of like a predator/prey system where about 6 players are henchmen(prey) and 2 players are batman and robin(hunter). I like how the mutiplayer gives you the opportunity to play as henchman and get to experience their perspective of being stalked by batman, you maybe thinking how hard can it be to spot a man in bat costume or even be scared of him but trust me after playing as a henchmen you will FEAR THE KNIGHT.The drawback to multiplayer is that its really hard to find a match when there aren't many online players, each matchmaking session takes about 10-15 minutes which is abit frustrating and things get even worse when a game starts with people who are either afk or disconnected during the match since there is no vote to kick feature and players can't join during multiplayer sessions.

This game may not be as good as arkham city but its still worth buying and playing. I recommend buying when its on offer like i did, then you won't regret your decision if you dont like it.

reviewText: Batman: Arkham Origins is the third game in the franchise, and a prequel to Arkham Asylum. It takes place around 5-years prior to Batman: Arkham Asylum and features Batman going head to head with 8 assassins sent by Black Mask. Not only are gotham's most dangerous assassings out to kill you, but the Gotham City police are trying to apprehend you, so you are alone. As with previous Batman games, the perspective is third-person, with all of the usual gadgets and tricks. For those who enjoy multiplayer, there is a multiplayer version of Arkham Origins as well.\n\nDuring fights I felt like the perspective would roll around to much and it was a little distracting. Gameplay is essentially like the other Batman games, and visually, it looks and feels like Arkham Asylum with a few differences made to the interior of the prison. I didn't test out the multiplayer mode, but I've heard mixed reviews on it. In all, Arkham Origins has an interesting story that shows us what life was like for Batman, prior to his assisting the Gotham City police.

reviewText:
Make no mistake, this is a fantastic game. The media reviews of this game are incredibly biased and bashes everything based on the fact that it is not made by Rocksteady. If the game changes too much, it is unfaitful, if it doesn't change, then it is uninnovative. There is no pleasing of the media dogs.

This game kept everything that made Arkham City amazing and added upon it. Here's a list of pros and cons that I've experienced during the game:

Pros:
1. The new detective vision allows far more interesting interactions with crime scenes and now actually requires effort to solve a case.
2. Fast travel is now available to compensate for the larger city
3. Superior story telling. This game tells a fantastic story of Batman's  beginnings and lets you see into the internal struggles of Joker. In terms of story and character presentation, Origins well surpassed its predecessor.
4. Much improved graphics including higher texture resolution, dynamic lighting and ambient occulsion.
5. Far more optimized than Arkham City for the PC, better performance overall
6. More gadgets provide more ways to terrorize your enemies
7. More complex city geometry with multiple layers

Cons:
1. Bugs. Even though bugs still exists, they are more or less small glitches that are less likely to be game breaking. Of the 20 hours of gameplay there have only been 1 time where a bug actually got me into trouble.
2. Factial animation. While most of the characters have impressive facial animations, for some reason a few characters just never got the same effort put in to them. Gordon and Alfred talks without ever moving a facial muscle, which feels quite creepy...
3. Somewhat shorter in length compares to Arkham City, less side quests and shorter main story.
4. Grapple lock feels less accurate than its predecessor, aiming of your grapple can be a serious issue when you are trying to do some fast swings.

Overall I am incredibly pleased with the game, if you still have doubts, pick it up after it goes on a steep sale, which is likely to happen soon due to the relatively low sales figures...

reviewText:
Let's start with the short review:
The third entry in the Arkham franchise is good, but it's also superfluous. If you're looking for more Arkham, then by all means don't skip this game. That's what I was looking for when I started Origins, and I wasn't disappointed. I consider this game superfluous because it really doesn't do anything better than Arkham City. Indeed, in some cases it's pretty lacking.

And now for the long review:
The story to Arkham Origins is...well I'll be vague here. There's a bounty on the Dark Knight's head and eight villains are looking to collect. It's up to the player to put a stop to this nonsense and save the day. The pacing and story are a bit uneven, with a number of segments feeling like they're not really going anywhere. There's a distinct lack of great set-pieces, those moments that really define the Batman experience. That's not to say there isn't any, but they tend to get clumped together. It's like wow give me a chance to breathe here. There are even a couple objectives that seem to exist, solely to make sure Batman is in a particular place, so it doesn't break the next objective. Still the story definitely has its moments, the characters are well-done, and by the end I had a good sense of what WB Montreal was going for with the plot.

Next up there is the city. On one hand I like that unlike Arkham City, Gotham doesn't have The Riddler's ????? fetish on display around every corner. His trademark riddles are around, but they blend in a bit better with the surroundings. It's less guady, which counts for a lot. There are some nice details throughout the city. Overall though I can't say I'm too fond of it. Arkham City's..uh...city is more stylized, which is understandable since its villainous inhabitants have dressed it up to fit their personality. Still, I was expecting something a bit more gothic and ornate. There are elements of that and yet sometimes the city can look just plain. Aside from the aesthetics, Arkham City simply had a better design and flow" to it. It felt like more time was spent creating a slice of Gotham that the player could really move around in. Origins on the other hand

reviewText:
Origins is a really good game, if taken out of the series. But having in mind that it comes out after AC it fails to protect its name.

+ The visuals are great and the game runs smoothly
+ It gives more of the same, while trying to add new things to the franchise
+ The story is by far the best from the 3 games. The voice acting and story reveal are top notch
+ Good additions: Score system, I am the night mode
- Terrible level design, bad city design
- Full of bugs
- Fillers, easy riddles and direct copy-pastes
- The smoothnes and battle rhythm from AC is gone

Score: 70/100

reviewText: Despite Arkham Origins being an excellent game in its own right, it's hard to ignore the Arkham City comparison. Warner Brothers took no risks with Origins, and the few changes they made were for the worse. Everything in Arkham Origins is an exact replica of Arkham City, except with different buildings that you go into and obviously a younger story.\nThe only thing that's stopping this game from being completely pointless is the story. Seeing the characters when they are younger is quite interesting, but the story lacks focus it jumps around too much.\nThe multiplayer is tacked on, and doesn't even work most of the time on PC. The concept and class system and stuff is all just flawed and tacked on for the sake of it. Overall, Arkham Origins has solid foundations but fails to expand upon them.

reviewText:
Batman Arkham Origins stars a more younger Batman... a more reckless and more naive Batman that's just now being hunted down - literally - by a group of Assassin's hired by the Black Mask after a prison is raided and the old Police Commisioner dies - Batman is now being hunted by both cops, thugs and the assassins.

The newest Sequel, which is a Prequel to Arkham Asylum - was developed by a new studio - not Rocksteady, and there were some... changes and some not-so changes that ultimately make this, in my opinion, the worst Batman Arkham game out there right now. It is still a solid game however and it is pretty well built.

Now this game, visually, is a little different from the more Comic/Cartoony looking Arkham games Rocksteady had made. Origins looks a bit more... like plastic I should say but it's not entirely bad, same goes for the major enemies like Deathstroke, Killer Croc and the like. The environments also look pretty cool as you see snow tracks being made by either you or enemies (can be further enhanced by Direct X11 tasselation and PhysX features, respectively) but I found myself feeling a sort of Deja Vu, and it wasn't too far fetched to say they directly lifted models and scapes and pretty much rebuilt Arkham City and modeled it to be a standalone Gotham, which was pretty lazy - however, the nifty visual effects DX11 can bring, make this game quite a looker, Batman himself looks pretty beefy (though I noticed there is a might tight bit wrong with his model - his right arm seems to be longer than his left arm), the major enemies look pretty well designed with the minor nitpick that the enemy models repeat far too much and offer little to no variety.

Batman here has pretty much the exact same gadgets he has in Arkham Asylum and City - disappointingly enough. Other than the Shock Gloves - there's nothing you obtain that really makes much of an advancement over City. You still have your standard Batarangs, the Sonic Batarangs, Smoke Pellets, the Explosive Gel, the Grapple Hook and it's enhancer, the Decrypter and of course - the new Shock Gloves, which you obtain later on in the game. The Shock Gloves are like a temporary upgrade in combat that enhances your damage and makes your attacks unblockable while they are active. To Power up the Shock Glove, you still counter and fight as your normally would in a fight, once powered, you can activate 'em and start wreaking havoc. The Shock Gloves made the game considerably easier and it's the main way you're going to be able to add a 2x hit to your combo counter, unlike how it originally worked in Asylum - which was with an upgrade to your combos.

There are also a multitude of upgrades. Sadly, this was made worse thanks to a streamlining system they made for it. On previous Batman Arkham games, you could purchase upgrades as you would unlock them via sthe story - be them Health, Defense, Finishers, combos enhancers/extenders, etc - you can still buy ALL of them in Origins, but you need to buy previous and sometimes completely unrelated upgrades in order to get the ones you want. This to me was not a very welcome addition as it just made me want to pump all my upgrades into one skill tree instead of balancing out Batman but frankly, other than Defense enhancers (one for ballistics/bullets and one for armour/fist fights) there wasn't much I really wanted to get as upgrades in this particular game are pretty minimal.

This game pretty much plays out like past Arkham games - it has the exact same Free Flow" combo combat

reviewText:
Arkham Origins is a very curious title in a lot of ways. It was made by a different developer than the previous two games, since Rocksteady was busy working on Arkham Knight.

The things Origins does well is mostly in the storytelling department. I really liked how the game takes place early on in Batman's career as a crime fighter. Characters remark with surprise treating the protagonist as a myth and Batman himself comes across as more inexperienced and arrogant. It feels more in-line with the Nolan movies in this regard and it's a welcome change from the previous two games which felt like extensions of the Batman Animated series.

However, Arkham Origins isn't as polished as Asylum, nor does it have the steller presentation of City. It's clear the developers were working with a limited budget and time constraints, and that they weren't interested in innovating on the previous games like Rocksteady was. I still do like Origins but I think of it more of a spinoff to the previous two games rather than a sequel. If you treat it like that you'll probably enjoy it a lot more.

reviewText:
Let's start off by stating this game doesn't succeed Arkham City in the way I hoped. It does however entertain for what it's worth. The game is set 5 years before Arkham Asylum, where you play a less refined and experienced Batman. Black Mask places a bounty on your head which 8 of the world's greatest assassins heed the call to. The Gotham City Police Department aren't fond of Batman, and the tactical team, lead by Branden, attempt to take Batman down themselves to earn the bounty. At this point James Gordon isn't the commissioner yet, as he is the Captain, and he and Detective Harvey Bullock are trying to take down the Batman.

I thoroughly enjoyed this game. I was never too fond of Arkham Asylum, giving it an average rating, however I loved Arkham City, and it remains to be one of the very fews games I've ever given a 10/10 for. Regardless of whatever issues that game had, I enjoyed it far too much to deny it of that rating. Sadly to say Arkham Origins didn't entertain me as much as Arkham City did, but it did (in my opinion) stay true to the franchise. I would've loved to see Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy reprise their roles as Joker and Batman, however I enjoyed the new voice actors as they really did sound like the characters they were portraying. That being Troy Baker as Joker, and Roger Craig Smith as Batman.

One disappointing factor about this game is that you don't see much of the assassins, when that was one of the high points of this game, you only fight each assassin once, and in the Electrocutioner's case, it is a very short battle, where he literally falls and faints if you punch him ONCE, then Batman insults him and leaves the battleground. Deadshot, and Lady Shiva aren't even in the main story and are only in side missions (one series each). The only assassins whose true potentials was met were Bane, and Firefly. Both of their objectives as far as Batman goes, made sense, their character's dialogue seemed to be on par with their characters in the comics, and previous games, and their Screen time" was more than suffice.
