reviewText:
This game annoys me for many reasons. Mainly it is down to consistency.

They managed to screw up the brilliant combat system. While it is still fun, it is inferior to the previous two games. Sometimes you can free flow to an opponent, sometimes you'll punch the air and sometimes you'll favour hitting a guy already on the floor instead of the one who is standing next to him. The upshot is that you will lose your combo and this is annoying. You also have to be careful with quickfire gadgets, you can fire a batclaw at the only standing enemy and before you're finished slamming him another guy can stand up slide to you and break your combo with no chance of countering him. Same goes for any move which takes longer than a single beat (cape stun, mine laying etc). I like the idea that you have to be careful when to use these multi beat moves but the lack of consistency and apparent psychic/superhuman powers of your enemies means that it is less about skill and more luck.

The linear nature of this game is very obvious. There will be doors which look like other doors you can use but which are nothing other than scenery, no interaction, no trying to budge a blocked door or funny little animations of henchmen surprised that Batman is knocking on their door. The line launcher only works on rare and obvious anchor points. The grappler will sometimes let you grapple, but sometimes you will just hit the side of the building you're trying to glide to.
There seems to be one way to approach situations and any other idea you may have will be blocked by scenery (Batman is defeated by a single strand of police tape.. don't tell Joker), bad grapple mechanics or doors which mysteriously lock themselves after you've walked through them. I think it's a cheek to call this an open world game. The ability to hang from a ledge you are perched on has been removed, one can only assume because the developers were drunk or suffered head injuries.

The Deathstroke fight was little more than a button mashing interactive movie, ensuring you get to see all the animations the devs have made for you. Speaking of animations, a great improvement on AA by AC was the death animations. You know, where the bad guy would taunt Batman as he lay dying. They're great, but you don't want to be forced to watch them 20 times while you learn how to beat whatever stage you're on. Arkham City allowed you to skip these and get back to the game, Arkham Origins has gone back to the philosophy of Arkham Asylum (i.e. watch this animation, then wait for a reload).

The new detective mode is nice except it also suffers the linearity problems. You'll need to scan various aspects of the scene to build up a picture of what happened but you can't progress to the next peice of evidence until Batman has finished musing to himself about the previous one and forcing you, again, to watch animations.

I was going to finish this one before starting Arkham Knight but I think I'll skip it for now, though I will probably return to it when I want some more Batman. All in all, I wont recommend the game because the problems are too numerous. It isn't terrible overall, but it does leave a sour taste. If the other games didn't exist, I probably wouldn't mind so much. Get it on sale or something.

reviewText:
With the release of Batman: Arkham Knight in about 3 weeks I figured I'd remake my review of Origins considering it's been 2 years since its release. And also because it's due time for an updated one.

Story
This story takes place after 2-3 years of Batman donning his cape and cowl. 8 assassins are tasked with finding and killing you for 50 million placed by Black Mask. Killer Croc, Firefly, Shiva, Bane, Deadshot, Copperhead, Electrocutioner and Deathstroke are all out to kill you. Or so it seems. The twists are done well....however most people are not happy to see Joker take the spotlight once again. You need to remember that the title is called 'Origins' for a reason. It's exploring how Batman first meets some of his greatest enemies/foes. Naturally, you'll think of a couple being left out. Where's Two Face and Poison Ivy? What about Scarecrow? They didn't come into being until later. Overall, I think the story was well enough thought out and I don't get sick of it.

Gameplay
I won't sugar coat it. The gameplay is the clunkiest of the Arkham series. Batman will sometimes lose the freeflow due to hitting air regardless of being near enemies, hits are slower and counters don't always register. There are a couple new gadgets Batman obtains and uses and they add more fun to predator areas. The addition of shock gloves makes Batman much more powerful. Too powerful in fact. Once activated, you ignore any special goons and just hit right through anything. It does double damage as well. It's fun, but makes things too easy at times. I really like the martial artists. They definitely provide more of a challenge forcing you to counter as much as you hit. The new detective system is fun to use as well to solve crimes. I've heard some encounter game breaking bugs still, however I haven't had these problems. But WB Montreal did rush this so it doesn't surprise me all too much.

Graphics
Better than AC, but not by much. They added some fog effects and smart snow to add to the depth and I found it pretty cool and impressive. But that's about it. Graphics are nothing special.

Multiplayer
This was an absolute wreck at first. Many bugs and it worked literally 1/4th of the time due to never-ending loading screens. You have 3 teams. The Bane gang, Joker gang and Heroes. The two gangs war it out trying to take and protect key points on the map while Batman and Robin try to stop it all by taking either gangs members down and filling a fear meter. The match ends if one gang loses all lives, all points are held for a certain time or Batman and Robin fill their fear meter. Joker and Bane are playable of course. Bane is overpowered though. Able to absorb what seems like 10 full magazines and is equipped with a rocket launcher on top of it. Joker uses his handy pistol and will kill you in one shot if hit. It isn't perfect, but it's definitely enjoyable.

Overall
Origins is worth the purchase. Both singleplayer and multiplayer are done well. And this will retain some value because of the multiplayer portion. While it can be clunky at times, you can easily overlook it and enjoy every moment. My only complaints are the clunkiness and how empty the map can feel compared to City. Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is an intelligently developed game. Warner Bros Montreal knew it had a great core to work with and focused to improve the weakest points, with great success. This is no cash-in, but rather a full-fledged adventure that helps shed light on the first steps of Batman as the Dark Knight, while providing many hours of fun between a compelling main mission and the secondary activities.

Of course, if you weren't a fan of the games created by Rocksteady, chances are this one won't win you over. Still, it's a great start for a brand new development studio and a promising sign for the future of the franchise.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is a prequel to the Arkham Asylum and Arkham City games. The story takes place in a pre-Arkham Gotham city, staring a young and inexperienced Batman. The police force of Gotham is corrupt and mostly not better than the mobsters and criminals that run Gotham. The game takes place on Christmas eve, where Black Mask has hired 8 of the worlds greatest assassins to kill Batman.
The gameplay is smooth most of the time as it was in the previous Arkham games. Moving around is easier than ever with the new fast travel. The city is about the same size as Arkham City but is divided between old and new Gotham.
The combat system from the previous games returns. It is all based around timing and the rhythm of the fight. The stealth is a lot like Arkham City. You have the same structure of the last two games. New type of enemies and gadgets are introduced to add new elements to the game. There is a new addition to the detective mode. There are parts of the game where you use it to analyze a crime scene and piece together the crime. It is no longer just find something to trace and follow it to from point A to B.
The boss fights are improved and feel more serious but are repetitive. The story felt weaker compared to the other games. The main story could also last longer. There are also again side missions, again you have to collect the Riddler trophies. The challenge mode also returns in Arkham Origins.
Arkham Origins comes with a multiplayer mode. In my opinion it was not really necessary to implement a multiplayer.
Batman: Arkham Origins does enhance the visuals of the Arkham City engine and it is a very great looking game on max settings. The visuals are not a massive step above the already great looking previous game.
There is not much music to listen to but the overall theme sounds nice and fits with the whole story. All the characters do sound great. You have plenty of younger versions of characters seen in previous games. The new voice of the Joker sounds really a lot like the Mark Hamil voice.
Overall, this game is fun. I enjoyed it almost as much as the other two games.

Sounds 10/10
Graphics 10/10
Gameplay 8/10
Atmosphere 8/10

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

reviewText:
Difficulty: Just Right
The Bottom Line: Ambitious/Great
Score: 8.5

Being the huge Batman fan that I am, I still knew that at some point I was going to try it out. And that I did on Halloween night. Ten hours later, my opinions on the game have changed drastically. This is the largest, most complete, most refined Arkham to date. Every single aspect of the game has been tuned to the point where it has reached its full potential.

It is true that regarding game play, this is Arkham City on a larger scale, with a larger map and plenty more skills, animations, gadgets and so on. But the story in Origins is fantastic and stands out as the best in the trilogy. Every major enemy is introduced with flair, and the fights are spectacular. The Deathstroke battle (which has caused many a lot of trouble, but I thoroughly enjoyed) in particular, was epically designed. The martial artistry displayed in this scene is jaw dropping. I cannot think of a more awesome and cinematic showdown in a comic book-inspired video game.

I must say I do find a major setback with regards to a particular decision in the art direction, and that is Batman´s character design. It makes no sense at all. An excessively armored Batman on his second professional year cannot be justified on any grounds, and the countless amount of gadgets, from the get go, at times removed me from the context the story so passionately tries to portray.

The atmosphere is thick with immersion and somehow darker as well. I feel this visual interpretation more akin to the Batman world I know and grew up with. Similar to what Tim Burton did on his second Bats movie.

So to wrap things up, yes, Origins is very similar to Arkham City. Yet after spending some time with it, I´ve come to the conclusion that the Arkham formula is too much of a winning one, and polishing it rather than messing with it was perhaps, the safest and truest (to the franchise) course of action WB could have taken. Batman Arkham Origins´ biggest hurdle is its legacy, and the uncontrollable human tendency to compare.

As a gamer and Batman fan, I have given the game a chance and wholeheartedly recommend Arkham Origins. A truly memorable experience if measured on its own grounds.

Overall: I can only wish this was the first installment. Arkham City was pretty much a perfect game but it doesn't preclude Origins from being a great game.

Note: Don't skip the credits scene.

reviewText:
Who says a prequels can't be nearly  as good as the original..  Compared to Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, Arkham Origins doesn't skip a beat. great combat, awesome exploration and featuring an all new multiplayer option if you're into that kind of thing..  The story introduces us to The Batman and his humble beginings, trusted by no one but his trusty butler Alfred Batman is tasked with a mission to stop assassins hired by Black Mask to kill him.

The downsides, the joker isn't voiced by Mark Hamill any longer, which in my opinion is a bad thing, Hamill had that perfect voice for the joker which is totally missing from this game.  Another downside seems to be loads of bugs.. I haven't personally experienced any of these bugs but the forums are filled with people having all sorts of audio and video bugs... may be worth checking these out before you make the purchase.

With the few downsides this game has I would totally still recommend this game for any comic book aficionado's, fans of beat em up's and people who enjoy donning their  Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles sheet around their neck and pretending to be a super hero..   Come on we've all done it, and we'll all love this game...  buy it now....

reviewText:
Arkham Origins is a very good game, I don't understand the hate for it, maybe it was a buggy mess at launch, I ran across few bugs myself, like the cape fluttering a few times, but nothing game breaking , the story was good not excellent, and game-play was like Arkham City with minor changes and some new gadgets. Combat was fantastic and using many gadgets during a big fight makes it even more fun.

The story takes place five years before the events of Arkham  Asylum , and batman haven't yet met the joker , and this game is mainly based on their first meeting, which was interesting and there were many villains , most of them were Assassins who were after the bounty of 50 million put on batman's head by Black Mask Joker actually .
And this game has some of the coolest boss fights among the entire Arkham series, like the Deathstroke fight was awesome, I mean it was not much of a challenge but felt like a cinematic experience with a lot of QTEs, and other great boss fights include the Bane and firefly, others were just OK!

Didn't play much of the multiplayer, my experience was mediocre at best and as many have said before, it felt unnecessary  but it would have been great if more effort was put into it.

I recommend everyone to try it once  ,it  wont disappoint you and its totally worth it.
I would like to give it a 8.5/10.

reviewText:
I was one of those people that loved Asylum, but didn't care much for City. As a whole it felt very unfocused to me, with too many villains popping up that didn't get enough development. As a result, I didn't expect much from Origins, since WB Montreal was making a game in the same vein. My reaction after finishing it though, is very much the opposite. I loved Origins from start to finish. The story has more focus, and is centered around a few central characters. It's a nice 'Year Two' type story, with Batman learning that oppossing Gordon maybe isn't the smartest idea. The finale was a blast to play and there were some purely fan service moments that were still handled really well.

I still miss the more metroidvania approach from Asylum, but Origins deals with the open world type gameplay better than City itself.

Also, it has the Deathstroke battle, which is definitely one of the finest moments in the series.

reviewText:
This review is based on the current condition of the game and therefore my opinion may be a lot more positive than it would have been on the release day.

My favourate Batman game out of the first 3 Arkham titles
Origins took everything good about Arkham City and just improved on it.
The story, while simple, is a lot more entertaining than in Arkham City. This is an origin story. Batman is still just a rumor. You're not a known figure or a hero and so even the cops are after you.
This made the game feel fresh and unique. You're a hero" going after criminals but at the same time you have to avoid cops or even fight them.
Not only is this an origin story for the Batman but you also get to know all your favourate villains a bit better.
You get to see how Harley and Joker met and all that kind of stuff.

What is the story tho? It's simple: It's about Alfred trying to have a peaceful christmas meal.
Khm! A villain put a bounty on Batman. You're basically going around Gotham fighting bounty hunters and trying to capture the person who placed the bounty on you. There is a little twist in the story but that's pretty much it.
It took me 14h to finish the story. I did stick around to solve some cases and take down last of the remaining Enigma servers but I did not go for 100% completion. I assume it would take around 20h to do everything.

Gameplay is pretty much the same as in the previous two Arkham titles altho i have to say that the combat does feel a lot more faster and smoother in here. You can upgrade and unlock new gadgets as you progress in the game. Those same gadgets let you access different parts of the map or help you get to a shiny precious collectible.
If you've played any of the Batman games you know what to expect from the combat/gameplay.

Graphically the game is superiour to the previous Arkham games and it is still good to look at even in 2016. The voice acting is supreme. The gameplay is fun and the story is decent enough to keep you hooked until the ending.
I'd say the game is worth the full price.

- I did experience one crash and about 2-3 graphical glitches during my playthrough.
I understand it had a rocky launch but the game seems to be fixed by now and you have to work really hard to come across a bug."

This game is a nice chapter in the Arkham series. The gameplay runs smoothly and the graphics are great.

A must have for every Batman fan, though the story is not as good as in previous games.

reviewText:
When developing a prequel, make sure the game doesn't take place before the QA team has tested it.  The developers of Batman: AO apparently had one goal: If it isn't broken, fiddle with it until it is.  They took Batman: AC, and managed to break every single aspect of the game in some way or another.  The bugs are innumerable and the developers publicly stated that they would not be fixing any so they would have more time to work on the DLC.  Seriously?

Where to start...Batman occasionally glitches out while gliding in the air like he's bouncing off a platform and actually gains elevation while doing so.  I've gotten stuck on ledges, in objects, and been teleported to my destination when stuck while grappling.  Enemies will sometimes teleport to their fallen companions after being alerted in stealth rooms.  The graphics somehow received a significant downgrade despite including additional eye candy that AC doesn't have along with facial animations from 15 years ago.  It also includes new performance problems that cause the game to stutter badly when flying around the city and in certain rooms indoors.  Side quests regularly break with fights getting stalled or being unable to continue mission steps in the city.  Combat timing feels off with counters being harder to pull off than they should be, and a couple times I had enemies attack me from so far away that even though I had a counter indicator, Batman would ready a gadget rather than countering.  This is made worse by the game wildly varying the timescale during combat.  I've read about some major progression-blocking bugs as well but luckily I never ran into any.

Then come the design problems.  The map has no mouse support and the keyboard moves the cursor in very large increments making it very difficult to select specific locations (I know this won't affect many players but it's inexcusable for the map to be that hard to use with kb/m.)  The game has a lengthy tutorial laboriously explaining the basics but afterwards assumes you have already played the previous games and does not explain anything until after you've failed the first time.  The game includes way too many cutscenes and at several points in the game will drop you back into the game only to have you press one button before starting another cutscene.  Most of the bossfights are long and tedious and a few rather frustrating - none feel well-designed.  During one fight, after one of the frequent in-game cutscenes the boss recovered and hit me before the game gave me control back.  Riddler has been copy-pasted into the game as Enigma except with less personality and extremely simplistic puzzles.  The game includes less interesting characters overall and half the story feels like a rehash of AC.  The new challenge system is strictly linear and will only let you attempt one at a time and most can only be completed in story missions which makes it extremely difficult to complete in one playthrough.  Many ledges are ungrappleable for no reason other than to artificially make it more difficult to reach that location.  Oh, and it seems Batman hasn't learned how to punch through plywood yet despite having more gear than AC and acting like The Hulk the whole game.

The only good thing I found in the game is that you unlock certain gadgets and abilities through side missions, rather than all through the story.  The new martial arts master enemies are pretty interesting as well, though they can make fights a bit unpredictable due to the variable way they react to attacks and counters.

So in summary, they took AC, made every part of the game worse, added a big pile of bugs, and released AO.  Play AA and AC instead or wait for AK.  Save your sanity, I already lost mine.

reviewText: Batman Arkham Origins...what can I say? Nobody wanted this game when it was announced that original developers Rocksteady were not behind the helm, myself included, but after seeing it on sale I just had to suck up the misgivings and give it a whirl. As it turns out I was extremely pleasantly surprised. This game gives you more access to Batman's iconic arsenal and carte blanche to use it not only on the City's criminals, but also the police force. Yes, that's right, as the Dark Knight of Arkham you get to use your near super human abilities to shatter the bones and bodies of every police man you see. Furthermore, you are even given a mission to infiltrate the Arkham City Police Station, and after a few grumbles from Alfred about toning back the devastating blows when fighting the police, you are then allowed to brutally incapacitate every on duty officer inside the station. The sheer amount of officers you are allowed to perform the ingame takedowns" and "freeflow combat combos" on absolutely blows away the miserly amount of cops you could attack in the previous games (note to Rocksteady
date: the mind controlled security guards in City and Asylum did not satisfy. The fans want to punch REAL cops who are fighting back on their own terms). Overall I'd say this game is one of the best Cop Smashing Games on the market and is a must have for any fans of beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of cops."

reviewText: I can't in good conscience recommend this as a game for PC. As a console game, it would present an enjoyable playthrough. As a PC game, it is clearly a console port - both the game play and graphics are not of the standard I would expect for a quality PC game. Holding multiple buttons to trigger various combos and being unable to separate my run and jump keys (they are both default spacebar) are simple gripes.\n\nHaving said that, it's not a bad game, and if you are a die hard fan and haven't played Arkham Assylum, then by all means give it a go. I just found the game play far too linear, the storyline predictable, and the gameplay underwhelming. I can't bring myself to finish a single playthrough.

reviewText:
I sit on the edge of a building looking down on some criminals on Christmas Eve trying to learn the whereabouts of the Black Mask. These guys don’t have much of a lead but they are up to no good so first I need to drop down and do a little training on a few faces.

Origins is the third game from the new Batman series but takes place before the last two. You are basically in the early years of being the bat. You’ll get to see some of the first encounters with some classic villains from the Batman stories we all love. Black Mask has put a $50 million bounty on Batman’s head and you now get the fun and excitement of dealing with all the villains who want that money. Not all is what it seems as you are soon to find out after a little progression and discovery.

The games graphics look about the same as AA & AC. Which is a good thing because I love the looks of the characters and environment. I did notice the lip syncing to be off sometimes but no problems there. Voices were all great like usual and I love the music specially the darker tone Christmas stuff.

Gameplay is what you expect from the last two games. Use your predator skills for silent takedowns which is always fun. Gadgets galore to use at your disposal. Like the new glue grenades to immobilize an attacker for a short time, or a gun which shoots a wire across to anchor points to be used as a zip line or tight rope. You can also use it to hook criminals to objects or each other.  Many fun times with that one. Other gadgets are your typical batarangs, grappling hook, explosive gel, and some others from the previous games.

There’s plenty to do in Gotham this time around with some side stories like Anarky, Deadshot and a few others. Small crimes you can solve which is now done with a cool feature were you can see a reenactment of the crime to discover what happen. A pretty cool feature and should be expanded on later down the line. Then there are the Riddler challenges again, which are just small packages you find throughout the city. Not as cool as the Riddler challenges from the previous game but it does give a little change.

Now the combat is what Rocksteady had perfected in the last two games and really made it exciting and fun to get into fist fights with your enemies. It was so fluid and fast and just beautiful to pull off some amazing moves. I’m not sure what happen but WB Montreal seem to screw up the system. Counters don’t seem to work many times and the fighting just did not feel as balanced as usual. It was disappointing and aggravating at times but I still had a blast playing.

Batman: Arkham Origins is a wonderful game to play and a great addition to the Batman franchise even despite its small flaws and some bugs I encountered. Like the red screen bug you get when entering the GCPD. Your screen turns red when you enter the rooftop door and then your PC restarts after like 10 seconds. An easy fix as you just have to put the game into windowed mode before entering and you can then go back full screen after that. Just be careful though because one downfall I got was after I beat the game and was almost finished with all side missions I forgot about this bug and got the red screen. When I restarted everything up again I had lost the last 7 hours of gameplay and all my completion stats. Luckily for me I had finished the game before this happened.

If the little issues don’t scare you away then pick this up and enjoy the great Batman story and fun.

Bear Rating: 7.5/10

reviewText:
Take everything I say with a grain of salt, since I received this game for free (came with my graphics card).

It is a broken game. The mechanics are ~simple~ yet there are moments where you will die, and there isn't much you can do about it. I know that sounds lame, but even with a ton of practice, there isn't much to gain.

The consistent crashes don't help. I have a fairly new high end rig, and this game crashes every 30-45 minutes or so, which is unacceptable. Hopefully some patches are released at some point.

Considering what I've written, I can't logically recommend a game at this price with this many problems.

reviewText: Poor example of a game, I have found several gliches that make it unwinable in spots, like suspects not presenting a prompt to be interogated, interogations not being logged/recognized by the game, and Interogation targets despawning before they can be interacted with. I don't play for challange usually, and I like having my open world games to have a sense of closure, which this lacks for me at the moment, also I find the abbrupt inclusion of several enimies attacking silmultaniously with unblockable attacks to be a poor choice for a harder difficulty, by far the brawls in the harder modes are near impossible without the shock gloves which unlock about mid story, making the starting portions increadably hard when faced with several kinife and shield weilding, armored and blocking foes. reviewText: I wouldn't believe the reviews that said this game was mediocre, so I bought it. I'm sorry to report that most reviews were pretty accurate. This game does a diservice to the franchise and to the oustanding job Rocksteady did in the previous installments. Somehow, the new developer managed to screw up the most important aspect of an Arkham game: The flow of movement and combat with unresponsive controls, forced camera perspectives and limited grappling points. The main story is boring and so are the side missions. Most of the technical problems reported were fixed by the developer, but there are a few kinks here and there (that weren't in the last two games).

reviewText:
I Am the NightTake on the Batman's established experience after and during the Year One story arc (since the game is inspired by it, not a direct page-to-screen copy of it). You get a shining moment in the early night outings as the Batman, with his Rogues Gallery to-be and some new rudimentary Bat-gadgets. The story is an endearing one when understanding why Batman kept his promise. Alfred Pennyworth has to be the best highlight of the evening though. Talk to him, you won't regret it!

Once again, all his flush and paned out as with all the Batman games in the series. Villains' personalities are thoroughly engrossing, but especially Joker's (check out The Killing Joke, you'll see). Don't forget the Cold, Cold Heart and Initiation DLC, both of which further develop the Batman villains and origins respectfully. Among all this comes an interesting multiplayer where you can play as Batman or Robin, Bane's gang and Joker's gang (Bane and Joker included)!

Batman Arkham Origins is a thorough origin story of its own merit, one with first appearances and references to villains you'll enjoy. For the most precise penning, I direct you to the comics. Though this game should not be evaded for its accuracy to those comics. Besides, it's Batman!
voteText: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is great!

I have played both previous versions and enjoy everyone of them.  Arkham Origins is far bigger than its predecessors, and plays pretty much the same.  I found the story mode a lot better than Arkham City, and a lot longer than Arkham Asylum. The mission path is easier to fulfill and i never really strayed.   Completing the game was easier to do than leaving untouched missions as i did in City.  However one thing that got on my nerves was the combat sequence.  The mechanics are great, but begun to get repetitive and became quite a chore.   Even so the rest of the gameplay was great and collecting all the collectables seems to be a lot better to seek out than Arkham City.   One new feature that wasn't in the previous installments is the crime scene investigations.  This feature is great, and like the whole sequences it plays out.  Unfortunately there wasn't many of them to do, more of these and less combat would of been great.

I have given the challenges a go but find this crazy repetitive when going from one challenge to another.  Nothing really keeps me wanting more in this mode.  Just get more frustrated when you miss the counter and the combo counter resets, gggrrrrrr!

Anyhow i recommend anybody who has played Batman Arkham City or Asylum to give this a go, its got all the goodness from previous installments and graphically is really good.

7.5/10

reviewText:
If you're a fan of the Batman video games, you will still enjoy this. It's not really a bad game, it just has a bunch of bugs and issues, and I'd like to say there are less than there were on release day, but I think I've actually encountered more on my 2nd playthrough which was just recently.

The story in this game isn't bad, and actually a few times it has great writing and dialogue. Other times, it really doesn't seem right, it's sort of a mixed bag, in my opinion. Some of it didn't feel right to me, but overall it was decent. Out of the 3 Batman games out right now, this was my least favorite, but that doesn't mean it's a bad game.

The whole 8 assassins part is what was misleading about this game. You would expect to fight all 8 in the campaign, which isn't the case. Some are side missions, and even as side missions, they're very short and unsatisfying. This could have been much better, much better indeed.

I could probably say a few more things, but overall, you get the idea at this point. If you enjoy Batman, pick this up, though I'd recommend waiting for a sale. If you're new to the series, definitely start with Arkham Asylum, followed by Arkham City, and save this one for last.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's not good enough to be considered a Batman Arkham game. Buggy, short and poorly designed.

The story is good and the locations are great (albeit Gotham City doesn't have any pedestrians because of a convenient blizzard storm, and most of what's playable of it is what will become Arkham City in the future).

I've experienced tons of bugs, something that never happened to me in the other Arkham games. For example, one time an entire Crime In Progress scene spawned right in front of me and I got locked inside the model of a truck which spawned on me. Another time I got killed by a bug in the first Bane fight, repeatedly. It took me more than three hours to beat that and I had to let Bane punch me because if I tried to avoid his hits I would get crushed by the floor for some reason, getting bugged inside the floor. Another time I used the Bat Wing to fast travel and my model didn't appear so I had to restart the game.

Fighting sucks because of the camera angle, it's very very difficult to aim when blocking or when jumping from one thug to another because the camera twists too fast (and there's no control to turn it off since the only one there is just changes what it does with the camera when you jump out of combat).

The animations are clumsy and laggy, but the game itself runs smoothly, so I wonder what happened there?

Some of the boss fights are uninspired repetitions of other boss fights from the other games and some even copy some of this very game.

I still recommend it because overall it's still a Batman Arkham game but it's way worse than the others. Buy it on sale and keep in mind Splash Damage hasn't fixed anything yet even though it's been months.

A shame really.

reviewText: *This is my opinion, and in my honest opinion, I thought this game is trash* (NO SPOILERS)\n\nMy honest opinion: I thought this game was just a complete waste of my time. Instead of Rock Steady, we get a new set of developers and we get this mess of a game. The game had a horrible launch, and the developers only had plans to fix glitches that blocked you from progressing through the game, but they left other bugs and glitches in the game and even announced that they do not have any plans to fix them, which is screwing over the consumer. The game is completely boring, with laughably easy boss fights, uninteresting characters, forced villans, and boring gameplay. What the game manage to do well is, improved combat and a good narrative (But the narrative is not as good as its predecessors.) Also there is no Mark Hamill, instead we get Troy Baker as the Joker (To make the Joker sound younger) And as good as a voice actor Troy Baker is, Troy Baker did not deliver a very good Joker (In my opinion.) Riddler puzzles are way too easy to solve compared to Arkham City and Asylum, the Riddler puzzles in Arkham origins usually take less than 2 minutes to solve rather than you considering using a walk-through since they're so hard to solve. The game is overly repetitive, with nothing new from the previous Batman games. Only a couple new gadgets, and they ''Re-named'' a few. Most of the villains are only used for 30-60 minutes in the game. This was a problem that Arkham City had except this game was worse. We get about 10 villains, and they only make very small/short appearances. The side missions are completely boring as well, and don't tell much of a story as Arkham City did. The game is way too short (Only took 8-9 hours to beat, while taking my time) And the game is way too easy. I never got stuck on the game once, and only died about 3-5 times. I even think it's a hard game to recommend on sale, but a lot of people are saying the game is quite fun, so you are probably going to have to try the game out for your self.

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, Arkham Origins is not a bad game. It was just a disappointment to me and I consider it to be not worth what it costs at the moment.
________________________________________________

I really really really don't know how to feel about Batman Arkham Origins. First of all I was stoked when I heard about it and preordered it as soon as possible. When I got it I locked myself in my room for the entire weekend and played. That at least was my plan, until a couple of bugs appeared that made it impossible to continue playing.

But by now I've finished it thankfully they quickly came up with patches for the PC version and storywise it was a great game. Unfortunately the story couldn't unfold it's entre potential because the game-play just straight away sucked. Batman no longer moves as fluidly, which is especially annoying when having to deal with larger groups of enemies. The freeflow everyone loved in Arkham Asylum and Arkham City has become no more than a painful itch between your buttcheeks. And do I even have to mention the Electrocutioner?
Furthermore it felt A LOT like Arkham City. Even the sidemissions were the same. All they really did was to exchange the graphics so it would at least look slightly different

This game held so many great possibilities, but it's rather poorly made, and I kinda regret having paid 45€ for it. Anyways, playing it was fun, there's a lot about it fans of the franchise will love.

reviewText:
Batman has a long history of escaping from some of the deadliest, most elaborate traps a brilliant criminal mind can devise. In his bat-utility belt is a gadget to get him out of nearly any predicament. But in Batman: Arkham Origins, there's one trap Batman can't escape from: the trap of expectations. By now, there are two things that define action in the Arkham series: rhythmic, free-flow combat and stealthy predator rooms. Arkham Origins has those elements in spades. But it doles them out in a straightforward, predictable fashion that lacks the inspiration of the earlier Arkham games.

The most noteworthy difference between Arkham Origins and its predecessors is a significantly larger open world. But that larger world has little meaning when the things you're doing in it are the same things the smaller world of the previous game accommodated perfectly well. Grappling up to rooftops and gliding through the air still feel great, but they don't feel any better here just because you have more rooftops to leap from. And there are side quests that have you doing things like racing to and fro to disarm bombs set by Anarky, which is much like racing to answer Zsasz's ringing phones in Arkham City.

The city is bigger just for the sake of being bigger, and while these side quests make interesting use of characters--Anarky's willingness to go to any length to liberate the downtrodden from the oppression of the rich and powerful makes him a fascinating figure, for instance, and the game gives him his due--the things you're doing are exactly the same as the things the previous game had you doing in its open world. Even the crimes in progress, events you can choose to respond to or ignore that come up on the police radio, aren't a chance to protect hapless citizens of Gotham from criminal elements, but just to fight more groups of thugs, something you do plenty of anyway.

Free-flow combat is unchanged from earlier Arkham games, aside from the fact that there are a few new enemy types in the mix, most notably a martial artist who has an attack you need to counter twice rather than once. The animations are still excellent, and getting into a rhythm where you're dishing out punishment while perfectly countering every enemy attack still feels good, but it also feels exactly the same as ever. At a certain point in the game, you acquire shock gloves that make your punches more powerful, but this doesn't prevent punching dudes in the face from feeling routine.

Predator rooms are also what you'd expect them to be, no less and no more. Of course it's still satisfying to sneak up on a goon and take him down silently, or to be perched on a gargoyle, waiting for a clueless criminal to walk right under you so you can do an inverted takedown. But it's also starting to feel rote. By this point, the mechanics governing these systems have become apparent, the process of sneaking up on enemies or of countering attacks overly familiar. You and Batman and the game he's in are all just going through the motions.

8/10

reviewText:
If you were a fan of the previous two games (Arkham Asylum/Arkham City) then this is a fitting exploration into a prequel of those two titles. The gameplay and mechanics will be very familiar and picked up easily (and the AR gliding tests are much simpler!).

If you haven't played the previous two titles, you can still proceed with this and only miss a few of the nods to the earlier releases. Being a prequel it obviously occurs before the events of Arkham Asylum. I personally recommend playing the games in release order due to the tighter controls and graphics each new title brings.

There are only a few bugs and glitches still present this long after release. I had to restart the game on multiple occasions to clear up various glitches (ie stuck game/mission progression). Apparenly WB do not see these as fairly substaintial problems, since they are still present even after most were reported around release back in 2013. So some mild frustration is to be expected.

Overall this is an excellent step up in the series with some fresh(ish) ideas to reboot the franchise.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins

I've decided to wait, and review Batman: Arkham Origins now, rather than had reviewed it back when it was released in October, last year. Why? Because the hype. I was so excited for this game to come out. I had changed every digital wallpaper I owned to it. Bought posters, digitally made a shirt, hell, the release date was even my phone's passcode. I thought it wise to just wait, and review it when my excitement had died down.

And here we are, 5 months later, and I still love this game. Sure, it has it's flooks. But what game doesn't? The gameplay is what you EXPECT, and that's okay! What the Arkham series provides is an unreal superhero experience that makes you feel like YOU are Batman. Arkham Origins still captures that and displays it in a different style and showing of the character. Arkham Origins somewhat takes the old gothic art style of Asylum and City, and sort of hides it away. You know it's there, but it's smothered underneath all the gritty realism. A harsh mix between the Nolan films and Batman: The Animated Series. The art style is also accented by the crisp visuals. and particularly to the PC version, the PhysX. (I love you Pepe) The graphics are unique, and not overly realistic, but at the same time, have that crisp Arkham feel. It knows what it is, and it tries to maintain it. The story is absolutely FANTASTIC, and is really what carries the game... Seriously... Batman fan, or non-Batman fan, you will like the story, ESPECIALLY if you have played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City.

I guess the main gripe most people had with Origins was that it was more of the same." But I have to ask
date: is that a bad thing? We got a new art style
hoursPlayed: gadgets
voteText: refined predator mechanics and new abilities
helpfulPercent: a expansion to Gotham
votesHelpful: and new playable characters. To me
votesTotal:
Arkham Origins is a solid installment to the Arkham series.

Gameplay 9/10
Visuals 8/10
Story 10/10
Replay factor 7/10

Overall: 8.5/10"

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins

I've decided to wait, and review Batman: Arkham Origins now, rather than had reviewed it back when it was released in October, last year. Why? Because the hype. I was so excited for this game to come out. I had changed every digital wallpaper I owned to it. Bought posters, digitally made a shirt, hell, the release date was even my phone's passcode. I thought it wise to just wait, and review it when my excitement had died down.

And here we are, 5 months later, and I still love this game. Sure, it has it's flooks. But what game doesn't? The gameplay is what you EXPECT, and that's okay! What the Arkham series provides is an unreal superhero experience that makes you feel like YOU are Batman. Arkham Origins still captures that and displays it in a different style and showing of the character. Arkham Origins somewhat takes the old gothic art style of Asylum and City, and sort of hides it away. You know it's there, but it's smothered underneath all the gritty realism. A harsh mix between the Nolan films and Batman: The Animated Series. The art style is also accented by the crisp visuals. and particularly to the PC version, the PhysX. (I love you Pepe) The graphics are unique, and not overly realistic, but at the same time, have that crisp Arkham feel. It knows what it is, and it tries to maintain it. The story is absolutely FANTASTIC, and is really what carries the game... Seriously... Batman fan, or non-Batman fan, you will like the story, ESPECIALLY if you have played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City.

I guess the main gripe most people had with Origins was that it was more of the same." But I have to ask
date: is that a bad thing? We got a new art style
hoursPlayed: gadgets
voteText: refined predator mechanics and new abilities
helpfulPercent: a expansion to Gotham

Arkham Origins is a solid installment to the Arkham series.

Overall: 8.5/10"

reviewText:
After playing the previous Batman series, I think that Arkham Origins is disappointing.

Lets begin with the Pros:
First of all, i should say that the story line is very good and there are some great moments too. The gameplay is brutal, fun and challenging some times. I also think that there is an improvement to Boss Fights. Regarding the Voice Acting, it's a good try by all actors (Troy Baker as Joker, Roger Craig Smith as Batman etc). Finally, the amount of side missions is Substantial.

And now let's turn to the Cons:
Glitches, Glitches ... Glitches..., did I mention GLITCHES?! The biggest problem of this game is the glitches/bugs and the technical issues because they are just so many! Apart from this, Akrham Origins is exactly a copy-paste of Arkham City. It got the same map and nothing new added (+things like gadgets, mission types etc). Also, there are not many Riddles and Challenges.

I would only recommend this game to the fans of DC Comics/Batman Series because they will like it. If this is a new experience" for you

reviewText:
Bruce Wayne no longer exists. The person he would have been died along with his parents in that dark alley. Only rage is left. He feels no sympathy. He has become unstoppable and invincible vengeance. Criminals will not get away with the pain they inflict on others. Even the smallest crime is unforgivable as they will only lead to bigger crimes. I have no fear. I am the Batman and no one will escape my wrath.

Batman: Arkham Origins is the most brutal Arkham game yet. The younger Batman does not know that he is not invincible. Familiar epic gameplay and a great dark story.

More thoughts at http://germaximus.com/batman-arkham-origins-impressions/

reviewText:
Arkham Origins is an addicting game, but that doesn't mean it's good. As someone who has put over a hundred hours into Arkham City and has 100% Arkham City and Asylum, I'm not afraid to say that Arkham Origins is an inferior follow-up. Don't get me wrong, the game is fun; the combat is better than ever with the addition of new enemy types and the ability to stack up to 2 special moves. But besides that there isn't really that much the game has going for it. The predator rooms feel uninspered and generic compared to the ones in City, and can be breezed through with the use of Deathstokes grappel gun which basicly allows you to pick off up to three enemies with no challenge to it: it's basicly a ranged Inverse takedown. This eliminates the diffliculty of predator rooms.

Then there's the city, the game's hub world. While it is larger than the one in Arkham City, if I remember correctly I've been told it's atleast 3 times as big as the one in AC, it feels empty. There isn't much to do apart from stopping the same general street crimes that pop-up in the city districts (whether it's fighting mobs or beating up gangs it all ends up becoming the same repitative task after a while). The are no riddler trophies or riddles that unlock bonuses and give winks and nods to the batman lore. I understand Edward Nigma hasn't transformed into the Riddler yet, but the replecement collectibles they have in the game just feel inferior compared to the collectibles of past games. There are side-missions you can do, but half of them are straight up copies of the ones present in AC; Instead of blowing up titan containers you're blowing up drug containers, there's the one where you get sucked into Mad Hatters Wonderland, there's the one where you have to track down Deadshot just like you did in AC.

Speaking of Deadshot, one of the biggest flaws in this game is character development. For a game whose whole premise is based around Batman having to defeat eight assassins, the assassins themselves have barely any impact in this game. Assassins like Deathstroke have little to no screen time, they just show-up, you beat them, and you about never see them again. I'm not talking about B or C list characters here, this is Deathstroke, a major player in the DC Universe, a man who has fought the Teen Titans and had multiple comic series. Instead more emphasis is placed on characters like Bane, who has already had screen time in the previous two games. For the most part it just feels like most of the assassins where just there as fan-service instead of actually having a purpose; it's like how people always joke that the Batman story-arc Hush" was just an excuse for Jim Lee to draw and include major stars of DC universe
date: with them having little to add to the overall plot.\n\nBut while there's a lot I can criticize about Origins
recommended: there are some things it gets right. Like I said earlier the combat is better than ever

reviewText:
Arkham Asylum came as a breath of fresh air in a genre combination that had left a long trail of mediocre at best games, even when coupled with some of the biggest licenses in the world. Arkham City expanded on that with an open world and a ton more things to do. Can Arkham Origins, the third game in the series, a prequel made by a different developer, keep the same high quality and still make the franchise feel fresh?

The answer is, thankfully, yes. Though Rocksteady didn't work on this entry in one of the best new franchises in years, WB Montreal has hit it out of the park and convinced me that even if Rocksteady has moved on, WBM's hands are more than capable.

The game starts out long before the events of Arkham Asylum, and you play as a Batman who's nowhere near as confident. He has no allies aside from Alfred, the criminals of Gotham City still aren't quite sure he's more than a myth or urban legend, and the police force will stop at nothing to take him down. On Christmas Eve, Batman discovers that someone has hired eight assassins to kill him, with a $50 million reward to the one who manages to take him down.
The story takes place across Christmas Eve night and a couple hours into the very early morning of Christmas, and it's wonderfully well told, which is good because the story was the most worrying thing to me, since I figured the gameplay looked nearly identical to the past two games.

The gameplay isn't just a cut and paste of the prior entries, though, with a handful of new gadgets, takedowns, and combat moves thrown in to keep things fresh. Obviously there are some gameplay continuity quirks, since why would Batman have lost some gadgets between now and then, but for the most part you'll forget about those kinds of things as you fight quite a few new enemy types, the best bosses in the series, and use your detective skills to solve crimes with some cool new crime-rewind/fast-forward stuff. It's all very fun and I have no real gameplay complaints, though those expecting radical departures from the series' formulas will be disappointed.

The non-story stuff is at its best in this entry as well, with cases to solve, criminals to catch, and an enjoyable random crime system to mix things up.

The only real downsides to AO are negligible. The multiplayer mode is both dead and somewhat pointless, though it could be fun if you could find some games and play with friends. The other issue is that the game, unlike Asylum and City, could use a couple more passes of polish. There are quite a few bugs in this entry, mostly with mission triggers not occurring or enemies becoming unable to be interrogated. Sometimes while rewinding a crime you will become stuck in the ground until it finishes,  things like that. I didn't run into any of the gamebreaking bugs some people have, but I guess your mileage may vary.

All in all I had a blast with B:AO and I look forward to what both Batman developers have up their sleeves.
9.5/10

reviewText:
Now, before all of you simply glance over my words simply because I don't recommend this game to everyone, allow me to explain in detail why that is so.

Have in mind that I have not completed this game 100%, nor do I intend to; I am not a completionist, and even if I were, this game does not deserve it. I've also played both Arkham Asylum, and Arkham City, followed by Origins, all in quick succession and in proper order, over the course of about 3 weeks. I was also (un)lucky to pre-order this game with a decent discount; it cost me about 30€ or so, a good dip from the 50€ that the game retails for.
Also have in mind that I will not be talking about the online multiplayer of this game; I feel it is an unnecessary add-on to the game that does not benefit a previously exclusively single-player experience, and a great one at that.

Now, I usually don't tend to compare different games because it takes away the focus of the game at hand, but since this is a sequel (or a prequel, to be precise); a game in a series of games, I shall compare it to its predecessors simply because it makes sense. This goes more so for the quality of the previous games, and to see if this game is up to the same standard. And unfortunately, it is not.

This game, like many other in their respective franchises, such as God of War and Assassin's Creed just to name a few, suffers from a very common AAA game problem; over-iteration. Companies become greedy due to the success of previous entries, and simply start cashing in on the loyalty of players with a passion for games like this. It should also be noted that this game, unlike Arkham Asylum and City, wasn't even made by the same studio; the first two games were made by Rocksteady, whereas Origins was made by WB Studio Montreal; meaning that the entire cast was changed.

Now, before I can state why I don't recommend this game, I'll take a look at the two previous entries in the series.

Back when I started Asylum, I expected nothing of the game. It is the only game of the three that I have not done any reading on, or have not seen any video material beforehand; I explored as I went.
A week later, having finished it, and on a side note, it is the only game of the three that I have played on the Easy difficulty (and it still remains the most difficult game in the series), I came out more than pleasantly surprised. Everything, from the game's level design, to its closed, dark, gritty, and almost paranoid atmosphere, not to mention amazing characterization, was spot on. I won't even start talking about the voice acting, which was second to none. The game felt fresh. It felt new. It felt like a really high-quality piece of work.

Afterwards, I almost immediately started Arkham City. With this one, I'd done some previous reading and watched some short videos. The game received almost universal praise, and I read reviews filled with nothing but good word of it. And given the quality of Asylum, I went into the game with high expectations.
Another week later, I finished the game, but with mixed feelings. For one, the story seemed out of place, and was kind of messy all around. Other aspects of the game received no change whatsoever; it was basically Asylum with a different story. Luckily, voice acting remained on the same quality level as with Asylum; Hamill really shined with the Joker. Lastly, the game did improve in one aspect. That was the environment. It provided me with a more or less open world, shedding the closed atmosphere of Asylum, and providing me with the constant feeling of being on the move. The design of Arkham City was great, and it was a good change from the closed corridors of the Asylum, and this required a different approach from the player.
Yet, despite all this, I still prefer Asylum. It just felt better.

Lastly, I started playing Origins. I had hopes for the game. I wanted to see it correct the things City got wrong; a more coherent story, a larger world to explore, more stuff to do.
And after a while, I saw that the game failed spectacularly at all of these. Now, since I'd harbored nice feelings for the previous games, I could look over the various issues that the game has. However, by the end of the game, I realized that this game was indeed a failure. It is a failure because it takes everything enjoyable from the previous games, and then limits it.
For starters, the level design is a step back from Asylum, let alone City. The game basically tricks you into thinking you've been given this large open world, when it fact it is more limited than the closed levels of Asylum, for most of the game. There are only a handful of ways to progress, and the game is not flexible in this aspect. Adding a quick travel feature detracts from the game's supposed exploration-based nature, and you're left to realize that, despite this game having a (slightly) larger map than City, it is barren. The entire city is almost empty, and to make things worse, this is obviously artificial, and on purpose. The game feels poor in content. It even has loading times between areas if you quick travel. It is simply pathetic.
And all of this is made worse by the fact that the game doesn't try to innovate in the slightest. It sticks to the formula of 'if it ain't broke, don't fix it', and it pays for it dearly. Nothing has changed gameplay-wise, and some things are even performed worse than in previous games. The entire system, like City, is simply copy+pasted from Asylum.
Last but not least when it comes to gameplay, the game has a multitude of bugs. From what I heard and read, I actually got off easy; I only encountered two or three game-breaking bugs over the course of my playthrough. Gameplay aside, there are even more issues with the game. And that would be the story.

SPOILER warning; mild story spoilers ahead.

Now, it might be just me, but the story of Origins feels even more out of place than City. It is cluttered, and makes no time to explain itself, while at the same time letting down my expectations. For one, I expected the Joker's presence in the game to be minimal, even more so than in City. But no. They just went and had to make him the main villain. Again. For the third damn time. Now, all of this would be ok if he was up to par. But even that doesn't occur, as the change in voice actors is visible; while I have nothing against Troy Baker, by trying to be as good as Hamill just doesn't work, and makes the game feel cheap. It is something you'll notice if you played the previous games.
Second, the game disappoints in its choice of villains; because the Joker is the main man behind the scenes, this de-values all the other villains, and makes them effectively the Joker's underlings, which is terrible. None of the other villains are given proper screen time, nor are they challenging in fights. This is evident as the game has the worst boss fights in the series. It is a step down from the outright amazing boss fights with Scarecrow and Mr. Freeze, as well as the Penguin in Asylum and City respectively.
And as far as the story goes, the name of the game is misleading. This is no origins story. It is just a half-as*** attempt to cash in on the amazing work of Rocksteady. The story does not feature the true Origins of the Batman, and provides no backstory to his motivation, like Asylum does. It just takes a great character and gives him more stuff to do.

TL;DR - If you simply have to have more of Batman, play the game. However, this game works best if you haven't played any of the previous two games. If you have, and think the series was great so far, for the love of God, don't play this game. If you were a fan of Asylum, stick to it. It is by far the best game in the series, and playing this will only make you dislike the franchise.

As a side note, this review was longer, but it seems there's a character limit, so I had to shorten it. Oh well.

reviewText: I played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City and loved them.  I absolutely could not wait for Arkham Origins to come out.  The only word I can use to describe it is.......disappointing. reviewText:
Arkham Origins exceeds on a technical level, having some really good looking character models and good looking environments. As mentioned it doesn't feel as alive as it could be, but it's not a bad looking game by any means. The soundtrack is one of the biggest rewards here. It's a really good one. About what you'd expect from an Arkham game.

The only thing that keeps Arkham Origins down is that so much of it feels like a retread of familiar territory. There's nothing here that really tries to build on the foundation of what was already established in the game before it. Arkham City did a good job of building up on what was established in Asylum despite having a lot of familiar gameplay. It feels like the developers here were playing it safe.

The good news is that Origins isn't a step back. It's just not a big step forward. It does have it where it counts, though. A strong story and a good narrative to accompany it. If you liked the previous Arkham games then Origins is worth your time.

reviewText:
Arkham Origins is the third game in the Batman Arkham series, though it is a prequel. It is obvious when playing through the game that the developer of this game is different than the previous two installments, Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. The game feels clunkier and is not as well optimized but the game still has a sort of charm that drives through, which makes it a unique, though flawed, addition to the series.

The story in this game caught me by surprise because of how honestly interesting it was. The game takes place on Christmas Eve and features the first night Batman encounters The Joker. There is a twist that happens during the beginning of the game, but do not expect anything of Arkham City caliber. The character interactions are fantastic and honestly my favorite part of the game, especially the relationship portrayed between Bruce and Alfred. To see the beginnings of many characters and their involvement with The Dark Knight is interesting as well, including Officer Gordon and Barbara Gordon. Many parts of the story actually portrays Batman as a ture detective, which is very well done and satisfying.

The voice acting in this game is pretty solid, even thought the actors Batman and The Joker have both been replaced. Troy Baker must be commended for his outstanding job as The Joker and filling in the big shoes left by the much talented Mark Hamill. A huge negative for me though is how awful the lipsyncing in real time is in this game. It looks extremely clunky, unfinished, and just plain bad, especially by 2013 video game standards. The cutscenes, on the other hand, are a big plus because they are extremely stylized and are a huge factor that sets this game apart from the previous installments in the series.

The graphics in this game are nothing special and even when they are maxed out, they do not look as good as Arkham City does. That said, it is definitely not a bad looking game (though the fire effects are absolutely atrocious). The funny thing is even though the game came out two years after Arkham City and does not look as good, it also does not run as well. I have a pretty solid PC which can run games such as Battlefield 4 on high smoothly and at a constant framerate but for this game, it manages to lag (though not frequently) at random locations throughout the game, and especially prominent during the last couple portions,

The gameplay in this game consists of what you have already been accustomed to in the series, except it just seems to be a bit clunkier. Though the flow of the combat is fluid, sometimes the takedown controls did not seem to work which got quite annoying in specific portions of the game. Also, the combat in this game is much easier than the other games because once you get a flow going, which is easy enough, you can attack enemies that are stunned and already on the ground which somewhat removes one of the only challenges in the beat-em-up combat this series did so well. There is a return of stealth portions within the game but it plays quite differently because of the very different level design compared to the previous installments. In this game, the stealth portions really just seemed easier and if you are caught sneaking around, it was also simple enough to dodge the enemies' bullets and take them down non-stealthily, which honestly should not be the case. So one of the biggest gripes about this game is the fact that it is really a lot easier than Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. There are also many new weapons introduced in this game, which does not make sense since Batman could have used them in the other installments, which take place later on the timeline. Though when making a prequel videogame, it is inevitable to run into problems like that. One of my favorite additions though is the grapple accelerator, which allows Batman to increase his speed when grappling on to any surface, which happens a lot in these games. This is one feature I definitely want to see carried over into Arkham Knight.

The map in this game is slightly bigger than that of Arkham City, though it may feel emptier because of the lack of interesting and engaging sidequests. The game takes place in Gotham this time around and it does not make a whole lot of sense since the only people we see roaming the streets or the rooftops are criminals. It made sense in Arkham City, since that is an entire area infested with criminals, but the same cannot be said about this game. One great addition though is the fast-travel using the Batwing. There are multiple fast-travel spots that can be unlocked throughout the map and this idea works very well and I hope it is implemented into Arkham Knight.

Though the game is still pretty fun, even compared to the first two installments, it is lacking something huge. A variety of Batman villains. We get some interesting bosses in this game but we also get some fairly unenjoyable ones with villains I don't really care about. Arkham City had an assortment of crazy and fun villains, but this game takes a slump in that department. Bane returns for a total of three different boss battles here and though they are fairly fun, it would have been more interesting to change up the formula. There is a boss battle with Deathstroke early in the game and it is very well executed, and one of the highlights in this game for me. One thing to note is that one of the boss battles is very annoying to play with a mouse and keyboard, so using a controller for this game may be a good idea.

Overall, Batman: Arkham Origins is a solid game muddled by being unpolished and some poor design. However, it is still a good game in my opinion and one that is worthy to be in the series. WB Montreal did a good job at portraying these characters in a new light and I really appreciate that.

7.5/10

reviewText:
Some glitches/bugs solutions - on the bottom of the review

Storyline  On Christmas Eve, Black Mask has put a bounty on Batman's head and 8 asssassins are trying to kill him - Deathstroke (veteran assasssin), Copperhead (a poisonous contortionist), Firefly (a pyromancer), Electrocutioner (a guy who uses high voltage), Shiva (a  martial artist), Deadshot (expert marksman), Killer Croc (a killer who is crocodile) and Bane (Oh, this will hurt) . And on batman's way the police is trying to capture him . I enjoyed every part of it honestly . It was interesting how you deafeat everyone of them successively .

Gameplay Batman Arkham Origins is an open world stealth game . You play as Batman as well . You have many gadgets which really makes you feel like Batman .
When you free roam you use your batclaw to attach to buildings and you can also glide in the air . You also use your other gadgets like cryptographic sequencer which hacks security consoles by guessing the password (which I find really annoying as it was in the previous games), batarang which you throw at enemies (also you can choose remote controlled batarang which you controll), explosive gel - destroying weak walls and lots more gadgets which you also get by deafiting the assassins .
When you free roam there are side missions like crime in progress where you help the police from the gangs . There are also Most Wanted missions where you do the side missions of a villian such as Anarky who plants bombs around or Enigma who has data files hidden around (also in levels) . When you stop these side missions you earn points which can be used to upgrade your gadges and etc.
The combat is great but really easy (you pretty much do the same - just pressing some buttons) . The whole game didn't have a lot new stuff from Arkham City except one - the world . Its double the size of Arkham City .
The boss fights are amazing . The first one which was Deathstroke showed me what Arkham Origins offers with its boss fights.

Issues I honestly enjoyed the game a lot, but then the holy experience of glitches began . I even made a countdown for how many glitches/bugs I found and they were 11-12 . I had a glitch/bug in almost every level . I found solutions for them in the internet (well some of them still persist) . Wb Games doesnt give a ♥♥♥♥ about the game after they realised it .There are missing data handlers, glitches while you glide, some glitches that you just fall and when you get up everything is white and you have unlimited gliding, beatdown glitches (I thought the game was on ubisoft), corrupted save files (mostly on xbox), game-breaking glitches, crashes and a lot more .

Verdict After all these issues I do recommend the game for its awesome storyline, amazing boss fights, great world and all these gadgets that makes you feel like Batman.

Issues fixes Here are some fixes which MIGHT help you.
Corrupted Save Files - Reinstall the game  .
Startup Crash - Go to BatmanArkhamOrigins > SinglePlayer > BMGames > Config and delete BmEngine
Elevator Glitch - immediately after you press SPACE (elevator button) press Z (first person view) and you shouldn't fall from the elevator
Glide bug - Press Ctrl while gliding and then space
Joker Beatdown glitch - Low your graphics and turn your wi-fi off
Missing Enigma data handler on the pioneer bridge - Restart the last checkpoint and then fast travel to the BatCave and then go back to the enigma data handler and he should be there

reviewText: If you've played the previous Batman games, it will be easy to get frustrated with Arkham Origins. The real center of these games is hand-to-hand combat with large groups of thugs. That's what you'll be spending a large portion of the game doing, and it's never been more frustrating.\n\nIn past games, you were able to cancel out of any long animation Batman might be in the middle of in order to counter an attack coming from a thug behind you. In this game, not only do your animations have priority over your commands, but enemies can slide from a good distance away right up next to you to lay a sudden smack-down on the Bat, the whole while you are helpless to defend yourself. This makes the Bat sense" warning signals above enemies' heads useless at least half of the time
date: since it will be impossible for you to counter them.\n\nThis is more or less emblematic of the problems with Arkham Origins: changes were made that make little sense and do a lot to detract from the experience. There's some fun to be had here for anyone desperate for more Batman after Arkham Asylum and Arkham City
recommended: but if you can hold out
hoursPlayed: you'd be better off waiting for Arkham Knight next year."

reviewText:
It's more of the same with more bugs.
tl;dr: I paid $30, it’s worth $10.
Now you might think more of the same would be a good thing, but sadly it's just stale.
I was all aboard the hype train for this, I had faith that WB could put together a decent game, I mean how could they mess it up?

1) It's incredibly short.  That being said I didn't run around getting all the Riddler boxes to beat him up for a third time.  But the main story is considerably shorter than that of Arkham City, and it ends sort of abruptly.  (Yes, yes you can continue playing after you finish the story to get the Riddler stuff.)

2) The writing seems half-♥♥♥♥♥.  The assassins that were hired to kill Batman, which I might add were the main marketing point for the game made up less than an hour of the game.  The concept of surviving the assassins in one night sounded appealing, the actual execution was boring and short.  It's almost the same issues the Batman films ran into all those years ago, when you have too many interesting characters there just isn't time for everyone.

3) The game is Riddled (heh, pun) with bugs.  From the buggy controls to the performance issues, all the way to that inescapable Riddler room that you actually had to fast-travel your way out of.  I played for 3/4 of this game on the highest settings with a decently high-end rig (i7, 16GB, HD 7970).  I had performance hits here and there, but as soon as I got to Blackgate the game became unplayable, and for no reason in particular.  Looking at performance monitors, my card was itting at 80% usage, my i7 was barely being touched and yet I was struggling to get 14 fps.   I had to look online for community fixes.  Though these are known issues, they have yet to be fixed.

4) Yes the map is roughly double" the size of Arkham city
date: but there were sections of the map that I barely explored because there wasn't a need.  It was big just for the sake of being big.\n\n5) While the boss-fights in the Batman series have never been anything special (with the exception of Mr. Freeze) the fights in this game are spectacularly vanilla.  I was looking forward to the Deathstroke fight
recommended: and it was over in seconds
hoursPlayed:
more of a chore than a challenge.

6) The gadgets are a joke.  The “glue grenade” is a clone of Arkham City’s “freeze grenade” with a new name but all the exact same functionality.
For some reason there is stun grenade… thing that you’ll probably forget that you have because it’s less effective than any of your other gadgets.

There is more
voteText:
but you get the idea.  With as little actual story was in this game it could have done as an expansion to Arkham City or been incorporated into whatever the next Batman game that Rocksteady is working on all hush-hush.

**I must say though that this game as a whole was disappointing the one part I was surprised by was the voice acting.  I wasn't sure of their decision to swap in new voice actors for that "younger" sound.  While neither of the main characters sounded particularly younger they did do a damn fine job of bringing the characters to life.
"
