reviewText:
IntroductionBatman: Arkham Origins is the third game in an amazing series which combines fun and proactive combat with a massive city full of secrets. If you have already played Arkham City or Asylum then you're getting more of the same, though there are many elements of the game (mainly story and characters) that are different because Origins is a prequel to the series.

Plot DetailsYou are The Batman, a highly trained combat expert with an arsenal full of gadgets at your disposal. However, Gotham City doesn't really know about you at this point in time. You go from just a rumor to a full-fledged night vigilante in the space of (what should be) a night. I find it a bit ridiculous to be honest, but hey, that's just my opinion. Basically you become 'wanted' by this guy called Black Mask who puts a pretty impressive bounty on your head and hires assassins to kill you, 10 of them in fact. At first this premise really got me interested, but I didn't feel like the story was carried as well as it could be. Nevertheless, you get to meet some of the most infamous criminals of Gotham in a younger version. It was weird seeing Penguin a little younger than usual.

All of this happens on Christmas eve by the way. As you traverse the city, you'll see a lot of snow, christmas trees and assorted lights everywhere. Let's talk more about Gotham shall we?

GameplayGotham City is pretty much the same from Arkham City. It's large with various major areas you can travel to. You can decide to grapple and glide everywhere, or you can now fast travel via the batplane. I do appreciate the choice between them both, however the Batplane travel is just a combination of three cutscenes that never vary. I prefer physically going through the city, finding cool grappling spots and just enjoying the game that way. BUt when I simply wanted to get somewhere quickly, the fast travel system helped a lot.

The problem I have with the city is that aside from enemies, it is completely empty. Remember the plot? Well it just so happens that there is a supposed curfew in effect for the entire night and so you'll never see a single regular human being anywhere. This is something I had hoped Arkham Origins would have fixed from City, but alas, we have to deal with another lifeless city. Almost any person you see is automatically an enemy because the cops aren't even on your side. The exception to this rule are the people you end up rescuing in various situations. They may thank you and leave, but otherwise they pretty much don't exist.

There are quite a few things to do in the city itself. From beating up baddies to finding collectibles, this game will eat away time like acid. Combat is quite satisfying and will involve a lot of countering, utilizing gadgets and changing your strategy to deal with various enemies. Stealth gameplay is quite fun and it's highly entertaining to listen to the voice chatter of terrified enemies. Gadgets give you so many creative ways of taking out, or immobilizing enemies, so no two encounters are ever the same.

Now, I dislike doing repetitive things, however there are two things that kept me interested in getting collectibles. Firstly, most of these collectibles are tied to some very creative puzzles. Each one kept me guessing and some of them absolutely blew my mind. However I never once had to pull up a guide to tell me how to solve any of them so most people should be able to get them all with enough time. Secondly, I enjoyed reading the new bits of information I got from each collectible I got. It put more life into the characters and was pretty worth it.

There are many other gameplay elements which are worth mentioning but it would make this review too long.

VisualsAbsolutely stunning. If your PC can max this out then that's perfect. However this game is very well optimized for even potato PCs.

AudioThere are a few new voice actors in this game and while I thought they did their roles just fine, I'd still prefer the originals. Other sounds and music are top quality stuff. Highly enjoyable.

SummaryWhile Arkham Origins is a great game in its own right, it feels like the developers missed multiple opportunities to expand the game past the original despite the plot. Arkham City felt a bit lifeless and this game would have done well with some expansion in that regard. Instead, it felt the same, if not worse in that category. However, Arkham Origins is overall more of the same from Arkham City, so if you liked that game, or you're new to the franchise, you'll love it.

Newcomers: 9/10 - Worth a buy
Previous players: 7/10 - More of the same

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText: The worst Arkham game, which still means that the game is really fun... but it feels off. The story is really cheesy and kind of silly, the gameplay is solid and well-rounded but feels a little off. The game also commits one of the cardinal sins of gaming and throws a last boss that is entirely different from the rest of the game at you. I enjoyed my time here and got some good mileage out of the game, but Arkham City and Arkham Asylum are incredible compared to this. It is worth a five to ten dollar purchase, and you'll have a good time with it, but it feels hollow compared to Asylum/City.\n\nTimeline wise, this takes place before Asylum, and tells a bit of the origin story, hence the name.

reviewText:
Origins is the newest , third, and the least strong of the Batman Arkham games. If you liked the first two you'll probably enjoy this one, though I found it tedious, and what DLC there is is tied to signing up for a WB account, which no one wants. It was worth it for a Steam sale price :)

A really difficult boss fight with Deathstroke finished off my patience for this game fairly early on, and so I haven't seen much of it. The level design (of the ship) was really quite nice and the core mechanics of Batman Arkham games are present, in minmum, but I didn't see anything new compared to Ciry or Asylum, both of which I was able to finish, eventually.

Cold Cold Heart seemed a neat DLC but I couldn't get very far in it and was already disinterested.

reviewText:
Similar Games:

The previous Arkham games, Assassin’s Creed games, and every game which has
attempted to rip either of those two series off.

The Good:

Fantastic setting for a Batman game. Gotham City on Christmas Eve just screams “Batman Returns” and is iconic in its own right.
The character design and graphics are top notch, from the major (and minor) villains to the skyscrapers of Gotham.
Character animations are fluid and natural, especially in cutscenes. Copperhead, one of the eight assassins gunning for Batman, is the real standout in this aspect.
The gameplay is a rehash of the previous Arkham games, with the now standard attack/counter/stun/gadget methodology in place. The combat has always been a strength of the series, and Arkham Origins is no different, except to make Batman’s combat seem less refined and more brutal. That they managed to convey Batman’s inexperience to crime fighting through his fighting technique alone is fantastic.
Detective mode is now more involved, requires more evidence gathering, and *GASP* actually involves Batman having Alfred send the evidence to the GCPD for prosecution! It’s almost like the real world! #SARCASM
The plot twist, while obvious to anyone who was vaguely familiar with a Batman plot past his Detective Comics days, was a welcome change of pace.
The voice acting, despite having changed actors from the previous Arkham games, was still solid and believable.
The “Red Hood” section. I won’t spoil it more than that, but as a fan of the comic series, this made me very happy.
The Bad:

This game was shipped by WB Montreal one week prior to Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag. What this means in layman’s terms was that WB Montreal had NO wiggle room in their release date, since Assassin’s Creed (also being a stealth action/combat game with an enhanced vision mode) would almost certainly have cannibalized their sales. In business terms, they had to ship before Assassin’s Creed no matter what state the game was in – AND IT SHOWS. A number of game breaking bugs were present in both the single player and multiplayer portions of the game, including:
NOTE: MINOR SPOILERS BELOW
Multiple instances where ledges that appeared to be climbable were not. One instance occurred in Burnley Tower, after the Riddler closes off the only other exit, leaving your trapped inside the Tower FOREVER… or until you fast-travel out or reset the game. If you have time and appreciate nerd rage, just Google “Burnley Tower”.
An instance where pulling a raft in a dream-like sequence lead to being unable to drop the rope or reach the other shore. Infinite falling in certain places in the map, which really broke the immersion of the game somehow. If Batman ever runs into an enemy which can actually do this, he’s screwed.
No level or stat saving in multiplayer, which is a non-starter for obvious reasons.
Funky physics. More than once, I threw a baddie against a wall at just the right angle to make him go spirally hundreds of feet into the air. But even worse, once he landed, he got back up! Which is JUST impossible.
Occasionally, you are detected by criminals from whom you have both cover and distance. Conversely, you can fly just overhead of others and go completely unnoticed.
Batman sometimes drops combos for no reason, particularly during counters.
There was a lack of emphasis on stealth for most of the game, and often going into stealth areas, Batman enters the room through the front door. Perhaps the enemies were expecting the vents, so the door was the most stealthy option?
MINOR SPOILERS: In what is probably the worst tragedy of storytelling in this series, Barbara Gordon is portrayed as an enthusiastic teenager who somehow is allowed to access confidential police files and evidence because her daddy works for the police. Brushing aside the lack of realism there, Barbara Gordan, who became Batgirl and then, after the Joker shot her in the spine, assumed the role of Oracle, was NOT the airhead from this game. I almost stopped playing for this reason alone.
The method of unlocking certain gadgets and techniques is dependent on performing certain feats. Normally that is fine, except that these feats are very specific and must be performed in the exact order that the skill tree describes. And some of these feats are nightmarishly impossible and require specific areas and circumstances to complete… just leave it at XP, WB Montreal. Come on.
The Grapnel Accelerator, described as “experimental” in Arkham City, is mysteriously present years before in Arkham Origins. I understand why they decided to include it, but it represents an obvious break in the timeline of the games.
The multiplayer… oh the multiplayer. It requires eight people to play, real people. NOT BOTS. NO BOTS. Good luck finding eight people on the servers a month from now. Make some friends on Steam, get a group together, and it might be feasible. Otherwise, it’s a waste of install space. Also, the shooting is really hit-and-miss, but that makes sense in an engine designed for hand-to-hand combat.
Can you play it while the children are awake?:

Of course not. Corpses with rictus smiles, tons of on-screen violence, multiple murder
scene investigations, psychopathic villains… I could go on. Then again, if you are looking
for a creative way to punish them…

While I’m picking nits…

Rocksteady better be working on something damned important… like freelance work on
Half-Life 3, or (dare I wish it?) a good Superman game. I know that sounds impossible,
but before Arkham Asylum, there wasn’t a good Batman game, either. I would only
recommend this game if you haven’t played Arkham Asylum or Arkham City, and thus
can’t compare the quality. Or if you have enemies, you could recommend this game on
its multiplayer strengths.

Did I make time to complete it?:

I put 26 hours into it, primarily into the single player. I know that’s incongruous with
my criticisms above, but I was a big fan on the franchise going into Arkham Origins.
This also represents the smallest amount of time I have put into an Arkham game, and
none of the others had multiplayer. I should also mention that a number of the bugs
mentioned above have been fixed… but not all.

Recommended Purchase Price:

$19.99 (so, maybe Steam Summer Sale 2014?)

or

40% of current retail value of $49.99

Reviewer:

Rod Kimble

http://www.gamerglance.com

reviewText:
As a young studio best known for porting Batman: Arkham City to Wii U, WB Montreal must have been desperate to prove that it belongs in the same conversation as series creator Rocksteady Games. To its credit, it's hard to tell that Batman: Arkham Origins isn't one of its sister studio's earlier releases. That's some achievement, but it's also a mixed blessing.

To begin with, the set-up is as economical as Arkham Asylum or Arkham City. Batman is thrust into Gotham on Christmas Eve after Black Mask puts a $50 million bounty on his head and invites eight super-villains to town to compete for the spoils. As with previous Arkham games, that simple set-up then evolves as Batman races to keep up with events.

Arkham Origins doesn't leave the strongest first impression though. After a CG cutscene and a short playable prologue in Blackgate Prison, Batman is dumped into a sparsely occupied Gotham that looks tiny on his Batcomputer map compared to some of the open-world playgrounds we've run around in lately. You're free to travel across it all from the start, but players used to maps dripping with icons may be surprised at its cold emptiness.

This isn't a game that lacks depth, though - it's just a game with rare patience. Story missions take place away from the streets in carefully knotted set-piece levels built around single locations - like Penguin's hidden casino-♥♥♥-arms-bazaar or Gotham City Police headquarters - and as you make progress the open world gradually fills up with distractions.

The initial slow burn is welcome, anyway, because it's an opportunity to luxuriate in the wonderful systems and mechanics that Arkham Origins inherits from its forebears. Batman glides through levels even when he's just walking around, those famous bat ears erect with authority, and he moves fluidly in a crouched run, too, barrel-like thighs pumping him from shadow to vent. But when you start actually gliding, it's a minor revelation, opening his wings to the wind and using the grapple to grasp the edge of a distant chimney, reeling it in and launching him over the crest to continue his flight.


Watch me play through the first level of Arkham Origins and provide an overview of some of the systems.
We had all this before, of course, but you forget how good it was. The same goes for Batman's many gadgets. You start off with quite a few - batarangs, smoke pellets and explosive gel for blowing holes in walls - and of course you have detective vision, the sonar view mode that maps Batman's surroundings so he can track enemies as they move nervously through the darkness around him. You gain other toys at intervals, including the remote batclaw for setting up tightropes between particular grapple points.

Batman remains handy in a fight, too. In hand-to-hand combat, a single attack button allows him to flow between targets, ducking and diving through dense matrices of incoming blows, repelling those that threaten to land by reaching for the counter button. It's still quick to build combos, and the final blow, which the game always puts into slow motion and frames up nicely, often has a satisfying crack to it.

The one thing Batman still lacks is a gun or grenade to deal with unsuspecting groups of enemies from afar - he can either wade in with his fists and gizmos or try to isolate and pick them off using stealth - but of course that's the point of the character. There is still a slight frustration though that the game often forces you into direct confrontation rather than letting you choose your own approach, especially as tougher enemies arrive with riot shields, knives and body armour to inject complexity into each fight.

Still, that is what Arkham Asylum and Arkham City did, so at least it's canon. As is the way the city starts to fill up with intriguing diversions. The Riddler is back, of course, custodian of unlockable fast-travel points that can only be activated when you break into them. This often involves hopping around adjacent buildings examining the exterior of your prize, like a high-tech octopus feeling around the outside of a bottle to reach the fish inside. Enigma has left his mark in other areas of Gotham, too, and you'll be on his various trails all night.

He is probably the highlight of the side missions - again, as usual - although he's far from alone in the dark night. Anarky is fed up with Gotham's corrupt rulers and plans to deal with them somewhat more explosively than Batman, so that's a thing, and there are various other threads to follow once secondary characters - friends and foes - present themselves.

2
Manoeuvring around enemies to set up stealth takedowns is still fun, although you can autopilot a lot of it with two games' experience under your utility belt.
So it's fun crawling over Gotham. It can still feel slightly empty at times - you'll never see a pedestrian who isn't a cheesy thug or a trigger-happy SWAT team member - but among the dark rooftops, smokestacks, red brick facades and Ace Chemicals billboards there emerges plenty to do, and I am loath to scold a game for rebelling against the fad of instant gratification. Besides, some of it is there from the start should you be paying attention. There are a host of character-building challenges to complete, for example, by doing things like performing certain combinations in combat or gliding through rings dotted around the city. These tasks are just sitting there quietly listed in one of the pause menus.

The one area where Arkham Origins truly distinguishes itself from Rocksteady's work, of course, is the part of the game that UK studio Splash Damage developed: multiplayer.

In Arkham Origins' online mode, three of Bane's mercenaries face off against three of Joker's gang across four maps, fighting over capture points and trying to kill the opposition until they no longer have any Battlefield-style respawn tickets left and can be wiped out.

As well as limited-use knockoff versions of Batman's see-through-walls detective vision, and loadouts that can be customised with unlockable weapons and abilities such as an explosive RC blimp, each team can also call on their master when they hit a certain threshold. Bane has powerful melee attacks, while Joker has a pair of pistols good for one-shot kills and spamming explosives.

The biggest twist, though, is that two other players control a third team of heroes. Yes! Someone gets to play as Batman! (And Robin.) The heroes have a suite of predatory tools including grapple hooks and various batarangs and can stalk their prey from underground passages as well. They are rewarded for performing a variety of takedowns.

Despite the competing objectives, matches are simple to understand and often draw to a nervous conclusion, as Bane and Joker's teams run out of respawn tickets and try to pick each other off while the heroes circle. If a player takes out a hero at this stage, their downed team-mates retake the field, while heroes who die in this endgame lose much of their score.

Things can yo-yo very quickly, and while this can mean that the preceding drama feels as though it's more for show than anything, it's tense and exciting every time, and really does result in gang members waving their guns around at the shadows in terror, just as it should.

It's a fair amount of fun, then, but it's also the kind of mode you will enjoy for an evening rather than a lifetime. Taken on those terms, it's a welcome inclusion.
They also feed into Batman's tech tree, although this is one of the weaker areas of Arkham Origins. Batman is already well outfitted and his most useful additions - like the shock gloves, which allow him to power up electrical items and rain fizzly blows down in combat - are rewarded for making progress in the story, so I generally just invested my XP in tougher armour, which is a bit boring. Tech trees where you find yourself rooting around for the least uninspiring upgrade are always disappointing,

reviewText:
A lot of people are raging about Origins. They say that it's not as good as the last two games out of the Arkham series. They say it's bugged. They say that the multiplayer part is weak, buggy, not fun and instable.

I say that I pre-loaded this game, played it at release day and had a lot of fun with it. Level 174 at multiplayer. I never experienced a game breaking bug. It's running very well on my casual rig (two year old pre-build pc 700€).

Is it perfect? It's really close to perfect in my honest opinion. The story is thrilling, the gameplay is solid and fun, the muliplayer is a unique experience(3vs2vs3).

Do you like action games with a good story where you don't have to necessary shoot people into the head? Get this masterpiece. You won't regret it!

reviewText:
Let me clarify two things before moving forward with this review:
1) I have not encountered one single bug / glitch throughout the game during my playthrough. Perhaps one thing could be mentioned: Batman occasionally does some strange movements once in the air whilst gliding. But when you stop it and do the gliding again it is fine. So, I have to assume that by the time I played this game WB had patched it properly eliminating all (or most) of the annoying issues.
2) I have not tried multiplayer out, at all. I just didn't care. This franchise is all about the single player experience for me and after completing the story I moved on to other games simply skipping the multiplayer component. So, whether good or bad, I do not know and my review is based on the single player experience.

Additional criticism towards Arkham Origins (beside the handful of glitches) was its incremental nature. So, while Arkham City offered a couple of new things Origins does not do so. Media cited it should have been a more transformative sequel. But why? It prepares Arkham Knight for that - Rocksteady will do that (we already know vehicles have more involvement in the new Batman game), in the meantime, Splash Damage simply picked a working formula and created a game with that.

With that in mind Arkham Origins has one new thing: its story. This is now a prequel so Batman is just after his disappearance (the journey during which he honed his skills) and just started apprehending the bad guys of Gotham. Police, at this point, do not trust him (meanly because they fear him and another reason for that is them being corrupt). Of course, we have Gordon as the outstanding, good, by-the-book guy who can accept Batman (albeit he is making this decision reluctantly). So, it's interesting to be there from the beginning" and see - for instance - how difficult it is for Batman to cope with Joker (he's quite worked up after their first encounter). I liked the story and I liked the new villains - Black Mask

reviewText:
It's Arkham, It's Batman. Need I say more? Just don't expect the improvements like Asylum to City, since it isn't Rocksteady. I wish WB had been more daring with it, it's like they were too scared to alienate fans instead of trying out new things. Don't expect anything terribly fresh. It's largely a copy and paste of Arkham City, which, don't get me wrong, isn't a bad thing. Unfortunately the few changes they did make frustrate the heck out of me. I'll update if I find anything else, but I think I've explored most of the games mechanics by now.

Pros:

Boss fights: Bossfights are fantastic, infinitely better than rocksteady's to be honest, well, a few of them. (poison ivy anyone?) I've had a few so far, but the Deathstroke and Shiva fights were fantastic. Copperhead as well, can't wait to see what comes next. I loved the challenge, and getting the perfect completion trophies was a great was to test my skills. Few generic fights that every game has, but overall they've been great.

Open world: lots of enemies, plenty to explore. Alot of the side missions are unlocked by story progression, so expect to be locked into that. If you liked the design of City, it carries into here.

Crimes in Progress: I love these. Usually a tough group of enemies, nice difficulty, just don't expect to wrack up good combos without mashing dodge 24/7 (see below)

Cons: (so far)

Combat: I wish they had copy and pasted it. I wish. Enemies are extremely aggressive, and youll often find yourself being punched in the face while trying to perform a simple strike, and since batman moves in slow mo you cant hit and counter in time. If you played Arkham City to death like I did, youll notice. It's not obvious, but any veteran of those series will feel the slight change. Its ridiculously frustrating how hard it is to maintain any sort of combo without mashing dodge and striking once. The thugs will teleport punch to you, so even if you use freeflow to move 10 feet away, he'll somehow still hit you. I cant even batclaw slam without being punched in the middle of the slam and they weren't anywhere nearby. Really?

EDIT: i tried out the combat challenge mode, and the combat feels totally different. Very quick and responsive, felt even faster than it was in previous Arkham iterations. (Deathstroke is so fast i can barely follow how fast he strikes in focus flow) Not sure why its so different.

Collectibles: Scan tags, collect data packs, batarang network relays, interrogate informers. All a copy of different systems used in Arkham City and Harley Quinn DLC. I wouldnt mind but its all so mindless, I've yet to encounter a single challenging puzzle like I did in City. Got all the collectibles in City and had a blast. Here it feels like a chore.

Flying: I often find it really difficult to simply shoot to the top of a building and boost past. It likes to select the fire escape on the side of the building and makes it incredibly frustrating to get anywhere quickly. And expect alot of flying around, since you cant unlock all the fast travel points from the get go and the drop points can be rather far from the edge of district.

Upgrade Trees: I hate these. I hate these with a passion. I get it, its Batman starting out, he has to learn. Anyone who has experience with poorly designed upgrade trees knows what I'm talking about. Oh yeah, by the way, you HAVE to complete challenges in game to get some of the gagdets. They aren't too hard, but it took too long to get my damn sonic batarang.

It's a great game, if you loved Asylum and City you'll enjoy it, just don't expect anything too amazing. Hopefully Knight will remedy all the mistakes here.

reviewText:
Arkham Origins is a great game that doesn't deserve the flak it receives from most reviewers. Arkham Origins takes the gameplay mechanics from Arkham City - the responsive freeflow fighting mechanic demonstrating just how badass Batman is and the tightly coordinated predator rooms that allow multiple approaches - and combines it with a great storyline. If you enjoyed Arkham City, you'll enjoy this game.

The gameplay isn’t much different from Arkham City. You’ll have some new/replaced items, some new enemy types are introduced, the city has been expanded and they added a new detective mini-game. Ultimately, these are only minor changes from the solid base that Arkham City created. The game doesn’t offer the revolutionary changes that Arkham City did compared to Arkham Asylum, but rather expands on it.

The story features both well-known (Joker, Penguin, Bane) as lesser-known characters (Firefly, Shiva, Deadshot). Not every character is part of the main story, so it is advised to try and play the Most Wanted side missions for the full experience. The well-crafted Mad Hatter stage deserves a playthrough.

At the time of writing, it appears WB patched most of the bugs. During my three playthroughs (new game, new game+ and I am the night mode, 100%, roughly 70 hours), as well as during the Cold Cold Heart DLC, I experienced only a single non-game breaking bug. This is coming from an inherently more bug-prone Crossfire system. You’ll see most negative reviews because of bugs are pre January 2014.

Traditional rating: 8/10
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm conflicted about this game.  On the one hand its a very solid title.  Despite it being an obvious cash in on the Arkham series because WB couldn't wait for Knight to reach store shelves it still offers a lot of Batman kicking ♥♥♥ enjoyment.  The thing is people are very divisive about this game.  Either its the best in the series or its the worst.  Its just City with a new paint job don't kid yourselves.  City perfected the formula and Origins just came in and said why fix what ain't broke?

The gameplay is so similar to City that you wouldn't even know a difference if it was an expansion pack.  The gadgets feel more gimmicky when in previous games they had a practical application.  The remote claw replaces the line launcher and while its amusing it also makes predator sections even more brainlessly easy when they were already easy.  Who needs to actually stealthily take down baddies with guns when you can hook them to things and each other and take out 5/6 of the room without even moving?  On the flipside combat seems to have gotten harder with counters being a little different in timing and its a lot harder to hold up bigger combos when more variety in enemy types like venom brutes and martial arts experts.  The shock gloves feel like just evening things out at this point.

The story is probably this game's strongest part.  Without spoiling much this is Batman early in his career.  He's more stubborn and hot headed.  One of my favorite parts is Gordon and how his character progresses through the story and how he distrusts Batman and thats a really cool dynamic.  Young Barbara already got the inkling to become oracle here as well.  They do a really cool plot twist that is just as disapointing and I wont spoil it here.  I will say that Bane is the strongest part IMO.  As someone who has been waiting for a proper bane in something I am so happy with how they treated him here.  It also kinda helps explain why is the way he is in previous games.  Read the Knightfall comic storyline and see why not even Dark Knight Rises got Bane right IMO.

I'm just rambling at this point.  I'm a big Batman nerd if you couldn't tell lol.

Also shout out to the awesome voice acting across the board.

Finally the last thing I want to talk about is the open world.  This worked so well in City beacause it was all interesting.  It was densly packed and felt bigger than it actually was.  In this case its feels empty.   It feels like a city built around a video game instead of a video game built around the city.  Sense of scope is all scewed.  Parked cars all look like they were designed for midgets.  It doesn't look like a city at all.  It looks like a close up of a model city.  People complained about the riddler trophies in City and how many they were and how they got annoying getting them all" but at least those were interesting to get.  In this there is literally no challenge to getting any of them.  Errr I mean Enigma data packs :/.  You come across one and 5 seconds in you either have the gadget capable of getting it or you don't and move on.  This is actually its saving grace because prepare yourself for this game's biggest let down.  There is no reason to getting these.  Some XP and a little throwback to previous games.  Catching Riddler in City had a point.  He had hostages.  He needed to be dealt with.  He was a real threat and there was more to it than just collecting ♥♥♥♥ like an old 90s platformer.....  In this he's  blackmailing criminals and Batman has to stop that because.........  thats worse than beating them up?  Ok then well the completionist in me hated this.  There was no fun in getting them and absolutely no pay off because you don't even catch him.  Save the time and ignore this part of the game and it will be much more enjoyable I promise you.

So TL:DR gameplay is almost exactly the same as Arkham City.  Story is cool.  Game map and side missions are lame and boring.  The good outweigh the bad.  If you like Batman you'll enjoy this."

reviewText:
Have you played the previous Arkham games? No? Then do yourself a favor and don't start with Arkham Origins.

If you played the others and liked it then you'll likely enjoy this one as well. It is inferior in many ways though, and I'll try to make a comparison of the most pertinent aspects below.

Did you enjoy the story hinted on the trailers? If so, I'm  sorry to say this but you'll be disappointed. I won't spoil the surprise (even though I find it hard to believe it's a surprise to anyone by now) but there's a very obvious twist that simply negates the whole story advertised in the trailers. After the disappointment with the story passed I actually quite enjoyed it though! there are some interesting moments and characters. Nothing fantastic but it does its job competently.  Considering this is a prequel they certainly made some strange decisions reagarding the story. We know the villains, we know Alfred never dies, we know Batman doesn't die etc. These things can't really be used as tension effectively, but they certainly tried. They should have used the opportunity to introduce some new characters and put some real tension in there, but that's my opinion.

But the true problem with this game is the obvious lack of polish. Bugs, glitches, freezes,crashes, performance drops... you name it, Arkham Origins has it. The lack of polish also shows on most of the gameplay features. A few examples: when in combat mode, the camera will be your worst enemy, showing the wall, hiding behind light posts, losing sight of batman or, when not being completely against you, just sitting the least helpful orientation possible with every enemy on the wrong side of the camera. Other example of lack of polish in gameplay is when gliding accross the city. You'll find yourself frustrated by the grapple's edge detection system. It has the habit of not detecting obvious edges you can see right in front of you, sometimes detecting edges you have no intention of grappling to etc. It's a less satisfying experience to say the least. These examples just illustrate the way the game was rushed to the shelves. It lacks polish, the kind of things solved by tweaking of parameters until everything feels right.

My last complaint is the zipline feature. This was one of the fun things in other games, all you needed was a wall behind and in front of you to zip accross it! Fun and a gameplay element that opens up so many possibilities. In this game they ditched that for a zip line you can attach to nodes that are put on the map by the level designer. It's so boring. It's essentially a door/key system in disguise. A very similar dumb move was made by Thief developers when ditching the freedom of rope arrows in favor of predetermined nodes where you can put your rope. It's just a fancy key to a door.

It's hard to find something they did better than previous games. I like the graphics a lot! but it's not exactly better, it's just different, more realistic style. But I do welcome the different approach, it looks very nice.

If we weren't comparing with previous Batmans (which admittedly is a difficult position for any game to be in) I would say the bugs are the main problem with it. Some of them are absolutely game breaking! but if you can endure that this is a great game. It has my recommendation.

reviewText:
*Contains minor spoilers*

I’ve been a fan of the Arkham games since Asylum, and they never fail to impress. That being said, Origins feels like a step backwards from its predecessor, Arkham City.

Based during the early years of Batman’s career, the game focuses on a plot by the infamous crime lord, the Black Mask. I’m not familiar with the comics, so I was very happy to see a new primary antagonist replacing the Joker. The only problem was that Black Mask wasn’t the primary antagonist; it was surprise surprise, the Joker AGAIN. It was during the unveiling of this revelation that I became upset with Origins. I understand that he’s Batman’s arch enemy, but he had such a large role in the previous two games that I just wanted a break from his jokes. It became so much easier to compare the game to Arkham City, which was not a good idea.

The previous game, Arkham City, had a very deep and original setting. A prison city that was filled with Gotham’s worst criminals was very interesting. In contrast, Origins features a Gotham city roughly twice the size, but only half as interesting. Random criminals prowl the streets and no sign of other life can be found. I wanted cars, pedestrians, and so much more. I expected a living city.

There were parts of the game that impressed me though. I really liked the upgrade system. It’s still quite basic, but a definite step up from previous games that pretty much unlocked half of the upgrades from the get go. They added some cool new gadgets that I used quite often.

As for the bad guys, I felt they didn’t have enough screen time. One by one they showed up, you fought with them for 15 minutes, and that was the end of them. In particular, the fight against Deathstroke was one of the greatest boss battles I’ve ever played, but after beating it, he never made a return. What’s more disappointing was that his character was only available to play as in the boring and mostly generic challenge maps, rather than the actual campaign. Some of the other villains came and went without me really remembering them at all cough cough Electrocutioner. It kind of felt like Warner Brothers sold the game on the premise that there would be plenty of bad guys to go around, but delivered a mediocre performance from them. Quality is always better than quantity in my opinion.

The multiplayer is a new addition to the franchise and I don’t really know how to describe it. I feel as though the game didn’t need it and it was an attempt to get people to continue to play the game. There are times when it’s quite enjoyable, but I always felt as though it needed to be re-worked based on certain over-powered features such as the criminals detective vision.

Despite the uninspiring plot twist, the often annoying multiplayer, and the incredibly familiar gameplay, the game wasn’t that bad. I wasn’t too upset, but wasn’t too impressed either. I can safely say it felt like a 6/10 experience on the whole. Worth playing if you like the Joker, not so much if you wanted more.

reviewText: A decent title that stands in the shadow of the two games in the same vein that appeared before it, Batman Arkham Origins is a hard title to recommend even to fans of the other two games. The gameplay copies the other two titles to a T, with no originality thrown in. This is made worse since the combat in the other games flowed much better and this game generally has a small list of bugs. The story is very run of the mill, I found myself extremely disappointed as it started running over old villans for the third time now instead of using the newer villans to greater effect. The game does so little to make itself different from the others, and is so sloppy in execution that the game drags on towards the end.\n\n6/10 If you're a fan you can consider getting it on sale, but as a large fan of the past two games I honestly regret the time I spent playing this. Still a great game for completionists with too much free time, and it's not entirely half bad. reviewText:
Ehh... it's okay.

This one isn't made by the same people that did Arkham Asylum/City, but it plays pretty much exactly the same. And since that was already good gameplay there's little more I can say about it. The story takes place when Batman is still relatively new at his work apparently, but the only real way you see it is in how other characters act towards you. Otherwise, all the skills and gadgets are there for you to use. So it all feels kind of disingenous when everyone acts like you are this new vigilante who might not actually be real, but you have the full skillset of the Batman that everyone later knows. Not exactly what this game said its Batman was like.

One highlight of sorts is the voice acting: Batman and the Joker got new VA's for this, and yet I couldn't really tell the difference. They both sound close enough to Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill that, had I not known in advance that the latter wasn't the Joker anymore, I wouldn't have forced myself to look it up to check for sure. So I guess that's something. Oh, and our new Joker is the same guy who voiced Booker Dewitt from Bioshock Infinite. I thought that was neat.

I can't call this a bad game, but I wasn't really into it either. I'll give this a yes" because there is nothing fundamentally wrong with this game

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins manages to be the worst Arkham game that, disappointingly, barely does enough to justify its asking price of £30, especially if you have played Arkham City.

Lets start with the good things.
- The story in Origins is very good, possibly the best out of the current trilogy. While there are pacing problems, the overall plot is deep, thought out and even manages to surprise in a few areas.
- Sound design and the soundtrack are superb; feeling like they had a real production value and weren't just simply overlooked. (unlike some other things)
- The voice acting is incredible, for the most part, with Troy Baker as The Joker stealing the show. (though Roger Craig Smith as Batman does a pretty good job at emulating Kevin Conroy from previous games) I must admit it's jarring to hear Batman's voice at first, (being so used to Conroy's work) but it doesn't take long to get acclimatised, with halfway through the game, barely noticing the difference.
- The game manages a decent length of around 10-12 hours for the main story.

Now on to the negatives.
- The game world, while being of a decent size, is too cumbersome to travel round. Most of your time in the open world will be spent travelling from A to B by grappling rooftops. The fast travel does alleviate this, but you have to unlock the various points by overtaking radio towers as side missions, making the whole thing feeling a bit like too much work.
- Most of the side missions are now completely seperated from the main plot, they are now mostly unintresting and uninspiring filler.
- The combat is only slightly improved from City, and with the inclusion of the new shock gloves, makes it far too easy to beat enemies.
- Most of the little refrences and in-jokes to other DC comics which made the previous games that little bit more awesome are gone, it feels like most of the devs aren't as passionate as Rocksteady and it would have be nice for a couple of easter eggs here and there.
- The first part of the plot (about the assassins) doesn't quite gel with the rest of the story and feels like an excuse to shoe horn some D-list DC villans.
- The Penguin's 'assistants' are some of the worst characters I have ever seen in a Batman game. Plus the thick (what I assume is meant to be cockney) accent of one of them is so horrible, it's on par with Bolo Santosi in Just Cause 2.
- While I haven't played much of the multiplayer and while it was fun, it lacks depth to keep my interest, making it only passable at best.
- The biggest flaw of Arkham Origins, however, is its MOUNTAIN OF BUGS. While most of the game breaking bugs have been reportedly fixed, there are still a plethora of visual bugs, such as the skybox having circular clouds covering it, textures spazzing out and not unlocking certain areas of the game. Fortunately, in my personal experience, all it needs it a checkpoint restart. Others haven't been so lucky. As WB Montreal aren't fixing the game anymore a minority will most likely never finish the game, buy at your own risk.

This game is nowhere near worth its full asking price, and some of it is really good and well done, which only makes it more painful to say that if you have never played the Arkham games NEVER EVER PLAY THIS. If you have played the previous two then wait for a sale, only then it will be worth at least a vague look.

4/10

reviewText:
Batman : Arkham Origins is yet another installment in the popular Arkham series, but it doesn't fall in line with the other 2 games seeing as developement was handled by WB Montreal.

Right off the bat I'd like to say that WB did a great job with this game considering how new they are as a studio.

Yes, when you start playing, you'll see a different, slightly more cartoonish batman, you'll eventually get over it. The first few hours will feel very empty and pretty much dissapointing, if you have played the other 2 games of this series. The overworld feels empty, geometry detail is very simplified even with DX11 effects enabled. Overall the mood was pretty badly executed as far as the city itself goes. You will only see impressive visual and level design once you go indoors, where lights are elaborate, cinematic and colorful. Colour is much more abundant this time.

The combat system, both predator (stealth) and close up combat, remain pretty much identical to previous versions, aside from a few superficial changes like sounds. There is however a new mechanic that increases your damage output towards the second half of the story, but I don't want to spoil that for you. I found that close up combat felt more satisfying than stealth, simply because the stealth rooms were not designed for you to be creative, really. Rocksteady made extremely enjoyable stealth challenges, and WB basically was not capable of getting anywheres near that level of intricate design. All you really have to do in these sections is grapple around, wait for an enemy to seclude himself from the others, and take him down by gliding behind him and performing a silent takedown, rinse and repeat. So basically, this time close up completely trumps stealth, where as I found in City and Assylum, the stealth was more enjoyable than close up.

Gadgets remain from the previous games, some replaced by something similar, essentially reskinning previous ideas.

The main thing that WB really did right this time, is the storytelling, and the way you progress through the game. Arkham City's progression was fairly short, focused and let's face it, not very complex. Origins obviously tells the story of Batman's beginning, when he was considered a criminal just like the Joker, or Black Mask. Although Batman remains fairly emotionally flat, he lets out a lot of steam, and even interrogates many enemies through semi-torture, something that was rarely adressed before. Batman seems weaker in this game, he is actually a real, relatable person, in some ways. There is a sense of character progression that was completely absent in the other games. Hell, you even finally see some sort of relation between Batman and Joker that actually makes some sense, and let me tell you that relation becomes extremely interesting, and at times it almost seemed that Joker admired Batman, or even loved him.

TL:DR: Origins is a narrative experience, lacking the immersion of the previous 2 games but replacing that with a cohesive, understandable story with much more variety. Is it better than the others? No. but is it worse? I can't really say that, either.

It is definitely worth the price that I got it at, during the summer sale.

reviewText:
I AM THE NIGHT..........................................

Batman Arkham Origins cannot be called a game. It would be insulting to call it a game. Rather it is a expereince. Batman Arkham Origins is the vision of beauty, the perfect Batman simulator. It has detective work, Batman beating up thugs and the Joker. Reviewers complained that it is nothing new from Arkham City and I am not denying that. However, it is still one of the greatest Batman games ever. The predator encounters are intense and the fights are pure awesomesauce. Hearing the thugs reaction upon sneakily performing an inverted takedown is great. Batman feels like the night.

However, the icing on the cake is the boss fights. As you transverse through the story you meet some of your most iconic enemies. The boss fights are awesome because they are not AT ALL scripted events. The bosses take damage like normal enemies.  However combat with them is very fulfilling. Each boss adds variety and menace.

Thus I concude by saying that this game is pure awesomesauce and you SHOULD buy it. ♥♥♥♥ IGN. You cant spell ignorant without IGN. Seriously ♥♥♥♥ them.

reviewText:
This game is set before the events of Arkham Asylum. This game wasn't made by Rocksteady like the other two, instead developed by Warner Brothers Montreal. This is without a doubt a great game. But if you were overwhelmed by how great Arkham City was and is now thinking this game is good, you may be dissapointed. The story, while good, wasn't the best. The enviornment, in my opinion wasn't great. There is multiplayer in this game, unlike the first two, but is sadly disappointing.

However the game is still great. Beating up thugs is still awesome. The gameplay is fun. It still has the 'Batman' feel. The game is still great. Only the story and the multiplayer took away the sensation of the previous games. If you like Batman, I highly reccomend this game. If you loved Asylum or City and think this game will be just as great, you may pass it on for now. Many people consider this the 'black sheep' of the Batman Arkham Games.

7/10

reviewText:
I am writing this review for people that have played Batman : Arkham City (AC) and wonder if they should get Batman : Arkham Origins (AO).

If you are looking to get your mind blown by a massive improvement between the two games (say new mechanics, new engine, new gameplay features, new playable characters, maybe vehicles, etc.), then you will be disappointed : AO is basically a glorified AC. It does not bring much more than AC already did. In certain area (playable character), it actually brings less.

But if you are looking to extend the AC experience, on a new town with a new campaign, then AO is definitely the game to go for and it will not disappoint you.


Let me put some Arkham Origins in your Arkham City :
AO is indeed only" a second version of AC
date: but this is a very good second version of AC. You will get a few new gadgets
recommended: a lot of new combat perks
hoursPlayed: a new "in game integrated" achievement system (that you must fulfill to unlock a specific serie of combat perks)
voteText: among other things.\n\nThere is now a system which rewards you for your performance after every encounter
helpfulPercent: with an XP multiplier : the better you do
votesHelpful: the more XP you get. This is a very good addition in that it forces you to play well and try different things (do not lose combo
votesTotal: do not get hit
votesFunny: use different takedowns
commentsCount: etc.)\n\nThey made something different with the boss fights
column16: which are sort of based on quick time events (QTE). While I'm not a fan of QTE
column17: to say the least
column18: it does make up for more cinematic fights and the game is quite forgiving in that if you die
column19: you'll get to retry at the last "stage" of the boss fight you died in. The "amount" of QTE depends on the boss
column20:
so not all the fights play the same.

On that matter

my quick recap as of november 2014 :

Yet

column25: it's ok.\n\nSecond

it will not. Mildly annoying.


Final impression :
So all in all : if you really enjoyed AC and are looking for some additionnal content

reviewText:
As much as it would shorten things to say that if you liked or are at least familiar with previous arkham games, you won't find much new here. You have virtually the same gadgets, same fighting system, same UI, similar city, the only thing that really changed was the voice actors and storyline and for the most part, that’s totally fine if all you wanted was more batman and the DLC for arkham city just wasn't enough, and for the most part, that was me. As of writing, I haven't actually completed the game, but I feel like I got a pretty good impression as to where everything is headed. Because this is a prequel to the other arkham games, it can't really throw too much at you in terms of story as to not mess with the canon, and this kind of permeates the entire game. Everything feels like its playing it safe, and no real effort has been put in to expanding on the previous games in any light, though again, this isn't really a bad thing, it's just something that will constantly be nagging at you in the back of your head as you play.

The gameplay mechanics are virtually untouched except for a few minor things relating to the upgrade path. And again, not really bad, because the previous mechanics it uses, are probably some of the best brawler mechanics in recent time. One thing I can do without though is the often clunky PC controls, half of my deaths could be attributed to the weird key presses required to dodge and preform special moves. This was a problem in the previous titles, and I feel like there really isn't anything that can be done about it, so I feel like some sort of 360 pad required" tag would be nice.

The story isn't really anything special so far

reviewText: My personal favorite Batman game to date. It's darker, grittier, and more sinister than both Arkham Asylum, and Arkham Origins. It may not be Kevin Conroy as the Caped Crusader, but Roger Craig Smith does a decent job at a younger, inexperienced Batman. Troy Baker also takes over the mantle as The Joker, the unstable, unshakeable, villain we know and love; and he pulls it off well! While combat hasn't changed drastically from the previous games, Arkham Origins still delivers that Batman feeling we know and love. I don't recommend the multiplayer, however.

reviewText:
According to many critics a flawed mess, I find it rather enjoyable. Yes, it has a number of weird glitches, but up until now I have not run into anything game breaking. The combat remains pretty much the same from AC, the combos look better, the story is fine, and more detective work is interesting. The side quests are awesome, you will meet old and new adversaries, some of them you already met in the previous games (well, previous games, but in continuity, AO is a prequel). As someone who spent more than 30 hours in both AA and AC I can recommend this game mostly to fans of both games, while new players should really start with Arkham Asylum.

8.5/10, would be 9 if not for the minor glitches which are annoying.

Edit: There is hope for some bug fixes in the upcoming DLC Cold Cold Heart, even though they denied they are making anything. At least I find it rather stupid not to fix the common issues with bugged Enigma stuff.
Edit n.2: After finishing the story I have to say, AO has the best story of all the Arkham games.
Edit n.3: The DLC Cold, Cold Heart is fine. Nothing spectacular, the crash was fixed pretty fast, minor glitches still exist (weird camera angles and the weird movement of the camera). But it was better than the DLC in AC, so a few (literally 2-4 hours depends on your clear time) and it has the well known Freeze backstory. 7/10 for the DLC

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins should have been a standalone expansion to the Arkham series.

A quick note about glitches: from the 20 hours of gameplay, I encountered some animation bugs but sadly, one major bug that would not let me finish the game with keyboard and mouse at the climax of the game in the chapel.

While everybody is talking about the game being riddled with bugs, I cannot help but feel that Arkham Origins was made to cash in on the popularity of the Arkham series. While the story that is set on Christmas Eve is neat, the writing is sloppy, and the assassins are making a lot of dumb and contradicting decisions. Even though I played Arkham City two years ago, I can tell that some of the assets were re-used in this game. Moreover, the gameplay has not changed much, except for some additions to your equipment. So just take what made the Arkham games great, then rinse, repeat.

Fans of the Arkham games sooner or later will ask the following questions:
- Why does Batman start out with all of his equipment from Arkham City at the beginning of the game?
- Where are all the people in Arkham? I guess they are all locked inside, right...
- Why is the writing so forced in some areas, especially with the Joker?

Do not get me wrong: Arkham Origins is a very enjoyable game and there are some nice moments in it, but this whole origin story could have been dealt with much, much better.

If you played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, you should not buy the game at full price.

reviewText:
Personally, I've played all of the Arkham games and loved them so much that I went to 100% complete each one with the exception of Asylum. This one is the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of the lot. The world is much larger than the previous game (Arkham City) which is a plus, however that being said, they recycled half of the map from Arkham City as well. The buildings are taller, so you're able to glide from point a to point b with no issues but it's kinda pointless to do so. The fast travel feels very repetitive. The Bat Cave is a neat little addition to the game. The story felt very generic, with a very forseeable twist. It has some really neat easter eggs, like towards the very end of the game you got to meet Harleen Quinzel the intern.

The Gadgets... oh my god the gadgets. You start out with the Grapnel Booster for one, secondly they're almost identical to the gadgets from Arkham City. Baterangs, Bat Claw, Explosive Gel, all of that good stuff makes a return. The Freeze Grenade was replaced with a Glue Grenade and it (not kidding) is EXACTLY the same as the Freeze Grenade. The remote claw is neat, but it's comparable to the line launcher. You can even hold a button to ride down it just like the line launcher.

Lastly, the Riddler (Now known as Enigma) side objective. It was a joke. What I always do is clear the game, beat all the bosses and start to go for all the thugs that work for The Riddler. After I got all the information where the riddler items are, I go out and find them all. This whole process in Arkham City took me about 40 hours to complete on top of all the other things, so probably about a combined total of 55 hours or so (not including game+). In this game, Arkham Origins, it took about 8 hours to gather all of the riddler items.

All in all, this is an okay game. However if you compared to the previous two in the series, it's terrible. If you're thinking of purchasing this game just wait til the Game of the Year edition is released, and goes below $29.99.

reviewText: Arkham Oranges is a lovely game, that sadly only got mixed reviews due to its buggy launch and similaritys to Arkham City. Arkham Oranges feels like Arkham City 2.5, however, in my opinion this is not a bad thing for a game made simply to tide fans over until Arkham Knight. The game builds upon the great systems that City introduced, in my opinion Oranges offered a better story, however, this is for you to decide on your own. The multiplayer was a good edition but one I don't think the game required. In short Oranges Arkham is a good game it improved a already great game series, but did not innovate all that much.

reviewText:
Story mode completion, didn't touch multiplayer or any DLC.

Pros:
-Story is great. Really goes in depth of Batman before he's well established in Gotham.
-Minor tweaks that help you explore the city are fantastic (I used that turbo grapple thing a zillion times, that made it easy to get around.)
-I felt like the level-up progression had mostly good choices, it was hard to decide what to put points into. Shock gloves were awesome to use since they were so powerful too.

Cons:
-Buggy as ♥♥♥♥. Had 2 crash to desktops, and numerous disappearing walls, To top it all off, my favorite bug was fighting the first boss, Killer Croc, and PUNCHING HIM SO HARD HIS MODEL DISAPPEARS. Fighting an invisible enemy sucks, but at least I got a good laugh on that one. This is 6 months after launch too, I'd hate to have had this on launch day.
-They recycled the Bane fight from Arkham Asylum. Not only did they recycle it though, you fight him again later in Origins, and it's the same fight but with more anonymous henchmen thrown in. The other fights, while neat to watch, are pretty quick time event heavy.
-Only one new gadget is cool, Glue Grenades. Everything else feels like a gimmick or has been in a previous game in the series.
-Collectibles feel worthless. You get XP by getting them, but since you only upgrade the gadgets you like, it feels like a waste.

Pick this up if it's cheap and you're bored, everyone else should replay the others.

reviewText:
Story mode completion, didn't touch multiplayer or any DLC.

Pros:
-Story is great. Really goes in depth of Batman before he's well established in Gotham.
-Minor tweaks that help you explore the city are fantastic (I used that turbo grapple thing a zillion times, that made it easy to get around.)
-I felt like the level-up progression had mostly good choices, it was hard to decide what to put points into. Shock gloves were awesome to use since they were so powerful too.

Cons:
-Buggy as ♥♥♥♥. Had 2 crash to desktops, and numerous disappearing walls, To top it all off, my favorite bug was fighting the first boss, Killer Croc, and PUNCHING HIM SO HARD HIS MODEL DISAPPEARS. Fighting an invisible enemy sucks, but at least I got a good laugh on that one. This is 6 months after launch too, I'd hate to have had this on launch day.
-They recycled the Bane fight from Arkham Asylum. Not only did they recycle it though, you fight him again later in Origins, and it's the same fight but with more anonymous henchmen thrown in. The other fights, while neat to watch, are pretty quick time event heavy.
-Only one new gadget is cool, Glue Grenades. Everything else feels like a gimmick or has been in a previous game in the series.
-Collectibles feel worthless. You get XP by getting them, but since you only upgrade the gadgets you like, it feels like a waste.

Pick this up if it's cheap and you're bored, everyone else should replay the others.

reviewText:
Batman arkham origins is the first game in batman arkham games that was developed by Warner Bros. Games Montréal not rocksteady and the story is set 2 years before the story in b man arkham asylum. Okay first thing im going to talk about is the story:
The story is set on cristmas eve and black mask has hired 8 assassins to kill the Bat. In this game black mask will be important in the story. Batman is trying to save his head by takingdown every assassin my opinion is that the story in arkham asylum and arkham city are a lot better.
the second thing is gameplay:
the gameplay is the same as the previous games.One thing is realy good and that is the boss battles there are alot more boss battles than in the previous games and thats realy cool.
the third thing are the graphics and enviroment
The grapchics are the same as the previous games the system requiremens are the same but the problem is that the city is realy lifeles  and not well designet as arkham city so...
The multiplayer
Batman arkham origins is the first batman arkham game that has multiplayer. The multiplayer is realy fun there is 3 control points that you have to capture all three. When you capture all three you eliminate the gangs reinforcments to win that is invisible predator online mode but there is hunter hunted mode that you have only one life. The rest of the multiplayer you can check on the internet its realy realy fun and you can play as bane or joker or the heroes.
The final verdict:
The final verdict for batman arkham origins is:
story: 7.5
gameplay:9.4
graphics:7.8
multiplayer:10.0
So batman arkham origins is a good game but nothing like batman arkham asylum and arkham city. Thats what i expected when the other company developed a batman game and not rocksteady but the multiplayer rocks for me its the best multiplayer in the history of gaming, but most people would disagree. Well a new batman arkham game is coming out in october batman arkham knight and rocksteady will be developing it so i think it will be epic.

reviewText: WB may have patched the bugs that everyone is complaining about (or maybe I'm just lucky) but I just finished the rather short campaign and never hit any bugs that affected gameplay. The occasional FPS drop and unresponsive counter attack, yes. There felt to be a lot of loose ends with the main story that aren't addressed by the end of the game. Without giving too much away, there are certain villains that take a back seat as the story goes on and the game never revisits them, instead pushing the Bat towards one or two of them until you start to forget about the others. Overall, it's your basic Arkham game: smooth combat, strong storyline (except for the previously mentioned issues) and lots of bonus objectives after the completion of the story. Overall rating: 8/10

reviewText:
Arkham Origins is a pretty fun game with some exceptionally well done boss fights. The combat is the same free flowing wonder from the previous games. Its nice to see the early days of Batman shown in a video game. The vigilante/criminal uncertainty feels nice. The Batman-Joker dynamic is handled really well in this game.

One area in which the game lets you down is in the inconsistent world traversal, especially with grappling. When you are gliding around Gotham, it feels as if the developers decided to put in grapple points at random. So you lose the momentum and land when you dont want to. The usual tropes in Arkham games also are present. Mash A to open grates is extremely annoying.

All said, Arkham origins tries hard to be as good as the Rocksteady games before it. For the most part it is, but sadly it only comes close.

reviewText:
This was a damn great game. Comparing this game to most other games just seems unfair. The story is amazing, the graphics are amazing, the sound is amazing and it all runs and looks very good on my slightly outdated rig. Nothing was done poorly save for the fact that the game has quite a few more bugs in it than would be desirable. If you have never played a game in the Arkham series than you will very much enjoy this game, although I would personally recommend going in order of release (Asylum, City then Origins). That all being said this game is both a prequel and a fairly stand alone story so you can play it out of order if you want.

Now, after all that being said let's get some context of where I think this game stands in the series by first stating what I think of the first two games. I consider Batman: Arkham Asylum to be one of the few perfect games ever made. That being said I didn't care for Arkham City all that much. I did still quite like it but I felt that Asylum did everything better. The downsides are that for one the combat feels slightly slower and easier, not by a whole lot but it is noticeable. Being that Asylum felt like it had a perfect difficulty I see this as a downside. Another is that the open world design of City felt unnecessary as you were still locked in an asylum like before but this time it essentially just had a large outdoor room connecting everything. In short it may have been technically open world but it wasn't very open and it wasn't very world either. Asylum however was spooky and claustrophobic and it just worked. Another issue with City was the story. City was all over the place in a way. In Asylum we mainly had the Joker and few other villains on the way and that was fine but with City it just couldn't keep its focus on who the main villain was. Also Asylum had one silly moment in regards to the last part of the game but City felt like it had many silly moments through out.

That all being said I would place this game just slightly under Asylum but above City. The combat is back to actually being somewhat difficult as it is sped up from City's slower combat. This kind of all goes out the window once you get a certain upgrade halfway through the game but even then I would hold Origin's combat above City's. Another thing done better is the city itself. For once in the series you actually get to be outside of an asylum's walls and actually stop crimes in progress and solve crimes and such. It actually feels like you are inside of a city which is further helped by about doubling the size of the map from City. Lastly is the story. My god, Origin's story just might be the best. We see a younger Batman who doesn't have much experience and is essentially going through his first significant night of crime fighting. There actually some character progression as opposed to Asylum or City where Batman was already experienced and is who he is. That all being said I would like to repeat as I said above, Origin's only real failing is that this game seems to be quite a bit more buggy than a game should be. I heard at launch it was even worse but even as it stands now I have enemies get stuck in walls making sections temporarily impassible. Nothing has happened that can't be fixed by reloading a checkpoint however so it doesn't detrack too much.

To sum everything up here:
Asylum: 100/100
City: 95/100
Origins: 99/100

P.S. Oh yeah, there is also a multiplayer but I never bothered to try it. It's designed by Splash Damage so chances are it's quite good but I bet no one plays it anymore.

reviewText: Arkham Origins is not an origin story for Batman, but rather for how Batman comes across some of his greatest enemies in later years. That being said, Arkham Origins has a dark and impacting story that shapes his character within only one explosive christmas night. Though the game is handled by new developers, combat, stealthing, and other game elements are kept intact are extremely addicting. Though all of Gotham is exposed, the side content doesn't feel as immersive as one would want it to be, despite the fact it's most often fun. There are a few new gadgets, but nothing game changing. A few short conveniences also provide nothing too notable. It may have not stepped up the bar, but it's stil an Arkham Game. 8/10

reviewText: I give this game about a 8/10 its a very well done game with a amazing campaign lots of side missions and just a huge amount of content including a super fun mutliplayer, not the only issues I have with the game is the lacking amount of players on multiplayer(which can easliy change) but would be the amount of glitches now offline has just glitches that don't out right make gameplay harder in any shape or form it just has glitches that can be noticable but funny, Multiplayer in this game is my favorite mutliplayer of ALL TIME, it has a great feel to it, its a super fun thing to play but it also feels too dark at times, the matching making can also be weak at times, and there is a lack of maps/game modes which multiplayer only has 2 modes and no one even plays the other one it just needs some really fun but stupid mode to get you more hyped up, but multiplayer can occasionally have game ending glitches or unfair glitches giving advantages to a random team(but are extrememly rare) there are some super annoying glitches for multiplayer such as: when you finially get to play as Batman this glitch can sometime change your Batman Costume or even make you play as Robin, the evil Robin twin glitch, being locked in the super villian spawn, matches won't start or end and connection dropping from steam too much, It may sound like its really bad but its really rare for those to happen its very fun and I reccomend this game to any fan of Batman!!

reviewText:
I only slightly recommend this game for people who want to continue the game series, for others I DONT recommend it. Play the previous ones. I am a fan of the previous games and of batman but this series keeps getting worse, at least for PC.

1. The Story is fine. Nothing major. Just fine. You have a lot of side quests to do if you are bored. They are pretty boring after a while because repeating the same bust over and over again seems pointless. Especially the extortion files (riddler things) are boring as they repeat themselves for every territory. No idea who thinks that kind of grinding is fun.
Some cutscenes are skipable some are not, just telling you that its loading but it probably isnt.
It is a mystery to why it is not possible to listen to tapes while gliding through gotham. Worked in previous game but not here. That means you have to stay in the audio file and wait for it to play till the end. That breaks with the flow of the game.

2. The graphics are good considering when it was made, the faces are mediocre though.
This game is out for years and there are still so many repeating bugs in there.
FIrst bossfight against croc pretty much always glitches and croc himself is dissapearing out of the world and reappearing (flickering) and the sound cuts off at the later stages.
If you glide of places you sometimes have a bug where you kinda flap your wings like a bird.
The games sometimes even crashes if you enter a ingame cutscene, happend to me at least once, other times it just hang for a short time.

3. Controls are as bad as always. You just do sometimes things you dont want to do or sometimes counters do not work even though you pressed.
This makes the boss fights so much more annoying. Most of them are stupid gimmick fights. The fight agains Bane just takes forever because of the controls and the limited options of how to take him down.
The fight against Deathstroke is probably the stupidest of all with those counters. This is barely a fight and more a game of counter. Who counters better. Considering how early you fight him this is a good spot to just stop playing if you cant defeat him in normal or high difficulty because at first you dont really get the fight after a few tries.

The world is essentially a bigger Akrham City I guess. It looks very similar of course. Thats good as you have spots that you remember.

4. I have played 2 games of multiplayer. Playing as one of the thugs is horrible if you know how a shooter is supposed to be played. The camera control and controls are so ♥♥♥♥. Dont even try it, believe me.

5. Cold Cold Heart is the only addon that makes sense so dont buy the season pass.

I am not gonna say that this game is bad but it has a lot of issues and thats why its AVERAGE at most. After playing this game I am not surprised how broken Arkham Knight is supposed to be on PC.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is the Prequel-Sequel to the previous 2 Arkham games. Developed and published by WB Montreal instead of Rocksteady, one might be turned off to the idea of this game and would be unwilling to give the game a try. I disagree. Here's why:

Arkham Origins takes place a few years before Arkham Asylum, 2 years after Bruce Wayne donned the cowl of Batman. One of the leading criminals, Black Mask, is tired of Batman ruining his plans and sends 10 elite mercenaries (some more elite than others) to kill Batman in one night, Christmas Eve, for 50 million dollars. The story mainly follows Batman evading and defeating the mercs, as well as chasing down the Black Mask. As with Arkham City, there are a few twists and turns along the way, bringing a good time to the game.

The Origins" part of the game is very interesting
date: as it explores the origins of the Joker as the Red Hood (canon in the comics)
recommended: if not only breifly. It also explores the stuggle Batman is having with himself and how he feels the need to protect gotham from itself and all the super-criminals.\n\nAlthough the voice actors for Batman and the Joker are not the regular that we all know and love (Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy)
hoursPlayed: the replacements that WB Montreal found are absolutely a great substitute. While not the actors that made the characters what they are
voteText: the performances were far from sub-par
helpfulPercent: and should not be the factor that keeps you from playing the game. You can tell that the actors tried very hard to keep the roles what they were
votesHelpful: in order to preserve the legacy. The actor who plays the Joker does a phenomenal job
votesTotal: and I did not even realize that the actor was not Mark Hamill until I heard his monologue around half-way through the game. The Batman actor is a bit more noticeable but nothing to complain about.\n\nThe map is bigger than Arkham City's
votesFunny: and feels as such. There are plenty of side activities to do when you are tired of (or done with) the main story. The most fun of all of these is definitely the Crime Scenes that you can come across
commentsCount: and pretty much "solve" murders and thefts. There are also radio towers that Enigma (The Riddler) has hacked. These can be restored through fighting through enemies and using your cryptographic sequencer. This is recommended to do as each tower you restore unlocks the district for fast travel
column16: which signifigantly increases the speed of play.\n\nThe combat and gameplay is not very different from Arkham City or Asylum's
column17: but this isn't a problem to me
column18: as the combat does not need to be changed too much. There are 2 new enemies to fight
column19: the martial arts expert
column20: and Bane's super enforcers. While adding some diversity to the combat
column21: it can feel repetitive at times
column22: and I found myself avoiding combat situations and crime calls during the free roam parts of the game.\n\nOverall
column23: this game is a great addition to the Arkham series
column24: even if not near close to the best game in the franchise
column25: and if you plan to play through all of the games
column26: do not forget Arkham Origins. Though nowhere near a perfect game
column27: I personally find it a better game than Arkham City.\n\n8.4/10"
