reviewText: This game get's a lot of hate due to the fact that the map is largely the same as the map from Arkham City. Personally though, I enjoy this game a lot. I think that Rocksteady have upped the ante when it comes to side quests, and there is a feeling of urgency" in completing them due to the fact that they are assassins out to kill you. I also enjoyed seeing some of the lesser known (less mainstream) villains like Copperhead and Electricutioner
date: though was dissapointed with the fact that there is no actual boss fight for the latter.\n\nAnother thing that I love is the addition of the Batcave as well. This is something that I have personally wanted to see in every Arkham game
recommended: and the small cave in Asylum just doesn't come close to the one here in Origins. It;s also a nice touch to add the Batwing as a form of transport (cut scene only) as it can help you rush around the map if you need to and the cut scenes look pretty awesome too.\n\nI personally like the story in Origins too
hoursPlayed: much more than the story from Arkham City too. I know a lot of people dislike the fact that the Joker plays a pivotal role (This being the third game where he is the lead villain) but in all honesty
voteText: I think it works very well. It shows you the transition from the mainstream real life mafia crime family type thugs (sionis/falcone) to the much more twisted super-criminal breed like Joker and Harley Quinn. I think it is very well done in introducing Batman's arch-nemesis and showing the depths of his deviousness.\n\nThe game engine itself is basically the same as Arkham City. A few of the skills on the utility belt wheel have swapped around
helpfulPercent: but that has happened in every Arkham game so isn't a major change really. They have added one or two new gadgets as well (usually collected from an assassin once you have beaten them) and that does make the gadgets seem fresher than before which is a good thing.\n\nThe Cold
votesHelpful: Cold Heart DLC is also masterfully done and it introduces you to Mr Freeze and shows you why he is the way he is. It also allows you to see a part of Wayne Manor
votesTotal: and you see one or two new toys that Batman has in his arsenal. Anarky also plays a small part in this DLC as there was a quest that was removed from the main game at the last minute and so was added to the DLC as an extra. Personally I feel that this is the best DLC to date
votesFunny: and whilst it can be completed in a matter of hours
commentsCount: it does feel like a game in itself.\n\nI would say that this game get's far too much hate
column16: and really doesn't deserve it. This is probably my second favourite in the series
column17: and I would recommend this to anyone who has played any of the Arkham games and wants to see more.\n\nTry it with an open mind
column18: I can pretty much gaurentee that you will like it."

reviewText: The best batman game so far. It improves many aspects of Arkham City. The campaign is more engaging. The narration is fluid and full of plot-twists. Some scenes are epic, really! The combat system is the same as Arkham City, perhaps a bit harder, and the upgrades are almost the same. That's a bit disappointing, but it's not a huge problem since the previous game hade already a very good gameplay. The map is double the size of AC: old gotham ( arkham city before the earthquake) and new gotham (more verticality). There are a lot of sidequests but not all of them are good... The voice acting is just great! I initially had some doubts about batman's new voice actor, but he surprised me. In my opinion he's even better than Kevin Conroy. Also Joker's voice acting is great! Then there are challenge maps as in the previous games and...the multiplayer, which I haven't tried yet due to some bugs (which they have solved now). good job wb montreal.  9/10

reviewText:
Batman Arkham Origins is not a bad game.In fact it's rather strong.But what holds it back is failure to add meaning full changes to the orignal games.

Pros-
+A young Batman.A Batman who's not as hardened and is vulnerable.
+The excellent Predator gameplay and free flow combat returns from the orignal games.
+Voice acting is top notch and Troy Baker does a fine job of Joker.
+Crime scene investigation.
+Engrossing side missions and activities.
+Joker and Batman.
+Boss battles are challenging.

Cons-
-Doesn't really move things forward.Most of my feeling when playing was 'been there,done that'.

Score-8/10

reviewText:
Played after Arkham Asylum and Arkham city, this game keeps the essence of those two games published before this one.

The storytelling is the same as the other two previous games and keeps alive the tension produced by your enemies, villains and criminals in Gotham.

I felt like the developers abandoned tis game more than the others because it was not toally polished, it has some noticeable bugs that, in my humble opinion, could have been avoided, In general aspects this game looks much more unpolished than the others I have played in the Batman saga.

In a nutshell, Batman Arkham origins keeps the essence of the Batman saga and if you have played any other game from the saga and you liked it, you will enjoy playing this too.

reviewText:
It's Batman, what could be more fun. You are Batman. But, it is NOT a Rocksteady game.  You are playing before the Arkham Asylum gamestory. Hints are provided with the Detective sight mode. Movement improved with Grapplehook. You spend points on improving your batgear and skills.

Platforming, puzzles, finding hidden objects, dynamic Melee action combat with batarang.   Great graphics and action, ok story.   Voiceovers for all characters in game.  Has bios of the bosses and npcs.

Has Multiplayer PVP Online game with players using Batman and Robin vs Joker and Bane, also playing as gang members of Bane or Joker factions.  Capture points and TDM modes.

Has Only support for Xbox 360 controller.  Playable with keyboard and mouse.

Has Steam Achievements and badge cards.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is said to be the weakest game in the Arkham series, and yes it is gameplaywise. Storywise this game isn't really outstanding and you can see the major plot twist coming from miles away. But the characters is what makes this game standout from the other two, especially the Joker. The Joker in this game is the most horrofying version I've met, the developers. We also get an insight in his messed up mind which kinda helps to not only portray him as a monster. Which I like, in the previous Arkham games the Joker is the main villain and only placed there to be a anarchistic lunatic who murders everyone who comes in his way.

I've read some reviews saying that this game got performance issues. I for one have not experienced any other than a few small FPS drops when flying through the air which is to be expected. It's a big good looking world where it snows all the time, there is snow on the ground aswell as people even though I have been able to pretty much max this game(except enhanced shadows) on my R9 280x.

The game is overall great and is a nice addition to the Arkham series. I would recommend playing this one before Asylum even though it's the third in the series it a nice introduction to it.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is a very welcome addition to the series. While it is true that it's almost the same as Arkham City in terms of gameplay, Arkham City was amazing, a very good game. That being said, the game does have some things you won't find in Arkham City, some better, some worse.
Gameplay
+ Everything is the same as Arkham City in regards to combat and stealth with a few new, but very welcome animations.
+ Boss battles are improved greatly, with lots of different bosses to fight and ways to fight them. No 2 boss battles are the same.
+ Several new additions of gadgets make puzzles and combat more fun and varied,
+ New ways to achieve gadgets and upgrades aside from the upgrade tree by completing certain challenges make the game more interesting and more fun to reach 100%.
- The fact that the gameplay is like Arkham City, however, will make fans of the series dissapointed, and it just feels like laziness on the devs' part.
- Added Shock Gloves" can be activated during combat to deal increased damage to enemies and basically ignore any armored enemies
date:
shielded or taser enemies. Also makes leaderboards a bit hard to beat without using these gloves.
- The beloved challenge mode doesn't feature any maps outside the story unlike previous Arkham games. Challenge maps are the same maps you've already played with challenges to complete.

World
+ The open world is double the size from Arkham City.
+ Lots of brand names and logos etc. from the DC Universe
recommended: feels like I'm still part of Gotham and not just a city.\n+ Lots of things to do while outside the main story. You can go ahead and help the police with crimes in progress
hoursPlayed: solve casefiles
voteText: or go capture villains (all have very fun and unique capture missions).\n- World feels very dull and empty aside from a few landmarks.\n- The Pioneer bridge connecting the 2 sections of Gotham is very boring to fly through
helpfulPercent: it's too big to just glide through with your cape.\n- Half of the world is just Arkham City before it was Arkham City with a lot of reused assets. I was promised Gotham
votesHelpful:
not one half what I've already been through in the previous game.

Story
+ Story features a TON of villains from the comics.
+ Lots of relationships forming in the story (Bats/Gordon/Oracle
votesTotal: Joker/Harley
votesFunny:
Bats/Joker etc.)
+The struggle of both the police and the criminals against Batman is very interesting.
+ Alfred plays a very big techincal and emotional part.
- Story itself has a pretty dumb premise
commentsCount:
8 assassins vs. Batman.
- The story likes to use "Because corrupt cops." as an excuse for a lot of things.
- Villains have very short time on screen.

Audio and Video
+ Graphics have been improved from last game

especially Troy Baker voicing the Joker does an amazing job.

reviewText: This game, Does not work as a sequel. If you own Arkham city, don't even think of buying this game. It is almost exactly a reskin of Arkham City, with a larger map and less memorable levels and boss fights. The map is a slightly modified version of the one from arkham city, with a very large bridge and a equally sized island. The story is okay, but the boss fights are absolutely terrible. Even on the easiest difficulty, I almost broke my monitor on the Deathstroke and Copperhead boss fights, which try to be like the Arkham city boss fights, but fail miserablely. All of them are 0/10 apart from the last Bane battle, which is fantastic like the Mr Freeze fight, exept you cannot hide or run ANYWHERE because of the small size of the room you are in, and Bane is charging everywhere. The combat is great as normal, but the developers could not hold themselves back from adding the Joker. Over all, this game is the same price as the Arkham city GOTY edition, but is worse. Just buy the Arkham City GOTY version. It is better, Funner and far more replayable.

I should mention that I played Arkham City with maximum graphical settings and benchmarked at an average of 30 FPS, so the fact that I had graphical issues and slowdown was interesting to me.\n\nWithin minutes of beginning the game I began to notice graphical issues. During the first boss-encounter with Killer Croc" was a memorable one

This left Batman looking like he'd made a wrong turn on the way to ninja school and had taken up the art of mime instead.\n\nMore graphical errors started when I got into a more open world environment

It was quite entertaining actually.\n\nI also have to report that the combat system is what you would expect from this latest generation of Batman:Arkham games - because it's copy&pasted from Batman:Arkham Asylum. reviewText:
I wanted to love this game, but you can tell how it wasn't as polished the same way it would've been if the original developers made it or if only they didn't do a Call of Duty franchise setup with it.

-The chaining of moves isn't as responsive as Arkham City.
-The grappling hook isn't that responsive when travelling. I always end up on buildings I have to walk around just to pass by it.

reviewText: Batman: Arkham Origins is definitely a game. But I bet the one person on my friends list who reads these wants more. So in this Batman game you play as Batman. Big surprise there; and I was waiting so eagerly in line for this game so I could play as bloody Catwoman again. The difference is that this time you’re beating up thugs in all of Gotham city instead of just a part of it. Don’t know why because the map is the same size anyway. Obviously the people in charge of Gotham are true visionaries to double the city limits and then section it off. The character list was actually different this time though. Instead of fighting Two Face, Penguin, Bane and the Joker you will be fighting Deathstroke, Penguin, Bane and the Joker. Well I didn’t say it was a big difference. Apparently every villain is supposed to reflect something of Batman; the Joker is his opposite and Deathstroke is his equal in combat. So hell if I know what Penguin reflects. Perhaps it’s Batman’s insecurities or perhaps I’m just trying to make this segment longer. I should remember to cross out the last sentence later.\nThere are two things to do in Gotham city; king-hit pedestrians and label them as thugs or collect Riddler trophies, but let’s be honest, you won’t do the latter. You can finally traverse the Batcave; a privilege I never collected upon because there was nothing in the Batcave with the exception of clutter. Maybe there was a secret, but bugger if I could be bothered to find it. I now see this series taking the Halo methodology in the sense that the developers said Origins was going to be the final game, but now the Arkham series has been taken back by Warner Bros. who have already announced the next game. So I guess I’ll see you back here when that bolt from the blue arrives. And for the record, this game has the twisted oddity of not having Nolan North voice acting a superhero/villain.

reviewText:
This was a big dissapointment unfortunately.
Arkham Asylum and City were both epic games that were both strong on story and on character. Here all of those elements are stripped away and you're left with the bare bones fighting parts of the game without much purpose.

The story is so thin. A bounty has been put out on Batman. Rather than just sit in his cave or spend the night as Bruce Wayne, he heads out into the city for everyone to take pot shots at him. This story is set back when Batman had only just begun apparently. This idea had real potential as we saw in the recent Batman movies but other than a brief mention of it at the beginning there's very little attention paid to this element in the game. And he has the Batwing! Which he never had in the earlier games... so he starts out his career with a freaking jet that he somehow looses later on? Comon!!
All the gadgets from the earlier games are also present which doesn't make any sense chronologically either.
I've no idea where the Origins element came from but I get the feeling its just a marketing ploy.

After ten mins of playing the game you realise you've been here before. City didn't feel like it was just more of the same. It expanded on both the gameplay and story of Asylum's more focussed efforts. This really feels like a mission pack.

i would only recommend this to the most die hard fans who won't mind that there's nothing new here.

reviewText:
Do not get your hopes up, if you buy this game. Also do not be fooled.
It may have the word Arkham in the title.
But it is far from the other great games, in the somewhat recent series.
Even with it on sale at 17.99. It's still a risky gamble, to buy this game, as you probably won't like it.
However at least it's pretty low risk, and makes some degree of sense at under 20.00 dollars.

However, I'm not convinced it's worth it at full price, even slashed a bit at 29.99.
The game is filled with bugs, and it plays like, wearing your pants on head RE RE.
If the other two games had a younger brother, who fell down a flight of stairs, making him mentally slow and he developed a drinking problem.
It would be this game.
I say it's a easy pass and it's best to wait for the next one, after looking through professional and player reviews.

This game is all but broken.

reviewText: This game was pretty cool, about an 6.5 out of 10.  The game play was very similar to Batman Arkham City.  It pretty much consisted of the same main missions and side missions as Arkham City except with different bad Superheros.  Gadgets pretty much performed the same  actions as the ones in Arkham City except these new" ones had different names and minor tweaks (i.e. new glue gernade instead of the old ice gernade.)  The old Riddler Trophies are now Enigma data packs but they involve almost identical puzzles as to Arkham City.  I could go on about this forever but you pretty much get the point.\n\nHowever
date: if you are able to play the game on the ultra settings

I couldn't believe how the snow on top of buildies realistically reacted to enemies and my footprints when sneeking and fighting.  Knocked down enemies leave body shaped dents in fresh snow cover and each foot print looks like real as if someone was walking through 4-6 inches of snow.  When inside buildings

reviewText: It may not have the gripping, egdy story of Arkham Asylum, or the pulsepounding gameplay everyone loved from Arkham City but this game still holds a place among some of the greatest Batman games. Simply because the overall formula in terms of combat and manuerverability around the now expansive city of Gotham, it has been given low marks. Personally, I feel that the storyline presented in this iteration of the Batman: Arkham franchise is one of their most unique and intriguing yet. It has shown a much more human side to The Dark Knight than has been seen since the end of Akrham City. Throughout the games, we simply know he is the Batman but here where learn WHY he is the Batman. That should be more than enough to grant this game a playthrough.

reviewText:
i would recommend batman to those who love a good story, a gripping edge game with lots of great mechanics and story, both the single player and the multiplayer are great,

Here are some pro's and con's about the multiplayer.

Pros:
*The game is really fun to play with friends
*The hero/villian is simmilar to the star wars battlefront 2 game making the game really fun to play.
*Being batman and robin with a friend can make the game really fun systimatically trying to take down all the villians.
*Being able to run around and hide as batman and robin makes it good because there are many ways to take out opponents.
*The games Mechanics are quite like Gears Of War, making the game a easy game to understand the mechanics off and just pick up a keyboard/controller and get to it.


Cons:
*in loading scenes if you hear your friends are on before you, that almost always means, you aint joining that game.
*there is no grouping system, so you all have to quickly try and get into the lobby while there is space.
*Nobody plays the other game mode, unless then cant find a game on the other one.
*at the start of a game you can join with a team of just you, even though the game must have 8 players at the start, meaning it kicks them off, which can make one sided games.
*Players cant join midgame.

reviewText:
First and foremost, this is decidedly not the first two.  Don't expect an improvement on City here, save perhaps the multiplayer.  That in mind, as a game on its own... It's not at all bad.

Pros:

It's a Batman game at heart:  There's a story that draws you in, combat is seamless, and there's an insanely good cast of villains and side characters alike.  The setting creates a good amount of immersion.
Gameplay here is great.  You swing, glide, and parkour through Gotham, again making every little journey fun, and not the least bit boring.  Combat's a mixed bag, with bosses not altogether unique, but each different arrangement and setting of goons you encounter make these battles the star of the game.  Gadgets are improved upon, and the new electrical gloves are fun as ****.
Multiplayer.  So many people knock this off, due to mechanical issues, but I easily enjoyed this part of the game more than the campaign, even.  With possibly the best and most mature online community out there, a brilliant concept for battle, with three teams facing off, and a nicely balanced armory that still feels customized depending on your gang, I easily looked over the glitches and connection instability to pour 30+ hours into this mode alone.
While the sound pales in comparison to Mark Hamill and city, the music and voice acting is extremely good.  You'll leave the game still feeling like Batman, the theme in your ears.Cons:
Well, it's very glitchy.  Some enemies sink into stairs, and a good deal of goons seem to be entirely blind.  The brick-throwing is completely broken, but hilarious.  (ran this on a 660, btw)  Few of the glitches I encountered are game-breaking, but it's very jarring to be this into a game, and suddenly see five goons walking into a wall simultaneously.  I spent much of the story bending over in laughter, and another good portion wrinkling my brow in frustration.  The latter came mainly when gliding, due to the.. err.. flapping error.  Basically, Batman has a sky seizure every three times you try to fly somewhere.  This happens often in multiplayer too, and is an even bigger annoyance there, as stealth is quickly ruined by wildly flapping wings far too often.
Multiplayer has some terrible key bindings that you can't change... The same button is used for silent takedowns and vision scrambling, which blurs your victim's screen, letting them know you're right behind them.  As you can guess, this is beyond frustrating, given that only a few inches determines which of these is triggered by your click.
The story and script are a little more ham-fisted than city or asylum, and there are a few groaner lines.
The map introduces fast travel... something no one asked for in these incredibly fun to traverse games, and expects the player to use them all the time.  This, for me, ruined much of the open-world feel I loved in the first games.
This is a prequel, meaning chronological synchroniation with the other two is key... This is perfect in all cases save one:  remember the prototype" grappler you get in city?  Yeah
recommended: Batman had the same thing ten years earlier
hoursPlayed: and just forgot about it.  Nice one

Will we ever see the conclusion to the story of Darth Maul? The world may never know. If only one could frolic throught the inner city like we did in the first (being Goldeneye of course). reviewText:
WB Games Montreal did many things well and can be compared to Rocksteady Studio's Arkham games.
The story is equally thrilling, the game has a great usage of characters (with the exception of Deathstroke, whose potential wasn't fully used) and has the same gameplay with little additions (like a bigger map), though without innovation. Music and voice actors are still awesome; Troy Baker successfully follows in Mark Hamill's steps.
The character models are even better than in the previous games (I needed to get used to Joker though.) and you get an average multiplayer mode that is enjoyable for some time.

There is only one reason why I can't recommend the game, though. It is buggy as hell. The worst bug is a problem many gamers had with this game: At the finale the game stops recognizing the input from your mouse and keyboard. So if you want to beat the game you need to use a controller. And if you don't have one: tough luck. The bug is known and yet they said they will prioritize on putting out a DLC instead of fixing it at the current time.

reviewText: Batman: Arkham Origins is definitely a game. But I bet the one person on my friends list who reads these wants more. So in this Batman game you play as Batman. Big surprise there; and I was waiting so eagerly in line for this game so I could play as bloody Catwoman again. The difference is that this time you’re beating up thugs in all of Gotham city instead of just a part of it. Don’t know why because the map is the same size anyway. Obviously the people in charge of Gotham are true visionaries to double the city limits and then section it off. The character list was actually different this time though. Instead of fighting Two Face, Penguin, Bane and the Joker you will be fighting Deathstroke, Penguin, Bane and the Joker. Well I didn’t say it was a big difference. Apparently every villain is supposed to reflect something of Batman; the Joker is his opposite and Deathstroke is his equal in combat. So hell if I know what Penguin reflects. Perhaps it’s Batman’s insecurities or perhaps I’m just trying to make this segment longer. I should remember to cross out the last sentence later.\nThere are two things to do in Gotham city; king-hit pedestrians and label them as thugs or collect Riddler trophies, but let’s be honest, you won’t do the latter. You can finally traverse the Batcave; a privilege I never collected upon because there was nothing in the Batcave with the exception of clutter. Maybe there was a secret, but bugger if I could be bothered to find it. I now see this series taking the Halo methodology in the sense that the developers said Origins was going to be the final game, but now the Arkham series has been taken back by Warner Bros. who have already announced the next game. So I guess I’ll see you back here when that bolt from the blue arrives. And for the record, this game has the twisted oddity of not having Nolan North voice acting a superhero/villain.

reviewText:
This was a big dissapointment unfortunately.
Arkham Asylum and City were both epic games that were both strong on story and on character. Here all of those elements are stripped away and you're left with the bare bones fighting parts of the game without much purpose.

The story is so thin. A bounty has been put out on Batman. Rather than just sit in his cave or spend the night as Bruce Wayne, he heads out into the city for everyone to take pot shots at him. This story is set back when Batman had only just begun apparently. This idea had real potential as we saw in the recent Batman movies but other than a brief mention of it at the beginning there's very little attention paid to this element in the game. And he has the Batwing! Which he never had in the earlier games... so he starts out his career with a freaking jet that he somehow looses later on? Comon!!
All the gadgets from the earlier games are also present which doesn't make any sense chronologically either.
I've no idea where the Origins element came from but I get the feeling its just a marketing ploy.

After ten mins of playing the game you realise you've been here before. City didn't feel like it was just more of the same. It expanded on both the gameplay and story of Asylum's more focussed efforts. This really feels like a mission pack.

i would only recommend this to the most die hard fans who won't mind that there's nothing new here.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Do not get your hopes up, if you buy this game. Also do not be fooled.
It may have the word Arkham in the title.
But it is far from the other great games, in the somewhat recent series.
Even with it on sale at 17.99. It's still a risky gamble, to buy this game, as you probably won't like it.
However at least it's pretty low risk, and makes some degree of sense at under 20.00 dollars.

However, I'm not convinced it's worth it at full price, even slashed a bit at 29.99.
The game is filled with bugs, and it plays like, wearing your pants on head RE RE.
If the other two games had a younger brother, who fell down a flight of stairs, making him mentally slow and he developed a drinking problem.
It would be this game.
I say it's a easy pass and it's best to wait for the next one, after looking through professional and player reviews.

This game is all but broken.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Don't make my mistake. Don't buy Origins. The battle with Deathstroke is a glorified qte (I mean come on! This is Deathstoke we're talking about), the controls are unresponsive and sluggish (I played with an Xbox one controller, the official pc drivers let it act the same as a 360 controller), the game is glitchy (with npc's often clipping into the ground being a particularly annoying problem for me), and you can't even use the costume dlc until you finish the stinkin' game. This game is such a letdown. I have been told Arkham City is much better by my bro who recently finished it. So consider spending your money there if you want a GOOD Batman game.

reviewText: Profoundly frustrating experience.  They took something that was near perfect and made it passable.  There are so many annoying little bugs everywhere, the story is forgettable, and the collectibles aren't even hard.  That being said, I still played almost 100% of the content, excluding New Game + and other harder difficulties.  I can only imagine that those modes simply make a frustrating game into a near-impossible one.  Everyone knows these were crumbs Warner Bros. fed us to keep our mouths watering for Arkham Knight.  I'm ashamed to say they did their job very well.

reviewText: An ok ish prequel. Stuffed full of bugs. One thing i hated about it was the increased number of cutscenes compared to previous games in the series. That and the fact that, even though the game its self runs fine for the most part, there are glitches (battling with killer crock, he dissapears and reappears with depressing frequecy) or the fact that cutscenes are jerky and out of synch. I am going to give this a big fat dont touch. Buy the first two by all means. They are good little games, which will take an average gamer about 12-15 hours to complete the story of, then a further 5 hours to complete the puzzles. The challenges are a nice touch i suppose.\n\nLong story short, it was probably great on console, but on steam it sucks prong.

reviewText: This game was pretty cool, about an 6.5 out of 10.  The game play was very similar to Batman Arkham City.  It pretty much consisted of the same main missions and side missions as Arkham City except with different bad Superheros.  Gadgets pretty much performed the same  actions as the ones in Arkham City except these new" ones had different names and minor tweaks (i.e. new glue gernade instead of the old ice gernade.)  The old Riddler Trophies are now Enigma data packs but they involve almost identical puzzles as to Arkham City.  I could go on about this forever but you pretty much get the point.\n\nHowever
date: if you are able to play the game on the ultra settings
recommended: it is a sight to behold.  I played Arkham City on PS3 but my visual expierence on my new self built computer was a lot better.  The character and city textures and shadows are amazing.  I couldn't believe how the snow on top of buildies realistically reacted to enemies and my footprints when sneeking and fighting.  Knocked down enemies leave body shaped dents in fresh snow cover and each foot print looks like real as if someone was walking through 4-6 inches of snow.  When inside buildings
hoursPlayed: debris and trash reacts realistically to the enemies that walk through it like ive never seen in a video game.  The texture details really made the game a more enjoyable than the similar one I played on the consul.\n\nHowever

I then decided to play it on the computer i just built (Intel I5-4430 Quad core

reviewText: This installment is definately half-baked and underdone. While the first two game were quite silly, they were still fun.This one doesn't feel fun, the side-quests quests feel more like chores and the main quests are uninspired and repetitions of the earlier games that add very little to the series. Graphically the game feels like it was made BEFORE the others. The levels lack detail and look primitive. A very big step backwards from CITY which had amazimg detail and still looks great. Origins feels like I'm playing a fan-made mod for CITY. The game is BUGGY and glitchy. Stupid little bugs that didn't exist in any of the previous games. Batman sometimes has real trouble figuring out if he's gliding or falling and other times whether he's grabbing a ledge or falling past it. So even the engine is a step backwards. Lastly the storyline....this game does not feel like an origin" story. I think whoever decide to go with "origin" was not connected to the rest of the development team. Batman is already well kitted out at the start of the game and there is little-to-no development into how he becomes later Batman. Character-wise and technology-wise he already is (Grapnel-Boost?). It seems the "origin" aspect was just a clumsy way to bring back characters that had already died in the previous games.\n\nDISCLAIMER: I haven't finished the game
date: but the way it going I don't know if I will."

reviewText:
First and foremost, this is decidedly not the first two.  Don't expect an improvement on City here, save perhaps the multiplayer.  That in mind, as a game on its own... It's not at all bad.

Pros:

It's a Batman game at heart:  There's a story that draws you in, combat is seamless, and there's an insanely good cast of villains and side characters alike.  The setting creates a good amount of immersion.
Gameplay here is great.  You swing, glide, and parkour through Gotham, again making every little journey fun, and not the least bit boring.  Combat's a mixed bag, with bosses not altogether unique, but each different arrangement and setting of goons you encounter make these battles the star of the game.  Gadgets are improved upon, and the new electrical gloves are fun as ****.
Multiplayer.  So many people knock this off, due to mechanical issues, but I easily enjoyed this part of the game more than the campaign, even.  With possibly the best and most mature online community out there, a brilliant concept for battle, with three teams facing off, and a nicely balanced armory that still feels customized depending on your gang, I easily looked over the glitches and connection instability to pour 30+ hours into this mode alone.
While the sound pales in comparison to Mark Hamill and city, the music and voice acting is extremely good.  You'll leave the game still feeling like Batman, the theme in your ears.Cons:
Well, it's very glitchy.  Some enemies sink into stairs, and a good deal of goons seem to be entirely blind.  The brick-throwing is completely broken, but hilarious.  (ran this on a 660, btw)  Few of the glitches I encountered are game-breaking, but it's very jarring to be this into a game, and suddenly see five goons walking into a wall simultaneously.  I spent much of the story bending over in laughter, and another good portion wrinkling my brow in frustration.  The latter came mainly when gliding, due to the.. err.. flapping error.  Basically, Batman has a sky seizure every three times you try to fly somewhere.  This happens often in multiplayer too, and is an even bigger annoyance there, as stealth is quickly ruined by wildly flapping wings far too often.
Multiplayer has some terrible key bindings that you can't change... The same button is used for silent takedowns and vision scrambling, which blurs your victim's screen, letting them know you're right behind them.  As you can guess, this is beyond frustrating, given that only a few inches determines which of these is triggered by your click.
The story and script are a little more ham-fisted than city or asylum, and there are a few groaner lines.
The map introduces fast travel... something no one asked for in these incredibly fun to traverse games, and expects the player to use them all the time.  This, for me, ruined much of the open-world feel I loved in the first games.
This is a prequel, meaning chronological synchroniation with the other two is key... This is perfect in all cases save one:  remember the prototype" grappler you get in city?  Yeah

reviewText:
I was scared they would ♥♥♥♥ it up. Rocksteady didn't work on this, the developer of the previous two Arkham titles, so I was afraid they'd mess up the formula or it would just flat out be a cash in with no effort. I was wrong.

While the boss fights don't match up to the awesome of some of the Arkham City ones(Mr. Freeze in particular), they are without a doubt all animated beautifully. The fight with Deathstroke was fun as hell and looked flat out awesome considering how much of a slugfest it was. You both just go back and forth with counters and attacks, with Deathstroke going through his entire arsenal of weaponry. It's ♥♥♥♥ing badass. Tons of side questions/missions, superb voice acting(Troy Baker blows me away with his Joker. He seriously captured Mark Hamill's voice well), and loads of little small improvements/additions to already excellently executed combat mechanics. Some new animations, some old ones smoothed out, and new enemies to fight: Martial Artists hit you with combo attacks requiring either precise counters one after the other, or multiple counters in one of their attacks. It's cool.

I was also fearful of the MP portion being tacked on, and while it kind of is, it isn't too bad. Very fun, I can definitely see an increased enjoyment if you were to play with buddies.

It's no Arkham City, but it's definitely better than Asylum for sure when weighing them all together.

reviewText:
Introduction :  The game, played from a third-person perspective, focuses on Batman's combat and stealth abilities, detective skills, and gadgets for combat and exploration. Aside from the main story, Batman can help the police deal with crimes, and confront other supervillains terrorizing the city. Arkham Origins introduces the ability for Batman to virtually recreate crimes, allowing him to investigate the scene and identify the culprit. The game is the first in the series with multiplayer capability.


(+)Graphics : Graphics have been improved comparing to Arkham City . The game looks even more realistic now .

(+)Music :  The melodies don't try to go too far and are consistently coated in adrenaline-pumping elements. You're gonna love it .

(+)Cutscenes :  Absolutely FANTASTIC. Can't really tell much witout spoiling everything but cutscenes just wants to make you play more and more !

(+)Story :  Arkham origins' main storyline is set five years before that of 2009's Batman: Arkham Asylum and follows a younger, less-refined Batman. So you have the oppurtunity to witness Batman become a legend from a simple .. rumour .

(+)Content :  The content is wide and full of possibilities . You can either keep on following the main storyline , or go after the most wanted targets , glide around the city and help cops in need , or you can just simply run around and deal with the Riddler's crazy puzzles .

(-)PVP :  Completely unnecessary . When i first heard about Origins multiplayer option i was very excited , but after actually having a chance to test it out myself i found out that it's nothing like the Singleplayer . In singleplayer you can bash in through your enemies and knock them out witout breaking a sweat . But in multiplayer , batman fights like he is drunk . Not recommended if you're buying for the multiplayer .

(+)Gameplay :  The gameplay is pretty much like any other Arkham games . Same tools , same counter design , a bunch of different takedowns , but still not boring .


My opinion on this game is that it's definitely worth every dollar . If you liked the other Arkham games you'll probably get hooked up on this too .

8/10 -   Triskelion Turbella Reviews

reviewText:
I don’t understand how this game received a 7.8 on IGN. This isn’t necessarily bad, however, Call of Doge received a score of 8.8, which irritates me endlessly.
This isn’t the best of the series, but it still is a lot of fun. The plot is a major improvement to Arkham City’s and the cinematic cut scenes are excellent. I’m not sure why people are upset about The Joker being the main antagonist. This is a PREQUEL! Of course he’s going to be the main baddy because this is technically the first time we are introduced to him! This doesn’t take place right after city, folks; this is before Asylum and the plot clearly indicates that.
The free-flow combat is still beautiful, but could have been improved more such as adding more combat moves. IGN deducted points because there’s ‘too many win buttons’, someone please explain that to me. WHY is that a bad thing?
The environment of this game is okay, but is not as lively as City; of course because of the thick snow. IGN also says there isn’t enough Easter Eggs… I’m not sure what game they played. Enigma has his challenges all over the map. IGN also said the city was ‘lifeless’. Again, not sure what game the played. You run into crimes in progresses and baddies roam around the streets.

IGN was completely unfair reviewing this game. They complain about it not having many changes compared to it predecessor, but YET they gave CoD of Doge an 8.8… Clearly IGN is being paid off here, either that or they got someone who is a big CoD fan to review the game. At least the community votes reveal the truth, as the community gave Origins an 8.9 and CoD of Doge a 3.2.

reviewText:
WB Games Montreal did many things well and can be compared to Rocksteady Studio's Arkham games.
The story is equally thrilling, the game has a great usage of characters (with the exception of Deathstroke, whose potential wasn't fully used) and has the same gameplay with little additions (like a bigger map), though without innovation. Music and voice actors are still awesome; Troy Baker successfully follows in Mark Hamill's steps.
The character models are even better than in the previous games (I needed to get used to Joker though.) and you get an average multiplayer mode that is enjoyable for some time.

There is only one reason why I can't recommend the game, though. It is buggy as hell. The worst bug is a problem many gamers had with this game: At the finale the game stops recognizing the input from your mouse and keyboard. So if you want to beat the game you need to use a controller. And if you don't have one: tough luck. The bug is known and yet they said they will prioritize on putting out a DLC instead of fixing it at the current time.

reviewText:
Let's be honest: Prequels suck. While yes, it is pretty much Arkham City Remastered, it has next to nothing new to offer. Why is that? Firstly, this game was developed not by Rocksteady (who made the first 2 games)  but by eidos Montreal. Let's start with the setting: It takes place in the Christmas-crazed  part of Gotham City that later will be made into Arkham City.

And while Arkham City had a very dark, intense atmosphere, the first negative point in Origins is obvious: It's a prequel, which means it doesnt continue the story of Arkham City (that I'm not going to spoil for you, but let me tell you that everybody was like OMG). Also, 50% of Arkham Origins' world is Arkham City. Okay, with a few, very unnoticable changes. The graphics arent even that better. On a sidenote: Batman has pretty much all the gadgets he needed to unlock in Arkham City. But it takes place before. In Arkham Asylum, he has way less gadgets than that. But it's never explained!

The story of Origins goes like this: A new, unknown villain appears in Gotham, he murders Black Mask (the former crime boss) and takes over. Batman has to find out who that is, while 8 different bountyhunters are hired to kill him. Beating up bad guys works exactly like in Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, which isnt a bad thing, because the freeflowing is, in my opinion, the best fighting system for an action-adventure there is. The stealth missions are also well made, but seriously they are the same youll find in the previous games. Arkham Origins is definitly not a bad game, its pretty good actually, but it simply isnt a worthy successor to Arkham City. So I can't really not recommend it, because its not a bad game, But not better than the second one in the Batman: Arkham-Franchise. Buy this if you already played the first 2 games, dont buy it if youre just starting to get into the series (in that case, just go with Arkham City).

reviewText:
Before I provide my opinion, please do remember this is all respective of my own experience, as I do not think anyone else will have the exact experience I did. As for the purchase, got this for $10 off of humble bundle and bought the dlcs through steam.

I do not suggest this game due to several issues and qualms I had right off the bat (no pun intended), and after a few hours, I stand by my suggestion. The game is poorly ported over, as several major aspects of PC play are completely disregarded and difficult. I personally play on a wide screen monitor, so the fact this game has no ingame FOV or graphical setting to adjust quality to my choosing is deplorable. Furthermore, if you have dual or more monitors running, the game essentially overrides any resolution on these extra monitors despite resolution limitation (i.e. the rest of your screens will be blacked out, kind of pointless dont you think?). The initial graphical settings just consist of Normal and High, not much customization there. Additionally, for those playing on high res monitors, mouse smoothing and the sensitivity options make it extrememly difficult to play as you must manually adjust them through the ini files. This comes to my next problem, as adjusting any of these ini files shoot up the ctd and glitch frequencies beyond the normal buggy gameplay.

Of course, I have played the previous games as well, and can shed light on the experience to the plot and mechanics. The mechanics have relatively stayed the same, but imo, have been simplified right off the bat. The executions are far more limited than in previous games and I think the responsiveness of the movement suffers as a result of the above optimization issues. That being said, its pretty much the same thing as the previous game. Some new gadgets and detective methods have been added, but the balancing efforts disrupted much of the combat. I still say play the first two over this one as they were much better imo.

With the lack of optimization and subpar experience, save yourself the trouble and dont buy this, but if you must persist, get it during a sale. The skins are unavailable during the initial playthrough which is again a bummer as most of the dlc consists of skin packs, and replay is not an experience I wished to partake in. My advice for dlc's, get the campaign addons, avoid the season pass, you'll save cash.

reviewText:
Batman Arkham Origins is the third installment of the Batman Arkham series and the pre-quel story of Batman Arkham Asylum, and was developed by a different team than the first two games. Although I must say that Batman AO is inferior compared to its predecessors gameplay-wise but still pretty good story-wise. I recommend you to play Batman AO if you are a fan of the Batman Arkham series, and I FULLY recommend you to get the Cold - Cold Heart DLC since its got a really good and interesting story, as well as the bad*** new suit  THE XE SUIT ,

TL,DR; I still quite enjoyed playing Batman AO, but I don't feel the solid gameplay that I got when I played the previous installments.

Pros:
+ GOOD gameplay, but somehow I felt that AO has an awkward feel and controls compared to its predecessor.
+ GOOD story.
+ GOOD fighting system. Free Flow Combat with this new feature ( Shock Gloves ) is a huge fun.
+ GOOD array of gadgets, allowing you to takedown enemies with your own style.
+ GOOD sound.
+ GOOD atmosphere.
+ GOOD graphics, better than the previous games.
+ GREAT characters and voice acting, the characters really felt like they are coming right out of the comics.
+ Detective Mode Case Reconstruction is a fun new feature, but could be done better.
+ Dark Knight System is a good addition as well, but is implemented poorly, especially the Predator System.
+ Batwing drop system, allowing us to Fast Travel to certain points in Gotham City.

Cons:
- The controls feel a bit awkward and clunky.
- Most areas are just copied from Batman Arkham City maps.
- More collectibles, but less Riddles.
- Gotham City is a huge city, but the lack of any civilians feels weird to me. All I see are thugs. Is this Gotham City? or Arkham City, where all its inhabitants are criminals?
- Dark Knight System Challenges should be able to be done in ANY ORDER, to avoid any missable challenge(s).
- Missable predator challenge, because some of them can only be done in certain maps of the STORY mode. This is seriously annoying, especially because this game uses autosave system. Imagine if you forgot to do a 1 predator challenge, progress through the story, autosaving and BAM you just missed the opportunity because its the only area where you can do the challenge.
- Less polished, Batman AO still has many bugs, such as:
-> gliding achievement sometimes not triggered, it takes a few tries.
-> sometimes after the Riddler Informant was interrogated, NO new collectibles are marked on the map, and then you must run around to find ANOTHER Riddler Informant.
-> sometimes predator challenges are not counted when the conditions are met, but sometimes counted when the conditions are not met. I know, I am confused as well...


Overall: 80/100

reviewText:
Alex Swaffer
Batman Arkham Origins
Review
Roman Sionis: Kill him, and I'll pay you whatever you want! Make him suffer, and I'll double it!

Well it seems it is finally time to join the cape crusader on a deep and dark adventure on the mean streets of Gotham.
Origins unlike what you may think is not an origin story at all not an origin of batman or Gotham, however it shows the story of a much more inexperienced batman, and of course a earlier Gotham, one that does not yet know of the Bat and even think of him as an urban legend the kind they don't know whether he is a demon or multiple people. Batman is much more young and reckless in this game and even way more brutal in his approach this is easy to see with the amount of brutal takedowns and interrogations where batman will usually stamp on the face of his victim and with an almighty crack it's time for bed.
This story gets you to see as batman comes face to face with many of his most advocate foes for the very first time, including the like of Deathstroke, Shiva, Bane, deadshot, and of course The Joker.
The story is based around Black Mask putting a $50 million bounty on the bats head, of which 9 infamous assassins gladly accept, this is as much of the story as I will spoil.
One gripe i had with the story was length and execution the story and characters were good however i feel the story later on was rushed and only took me around 10 hours to complete, where as city took me almost 25, there are however more side quests afterwards.
You also once again have riddles" in the form of data packs and other challenges imposed by the young Riddler himself currently going by the alias Enigma and abbreviation of Edward Nigma
date:
he shuts down the entire network and you must solve his challenges and "riddles" to functionally use your batwing for fast travel of which is needed this time around with the vast and fully expanded Gotham.
You also have to collect his data packs to stop him leaking confidential information of which could be the fall of societal Gotham.

reviewText:
I don’t understand how this game received a 7.8 on IGN. This isn’t necessarily bad, however, Call of Doge received a score of 8.8, which irritates me endlessly.
This isn’t the best of the series, but it still is a lot of fun. The plot is a major improvement to Arkham City’s and the cinematic cut scenes are excellent. I’m not sure why people are upset about The Joker being the main antagonist. This is a PREQUEL! Of course he’s going to be the main baddy because this is technically the first time we are introduced to him! This doesn’t take place right after city, folks; this is before Asylum and the plot clearly indicates that.
The free-flow combat is still beautiful, but could have been improved more such as adding more combat moves. IGN deducted points because there’s ‘too many win buttons’, someone please explain that to me. WHY is that a bad thing?
The environment of this game is okay, but is not as lively as City; of course because of the thick snow. IGN also says there isn’t enough Easter Eggs… I’m not sure what game they played. Enigma has his challenges all over the map. IGN also said the city was ‘lifeless’. Again, not sure what game the played. You run into crimes in progresses and baddies roam around the streets.

IGN was completely unfair reviewing this game. They complain about it not having many changes compared to it predecessor, but YET they gave CoD of Doge an 8.8… Clearly IGN is being paid off here, either that or they got someone who is a big CoD fan to review the game. At least the community votes reveal the truth, as the community gave Origins an 8.9 and CoD of Doge a 3.2.

reviewText:
Buy? Likely.

Is BAO more worthy of a 7.0 than a higher score as IGN review. In my honest opinion, yes. Sure, that score comes from the same people who were happy to rate arguably the most iterative popular game series, Call of Duty, with scores of 9 or higher, which doesn't make sense when their biggest argument for the score is the lack on innovation....By that standard, BAO would get a 10/10.

My score boils down to the fact that while there is still the solid, Batman Arkham series base mechanics and design, there are many minor or moderate imperfections compared to previous games.

Number one issue is the bugginess, with the infamous Lacey Tower Glitch (now fixed), interrogation glitches, geometry collisions glitches and to me, the loss of combos or the missing of attacks more than I should have compared to previous games (this could be an issue with my controller or just me).

Number two, the total lack of detail and flair compared to the previous games - there is less color variety (mostly greys, blacks, greens, and occasional blues), practically no environmental easter eggs and references (though, you can argue the fact that the villains don't have the ability to uniquly mark their territory like Arkham City because civilians and cops are still present), no interesting items to scan (except for Anarky tags), less entertaining Riddler/Enigma quest (The interesting Riddler trophies are now just boring Grey and bright green datapacks, that some how James Gordon didn't notice on his back wall with a BLARING GREEN LIGHT. The puzzles are immensely easier than BAC and argueably kind of stupid, and makes you wonder how Enigma thought Batman couldn't get them. Admittedly, Engima is perhaps less experienced/adept and hasn't became The Riddler" yet).

Number Three
date: a near complete lack of innovation and recycling of assets that makes BAO feels like a glorified DLC for Arkahm City. While it it great to see what "Arkham City" was before it was Arkham City

reviewText: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME AT FULL PRICE!!\n\nThe reason i say that is not because the campaign is bad or the multiplayer is plain and boring, it's purely due to the sheer amount of bugs and glitches that currently exist in this game. If it wasn't for the bugs that liter this game, then this game would be a full fledged complete package that would be well worth your time and money. The single player is very good overall. the graphics are great, the pc port is managable, the game mechanics without a rebind of keys is reasonably good and can be used easily when put in comparison to a controller. the multiplayer admittedly being rather sparse in terms of it's game modes and amount of maps, is fun, enjoyable and can get very tense especially in the hunter, hunted game mode which plays like search and destroy in call of duty in the sense that you have one lifeand one only, die and thats it, very emersive indeed. But the bugs in this game seriously hamper the amount of enjoyment you will be able to extract out of this title. in addition to the bugs, the developers of this title have no current plans to fix and improve the game which is bad and near insulting to hardcore batman fans and fans of the previous arkham titles. therefore i cannot recommend buying this game to anyone unless you are willing to encounter and ignore the near game breaking bugs that currently exist in the game then by all means play and enjoy but for the rest of us, i suggest staying away from this game.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is the third installment in the Batman: Arkham series of video games; it serves as a prequel to both Arkham Asylum and Arkham City and provides an insight into the early days of Batman's career. This is the first game in the series I have played extensively, despite owning the other two titles.
This game follows Batman/Bruce Wayne on Christmas Eve in Gotham City; the villain Black Mask places a significant bounty on your head, meaning the best and brightest villains flock to Gotham on Christmas Eve to take down Batman. I thought this was a great way to provide diversity in the villains you'll encounter, each with their own characteristics and different fighting styles; Bane, Copperhead, the Joker, Deadshot, Mad Hatter, Deathstroke, Electrocutioner and the Penguin are all villains that Batman will encounter in one way or another. The voice acting and motion capture of these characters is absolutely brilliant, and it was very enjoyable to face off against them.
This game is a sprawling open world brawler; Batman has a number of tools and gadgets to navigate the vast environments such as grappling hooks, glue grenades, smoke grenades and batarangs, all of which come in useful in a variety of ways. You can glide across the cityscape uninterrupted; this is one of the best features of the game, as the player is allowed to navigate the world as you choose without limitation.
Gameplay in Arkham Origins consists of engaging in fist fights with goons, sneaking around areas, solving puzzles and gliding around Gotham. Like previous entries in the series, Arkham Origins uses the freeflow combat system; as Batman, you can fly around a punch up whilst delivering hits and countering attacks. Different enemies require different fighting styles and techniques, and the enemy diversity as well as the range of tools means the fights are always entertaining and challenging. The stealth sections are equally entertaining, as you can use your tools and the environment to eliminate enemies undetected. You'll also come across challenging puzzles within the game, such as bypassing traps and blocked areas as well as solving puzzles left by Enigma.
Video and sound design in this game is also very good. Excellent attention to detail in combination with a highly appealing graphics engine, this game looks absolutely stunning on high settings. Voice acting and sound design is also fantastic, and feels like a highly authentic Batman experience.
This game was very enjoyable due to its highly polished gameplay and compelling story. Without spoilers, the scenes concerning the Joker and his early meetings with Batman provide a unique take on the story that I found extremely interesting and riveting for the game. If you enjoy action packed brawlers in an open world setting, I highly recommend this game. Loads of replay value and excellent value for money, Batman: Arkham Origins is an epic game for fans of Batman and action games in general. 9 / 10
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't understand why this game has some negative reviews. Most agree that this is the weakest entry in the Arkham series so far, but I don't see it. I have really enjoyed my time with Arkham Origins. The story is great and the voice acting is even better. It really puts the events in Arkham City into perspective. I will be replaying that one next just because of this game lol.

If you are a Batman fan, there is no excuse not to pick this up! It has challenging bosses, fun stealth missions, and a story with all kinds of fun twist and turns! The game is not perfect though. I have encountered a crashing issue every so often. It's annoying but by no means harms the game as a whole. I recommend picking this up if you are looking for an exciting adventure with a story that will suck you in! Enjoy =)

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is the third installment in the Batman: Arkham series of video games; it serves as a prequel to both Arkham Asylum and Arkham City and provides an insight into the early days of Batman's career. This is the first game in the series I have played extensively, despite owning the other two titles.
This game follows Batman/Bruce Wayne on Christmas Eve in Gotham City; the villain Black Mask places a significant bounty on your head, meaning the best and brightest villains flock to Gotham on Christmas Eve to take down Batman. I thought this was a great way to provide diversity in the villains you'll encounter, each with their own characteristics and different fighting styles; Bane, Copperhead, the Joker, Deadshot, Mad Hatter, Deathstroke, Electrocutioner and the Penguin are all villains that Batman will encounter in one way or another. The voice acting and motion capture of these characters is absolutely brilliant, and it was very enjoyable to face off against them.
This game is a sprawling open world brawler; Batman has a number of tools and gadgets to navigate the vast environments such as grappling hooks, glue grenades, smoke grenades and batarangs, all of which come in useful in a variety of ways. You can glide across the cityscape uninterrupted; this is one of the best features of the game, as the player is allowed to navigate the world as you choose without limitation.
Gameplay in Arkham Origins consists of engaging in fist fights with goons, sneaking around areas, solving puzzles and gliding around Gotham. Like previous entries in the series, Arkham Origins uses the freeflow combat system; as Batman, you can fly around a punch up whilst delivering hits and countering attacks. Different enemies require different fighting styles and techniques, and the enemy diversity as well as the range of tools means the fights are always entertaining and challenging. The stealth sections are equally entertaining, as you can use your tools and the environment to eliminate enemies undetected. You'll also come across challenging puzzles within the game, such as bypassing traps and blocked areas as well as solving puzzles left by Enigma.
Video and sound design in this game is also very good. Excellent attention to detail in combination with a highly appealing graphics engine, this game looks absolutely stunning on high settings. Voice acting and sound design is also fantastic, and feels like a highly authentic Batman experience.
This game was very enjoyable due to its highly polished gameplay and compelling story. Without spoilers, the scenes concerning the Joker and his early meetings with Batman provide a unique take on the story that I found extremely interesting and riveting for the game. If you enjoy action packed brawlers in an open world setting, I highly recommend this game. Loads of replay value and excellent value for money, Batman: Arkham Origins is an epic game for fans of Batman and action games in general. 9 / 10

reviewText:
I don't understand why this game has some negative reviews. Most agree that this is the weakest entry in the Arkham series so far, but I don't see it. I have really enjoyed my time with Arkham Origins. The story is great and the voice acting is even better. It really puts the events in Arkham City into perspective. I will be replaying that one next just because of this game lol.

If you are a Batman fan, there is no excuse not to pick this up! It has challenging bosses, fun stealth missions, and a story with all kinds of fun twist and turns! The game is not perfect though. I have encountered a crashing issue every so often. It's annoying but by no means harms the game as a whole. I recommend picking this up if you are looking for an exciting adventure with a story that will suck you in! Enjoy =)

reviewText:
I'm a massive Batman fan. I know a lot of people claim that, but I challenge anyone to find a Batfan as big as me. I loved Asylum and City, and when I saw Origins was being delivered by a different studio, I swore never to play it.

And then it went on sale.

Figuring 'hey, what's ten bucks?', I bought it. I now have no idea what people are/were complaining about. Yes, there are some shortcomings when compared to the previous games, but that comes with any franchise. I mean, what if nobody played another Zelda game after Ocarina of Time? People talked crap about Windwaker, but it's one of my favourite games.

Arkham Origins is a superb game. It's Batman all over. Does it hold up to its preceeding titles? Not 100%. But you can't let two near perfect games ruin a wonderful one. Is it worth $50? That's up to you. But if it goes on sale again, I thoroughly recommend picking it up. As long as you go in with an open mind you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME AT FULL PRICE!!\n\nThe reason i say that is not because the campaign is bad or the multiplayer is plain and boring, it's purely due to the sheer amount of bugs and glitches that currently exist in this game. If it wasn't for the bugs that liter this game, then this game would be a full fledged complete package that would be well worth your time and money. The single player is very good overall. the graphics are great, the pc port is managable, the game mechanics without a rebind of keys is reasonably good and can be used easily when put in comparison to a controller. the multiplayer admittedly being rather sparse in terms of it's game modes and amount of maps, is fun, enjoyable and can get very tense especially in the hunter, hunted game mode which plays like search and destroy in call of duty in the sense that you have one lifeand one only, die and thats it, very emersive indeed. But the bugs in this game seriously hamper the amount of enjoyment you will be able to extract out of this title. in addition to the bugs, the developers of this title have no current plans to fix and improve the game which is bad and near insulting to hardcore batman fans and fans of the previous arkham titles. therefore i cannot recommend buying this game to anyone unless you are willing to encounter and ignore the near game breaking bugs that currently exist in the game then by all means play and enjoy but for the rest of us, i suggest staying away from this game.

reviewText:
The third installment of the Batman franchise is imo the best and most refined. But is that enough to warrant a recommendation in late 2014, when it really only is an incremental improvement on the five year old  first game?

I think it is, but it really depends on whether you own one or both of the other titles, and how much you liked them.

There are some new gadgets, enemies, moves, refined crime scene mode with timeline control and much more.

The villian roster unfortunately still has the main focus on the same old characters.

As usual there's a ton of things to do besides the main story, but I didn't deviate much from it, and completed the game in 15 hours.

There were a couple of bugs, which I don't remember from any of the previous games, including enemies gettings stuck out of your reach forcing you to reload a checkpoint.

If you haven't played any of previous games, and know you're only gonna buy one of them - it should be this one.

75%

reviewText:
The following is in this review-

Pros and cons of Batman Arkham Origins
Batman Arkham Origins compared to the other arkham games
What Rocksteady should do for the future

Batman Arkham Origins story takes place several years before Batman Arkham Asylum. In this game you play as the one and only Batman trying to stop yet again villians on the loose in gotham city. In paticular, you are trying to stop a crime lord named Black Mask, and the eight assassins he's hired to try and kill you for 50,000,000 dollars.

The games story overall was interesting and I have to say compared to the others, the story was just as awesome with the plot twists and all. However, if I were to compare this game to the game that came before this, (Batman Arkham City) I have to say there was really no difference what so ever. Sure, you can play as deathstroke, and sure, the story is different, and sure they're are some new villians, but besides that what was the big improvement of this game?

Batman Arkham Origins honnestly feels like if you were playing Arkham City, but you bought some dlc that took place before arkham asylum, with a different story. Combat is the same, if anyway different its gotten alot harder, although it does have a bit of a different feel to it. Same gadgets, same challenges, and not even that much bigger of a map. Now, I will say this. The boss battles/fighting with the villans has improved and generally feels great. Although the combat hasn't changed, if you do like a good challenge then its for you.

Since I haven't played arkham city in a long time, I can't really tell if this game had more or less side quests, but I have a feeling there are more, and if not, the same. The riddler challenges are little bit eaiser as your map can now locate almost every challenge in the game, other then finding them on your own, but only really do it if you want to...put hours in this game? Or perhaps if you're very fond with the riddler, and want to catch him.

The voice actor of Batman in the game sadly wasn't Kevin Conroy and instead was Roger Craig Smith. I suppose the intention of doing this was to...perhaps make the player feel it was a more younger version of Batman? The voice actor for Joker has also changed, but I never really even realised it did. The one and only Troy Baker is the voice actor for The Joker, and has done a great job. Compared to the last voice actor, they're both awesome.

Now when it comes to DLC for this game, there are some ups and downs.

Cold, Cold Heart had a decent story, and the main villians focus on the penguin and Mr. Freeze. You also get to play as Batman in his new Environmental Bat/XE Suit. Some features inculde a fire batarang, and instead of shock gloves, you have heat gloves. There is free roam, but you can only explore half of Gotham instead of the full two areas. After the story, you can do mainly three side missions. You can unfreeze all the people who have been frozen, stop anarky from once again terriozing the city, and tag anarky symbols. I'd say its worth the 10 bucks. On the other hand initiation and the skin packs didn't really feel worth buying. The skin packs are honnestly dumb, compared to city, city had amazing skins. Arkham Origins skins were as if the designers of the game minds were up there ♥♥♥ and tried to make a good costume while it was. The challenges are only worth buying if you find the game easy. I personally am just fine with easy, normal for me almost felt like ultimate towards the end of the game.

Initiation doesn't really even feel like a story, more like just a bunch of challenges in korea with Bruce without his suit. For those of you who don't know what initian is, its basically the story of how Bruce learned his ways of martial arts, knowing the way of how to fight, and overcome his fear but also to use it and fear others. That is what it was suppose to be, but its just a bunch of challenges as far as im concerned. Sure there is a chellenge campaign, but one cutscene for every challenge with Ras Al Ghul giving him challenge after challenge. Where is the real story here? There isn't, and its also pretty challenging. I would reccomend though beating the game first before you try it. If you want to play a game that shows Bruce actully before he became Batman, either play Batman Begins for ps2 (great game), or watch the movie. (Movie is pretty good. 9/10)

Mods in this game are pretty fun, as they're mods where you can be Deathstroke, Anarky, Joker and some other villians and roam the city. Only do this if you've beaten the game though. There are some costume mods, but I could only find ones that are the suits from the batman movies. Other then that, there isn't really anything else big for mods.


Overall, I have to say, the origins of Batman put into a game is good if you do it right. It honestly just feels like arkham city though, and there wasn't really a big difference compared to city. Only really get this game if you want a good Batman story or to play as deathstroke. Besides that, there really isn't a point getting the game.


As for the future for Rocksteady with their new Batman game, Batman Arkham Knight, I will say this.

Now I am the type of person to expect a game to be good, but also to be expected unsurpirsingly bad. But, I will say this. Batman Arkham Knight looks honnestly, amazing. The gameplay shows promise, the graphics look great, batman himself looks awesome, and you get to drive the godamm batmobile. I am also excited to see the arkham knight into action and know the story of who he is and all that. Although the trailers for most games are half truth half bull, I have faith the game will still be pretty great. And compared to the other arkham games, this looks likes a whole new generation of Batman and I have some faith Rocksteady can make an even better Batman game in the future with the next gen consoles.

As for Arkham Origins -

8.5/10

reviewText:
This review can be wrapped up in a single sentence.

Not as bad as many people will say, but not good enough to carry the Arkham series name.

This game is utterly passable. The controls, looks and overall execution are just fine (as they should be, since it's primarily just borrowed from the previous titles), but the scale of the game falls significantly short of Arkham City.

I don't think purists will be the only people irritated by the anacronystic, and fairly schizophrenic, way that this origins Batman has advanced, and regressed, from his Arkham predecessors... wait... successors... well, you see my point.

Anyway, overall, not actually a bad game, but when compared to the excellent games from which it was spawned, you must wonder if it's existance was necessary as it seems to do nothing to advance the franchise.

That said, if cheap enough, and you just want more Arkham, pick up this game... just set those expectations down a level or two, and you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
This game is terribly underrated.
For the past few months I've been struggling with whether or not to get the game and play it, since all I've heard was harsh criticism. I got through the game and I can't understand WHY this game got 74/100 on steam. It has everything we could have asked for! Story is remarkable and I don't see absolutely anything wrong with it. In fact, I would say some parts are even better and more mind blowing than in Arkham City. This is so far the darkest and most interesting Batmans IMO, since it tells us so many stories that shine the light on things some players were wondering about (those who didn't read the comics, of course). Glitches? Bugs? They happen! Throughout the game I had some here and there, but they didn't even frustrate me to the point where I would even bring it up if others didn't. I absolutely love this game.

The only bad side is the graphics. It looks downgraded compare to Arkham City.

My personal rating for this game is 9.5/10

reviewText: I AM BATMAN
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Another great entry to a great series. Batman: Arkham Origins deserves none of the hate it gets from fans of the Batman games. I'll tell you one thing, though, WB did not innovate too much on the gameplay from the previous Arkham games. But, I ask you a question: is this really a bad thing? WB was wise to do this instead of taking the risk to change the game in a series that doesn't belong to them. So, what we get is another Batman game that lets us explore Gotham City once again and relive the beginning of the Dark Knight. The story, by the way, is a great excuse to throw in some SICK boss battles. The boss battles are each so different and challenging, I'll tell ya. And while I hear this game has major bugs at launch, all seem to be entirely fixed at this point in time, more than a year after launch. Speaking of fixes, this PC port is AMAZING! It runs beautifully, all settings maxed out, getting 40 fps (which is good enough for me for a 3rd person game) on my GT755M, a laptop graphics card, mind you. And with all of the nvidia-specific features, you'll be happy you're a PC gamer. And going back to the game content itself, Batman: Arkham Origins has the usual massive amount of side quests and things to do outside of story missions. Now, I've, for the most part, only played the story missions, but I plan on going back soon enough to do more side quests. One string of side quests I saw a bit of on youtube has you finding the Most Wanted Criminals of Gotham, letting you fight more boss battles, and ultimately squeezing as much as you can out of this worthy entry. While Origins doesn't add too much to the gameplay aspect (which is already simply perfect), there is no reason you shouldn't pass up the chance to enjoy it again in addition to a surpringly good story.\n\n9/10--Origins is a game which follows the rule: If it ain't broke
date: don't fix it".... and I appreciate that."

I waited until this had been patched and tweaked quite a bit before picking it up, especially after seeing early impressions of it. reviewText:
Pros:

- Beautifully rendered Gotham at Christmas time
- Wide assortment of enemy types makes for a constant challenge
- fun grappling and gliding mechanics
- decent story length and fun challenge maps

Cons:

- Weak antagonists
- sloppy combat compared to earlier titles
- Where is Kevin Conroy?
- Where is Mark Hamill?
- The game lacks the fantastic world building from Asylum and City, where you could learn more about the Batman Universe through notes and biographies.

Overall I'd say pick it up on the cheap if you're a Batman fan.

reviewText:
I would really like to say that I enjoyed this game.  I want to say that I enjoyed the combat system, the exploration, the visuals, maybe even the story line.  I want to say that I <was> looking forward to DLC.  I did purchase a season pass after all.

But now, I am going through major buyer's remorse after the unethical business practice, that is literally refusing to fix the game any further, and instead focus on the story DLC coming out.

Well, unless I can get a refund, I am in it for the long run, so I may as well find out.  And if you haven't bought the DLC already, DON'T.  If you haven't bought the game yet, DON'T!  Just read this article: http://www.gamespot.com/articles/batman-arkham-origins-has-no-plans-to-fix-several-game-breaking-bugs/1100-6417619/

And I want you to tell me if you'd still want to buy the game otherwise.

I loved this game.  But now, I wish I could break it into dust and blow it into the developers eyes in annoyance just for them to understand how we fans feel when this news came to light.
