reviewText:
7.5/10.

While it may not be as polished as the first 2 games, and it does have it share of bugs and glitches, Origins is a great pre-quel to Arkham Asylum. Plenty of DC villains, some I've never even heard of before, and the main story is a pretty wild ride.

reviewText:
Main game: fun, but too many ideas borrowed from Arkham City.  The final boss fight is literally a rehash of the ingenius Mr. Freeze fight from B:AC.  The story is decent & Troy Baker's performance as the Joker is excellent.  Bane is closer to Nolan's version of an intelligent villain rather than the cartoon versions of a stupid brute, so that's good.

I loved Arkham City & while I'd say this game was fun, I understand that they had no original ideas and used Arkham City to tell another Batman story.

Final verdict: 7.5/10

DLC: How long was it Angry Joe?  3.5-4 hours, including getting all of the achievements.  The story was okay.  Where as the main story had an original take on the Joker and other's origin stories, this was Mr. Freeze's origin story and was pretty much an exact retelling without much deviation from other versions.  At least it felt somewhat different with the new ice moves and stuff, but that's not really enough to recommend at anything over $2.  Oh, and the other DLC in the season pass was some garbage challenge maps and different suits for Batman which you can only use once you've beaten the main game and go for new game plus or plus plus (aka: I Am The Night mode).

Final verdict there: 6/10 and don't get the season pass

reviewText:
Short Review:
The Good: The Main Story is more gripping and intense than Batman Arkham City. But not much better than Arkham Asylum. The Costume is more realistic giving it that Nolan esque feel to the series. Bane is one of the highlights of the series.

The Bad: The combat was made faster which led to some problems like the enemy wouldn't give you much room to do your combo. On most fights it devolves into a counter fest. Effective use of gadgets could fix this.

The Ugly: The world looks almost the same. It's not as detailed as Batman Arkham City. The side quests are smaller in scope and some felt rehashed from the previous game. The Riddler datapacks are easier and requires less thought than B:AC.

reviewText:
Don't fix what isn't broken, one of the few cliches that still work.

I bet if people didn't know this wasn't Rocksteady studios they wouldn't even know the difference. It's like asking people to tell the difference between drinking bottled water and municipal water and then asking which one tastes better.

I'll rate this game high, I don't care. There is absolutely nothing wrong with Origins. If Arkham City were the third installment and this were the first one, then people would be making same complaints. I'll settle for the Uncharted 3 argument/syndrome but there is little to no reason to downgrade this game because it more or less features same core gameplay. And WHAT IS that same"? Refined fighting system
recommended: old and new upgrades (that you have to actually work for this time around by completing challenges)

column16: the perma-death mode

column18: the horror!\n\nThere's little to no innovation? Well
column19: for starters you can't innovate much when it comes to something that happened in the past. But there are small changes there and there. You can now slide into the grates and open them. You can daze your foes with smoke and they will swing their arms at each other and punch it each by accident. Many fights are no cakewalk. Many enemies become armed towards the middle of the game
column20: the ninjas
column21: the martial arts experts and Bane's brawlers can make fights quite tough. The environments are also more varied. There is still no blood splatter anywhere
column22: however. Many fights requires preparation in advance - disable guns
column23: check; disable gun crates check; mark the ones you want to bump together
column24: check; throw the smoke pellet in the middle of the crowd
column25:
check; swoop in and start kicking ♥♥♥.

The game is considerably longer than the other two. It took me 30 straight hours to beat it and I have only completed around 60% of the game. The game literally goes on and on.

The game is much more Tim Burton-y this time around. There are more highrise buildings so there is greater satisfaction of gliding and plunging down. The city is filled with gangs and crimes that you can prevent. The streets are wide so there is more maneuverability. There is more approach to targets. The old Arkham City area is filled with somewhat disturbing Christmas decorations. The art design is off the charts. I also like the fact that you are kind of on your own in a sense that cops and criminals don't really know what to make of you. The graphics are also somewhat expanded
column26: noticably the lens flare

column31:
psychological build up and later on skill and patience - something that Arkham City wasn't too famous for later in the game (which was one of GS's gripes by the way). The ultimate bane fight was as close to the Mr. Freeze fight as it got. The uneasy alliance with Gordon was also played out pretty well.

I can only wish this was the first installment. Arkham City was pretty much a perfect game but it doesn't preclude Origins from being a great game.

reviewText:
This is one of the worst games i have ever played.
I got it for free with my NVidia GPU and i wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

The gameplay is boring, the opponents are weak (even on the hardest difficulty) and the surroundings are lifeless, dull and repetetive. You can win almost any (non-boss-)fight by clicking the right mouse button. And if it gets too hard just use the batclaw and jump to a random ledge nearby.

The only thing I enjoyed in this game is throwing batarangs on insanely stupid opponents. You can basically sit on a ledge right above them and throw stuff at their faces and they don't even notice. This has to be one of the worst AIs I have ever encountered. Also they don't take damage and can't fall of their platforms. There are invisible walls. In a game from 2013. That normally costs 50€. Wow.

I have no idea how there are that many positive reviews for this piece of crappy software. Please enlighten me if you can.

reviewText:
Topping Arkham City would be hard to do, but they have succeeded. Arkham Origins is a masterpiece. The new voice actors were spot on, and they kept the game play the way we all came to love and enjoy. The story was fantastic, it was beyond flawless. Making a prequel to the events in Asylum and City and mastering it is not an easy feat. It was laid out perfectly and I loved the way they portrayed each faction and the way they reacted. Perfect 10 out of 10.

Multiplayer was actually a lot of fun and definitely a great added addition to an amazing series. (After you got over the random crashes that randomly occured). I hope to see them fine tone it, if they decide to do it again. When I completed the achievements only one mode was unlocked,, however I know now they added another mode, but it would be nice to see that happen during the initial release.

Most DLC is mainly silly skins and a couple challenges(not needed for achievements), but the one DLC that is actually worth something was the Cold Cold Heart DLC.
~ It adds as much as the Harley Quinn DLC in Arkham City did, and it was very well done. The story was spectacular and I enjoyed the way they developed it and how it connects all the puzzle pieces. Also the new batsuit was badass and needs to make a reappearance.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is a great, very fun, immersive, and visually stunning game! Most people prefer Asylum and City, since they were developed by Rocksteady instead of WB Montreal; while I don't necessarily prefer Origins, it didn't disappoint me either. One thing that is MUCH better about it is the visual detail and overall smoothness of gameplay. With my system (specs at the bottom) and new drivers, I play Origins in 3D Vision, rendered at 4K (using DSR), with EVERY setting maxed, except for AA being on TXAA low plenty smoothly enough for me to play very enjoyably and literally be blown away by the Nvidia Physx and rich visual detail all around! The footprints and thug impressions in the snow, the the sense I should be feeling the snowflakes hitting my face, the fun of demolishing the thugs, the joy of exploring the richly-detailed city as the Batman, along with many more great points make it great! This game has the same style and feel of the earlier games, which is AWESOME, and offers players a MUCH larger map to roam around as they wish! Great game, worth the money, and worth many hours of immersive gameplay!
Can't wait for Arkham Knight (back to Rocksteady)!

System Specs:
Case: NZXT Phantom 001BK
CPU: Intel i7 3970X
MOBO: ASUS Rampage IV Extreme x79
RAM: 32GB 1600 DDR3 4x8GB (Quad channel)
GPU: EVGA GTX 780 Classified w/ ACX cooler
Sound Card: Creative Sound Blaster Recon 3D Champion
Raid 1 for OS: 2 10,000 RPM 300GB VelociRaptors
1TB 7200RPM data drive
Monitor: Asus VG248QE 144Hz refresh, 1ms response, 80M:1 Contrast Ratio, 3D Vision support
Surround Sound: Logitech THX-certified Z-5300e

reviewText: Ah Batman Arkham Origins the game I waited for sense febuary when they gave clues for it. The game that I played right after preloading it. The game I completed 100% in less than a month after the games release. I am going to say I was in love yet also dissapointed with this game. First of all the game is very alike to arkham city with I am completely fine with. But the changes I found in the free-flow combat and predator missions were bad. With predator moving to gargoyle to gargoyle is not as smooth as the previous games and silent takedowns sort of glich out with their knockout smash's. In free-flow, the game has lost it's rythm with going from enemy to enemy. With that a side let's talk about the story. While not written by Paul Dini (the writer of asylum and city) instead it is written by Corey May and Dooma Wendschuh, which is fine because the story is great, but leads to a lot of screwed up continuity with Dini's work. Now let's talk about something new: the multiplayer. The multiplayer is created by splash damage not WB games Montreal. I found it very enjoyable to play with batman in predator maps with real players. There are two modes from the time of making this review: Invisible Predator Online and Hunter, Hunted. These are both extremely enjoyable and kept me playing. So the final verdict of this review though it is very alike to Arkham City it is still a fun Arkham game and with the addition of multiplayer I recommend this game but, with the bugs, glitches and other problems it detracts for the experience noticeably. So if you like batman and that is what you want more of, buy Arkham Origins. 8.6/10

reviewText:
I will commend this game on the premise and story. While not a particularly original plot, it is told well and at a good pace. This Batman is younger and more angry, and it was interesting seeing people react to him as a new figure in the city of Gotham. These things alone made the game worth playing. Even the item collecting seemed a bit more grounded, which made that more entertaining as well.

However, one is left with the sense that the game simply did not get enough playtesting, or not enough time to react to the results of playtesting. There are minor glitches here and there, but the most glaring oversight is in the combat.

Batman is no longer able to consistently interrupt his own attack animations. This most commonly manifests itself when trying to counter an attack that begins after you've already started attacking someone else. You'll find yourself getting hit a lot more. More difficulty is fine, but not allowing the player to respond to threats as they happen generally makes the combat feel unfair. This seemingly small change makes much of the gameplay less satisfying than in previous iterations, but is rendered moot about 2/3 into the game when you get a new upgrade that makes the combat fairly easy.

Batman Arkham Origins is not a bad game, but given its predecessors and its potential, it is a disappointing one.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
For a Batman: Arkham [something] game, this game was incredibly weak and full of bugs. It wasn't terrible, but they managed to make the most important part of the game frustrating and inconsistant: the combat. In the previous Arkham games, combat flow was silky smooth, and guiding the Batman around the fight was intuitive and consistent. In this game, that all goes away. It is incredibly hard to maintain freeflow, often at no fault of the player (Batman seems to randomly miss blocks and strikes, no matter how you are aiming the camera, and sometimes it is impossible to target the opponent you want, with it seeming like Batman is attacking everyone except the baddy you want him to take out). If these issues were consistent and predictable, it wouldn't be a big deal, but as they aren't, fighting goes from fun to frustrating in a hurry.

Going back and playing Arkham City after playing this game was like a breath of fresh air.

This game could have been a worthy addition to the Arkham games, but when it breaks the very thing that makes the Arkham games so much fun, I just can't give it a positive recommendation.

reviewText:
I really really love this game.
Before I say anything I will say there are some bugs. Nothing that has been game breaking for me but others will tell you that there are some nasty bugs and glitches.

They have done some 'tweeking' with Arkham Origins that has changed the timing of counters or critical hits. That will have you swinging at air a bit more than in AC. There have been times where I think to myself, that was cheap" but I have been playing AC lately too (I'm on a Batman junk out) and find there are things in that that also kinda irk me. I think they have done something with the flying/gliding that seem to make it more responsive or just plain easier. Either way I am better at gliding in Origins. reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is the prequel to the Arkham series, but will you want to play it ?

Batman: Arkham Origins take place in the first year of Bruce Wayne becoming Batman. On Christmas Eve Black Mask hires 8 assassins to hunt down and kill Batman for 50 million dollars. So it's up to you to capture every assassin and save Gotham.

Gameplay is almost identical to Arkham City. It adds new elements like shock gloves that speed up combat, but do less damage. Overall the combat is identical to Arkham City and if you played that you know what to expect.

Graphics are also identical to Arkham City, but unlike AC they add snow and snowing effects and add Christmas decorations to make you feel like Christmas is just around the corner. Graphics are amazing to say the least even though they are just a re-skin.

The soundtrack is awesome. When you fight some of the bosses and the music kicks in is just awesome and makes the fights even better.

The game is a bit harder than the other titles. Stealth play's a bigger role in this game and the armed enemies do more damage. But the game is still really easy.

Level design is mostly taken out of Arkham City, but there are new locations. Overall it's really well made but there is one location that has horrible design is the Gotham Police station. I got lost and confused multiple times. I would have liked for them for not make it that confusing.

Game is pretty long. It took me 17 hours to finish the main story and complete all side quests. 2 hours more to play the Cold, Cold Heart DLC. Not to mention there's also a lot you can do after you finish the game and also there are challenge maps.

The game is incredibly buggy. During a boss fight, the boss got stuck in a wall. I needed to restart for it work again. Sometimes, I couldn't interrogate people after I beat them up. The game doesn't have any game breaking bugs and restarting from a checkpoint fixes the problem.

The multiplayer mode is kind of fun but now it's full of hackers and it's kind of hard to get into a game. My suggestion is to skip all MP dlc.

Batman: Arkham Origins isn't as good as the previous titles. The game is buggy and it get's boring really fast, but it's still really fun. The boss battles are interesting and are fun as hell. The story is really interesting too. Overall if you are a fan of Arkham games this is a must own. But my suggestion is to get the game on sale only. I give Batman: Arkham Origins a 7/10

reviewText:
If you see people saying Origins is horribad, rest assured, they're wrong.

First thing first, Origins is almost copy paste of Arkham City, the 2nd installment of Arkham series. It definitely brings many good things Arkham City (and Asylum) had. Similar gadgets, similar combat styles, familiar characters (well, of course, it's Batman after all), and it's always nice to know Batman before he became established super hero. If you've played the previous two, you wouldn't feel any awkwardness playing the game.

Navigating in an open city couldn't be easier. Batman can jump from building to building, grapple with ease - much ease than on AC from my fingers' memory - and now can use 'teleport' aka fast travel with Batwing to reach other corners faster. ...well uh, after completing Tower missions against Enigma, of course.

There are also many other hidden objects and sidequests you can do like in Arkham City. Enigma Datapack, destroying poison barrels etc. The template pretty much the same like previous installment

Personal preference: I've played all three Batman installments on Steam, and I feel the smoothest combat is from this Origins.

Performance wise, so far I am having zero problem with Batman Origins set up on all low settings. On Batman Arkham City, though, I've had considerable slowdown, not because of my weak graphic card, but because it was bugged game engine - thanks to PhysX.

For the contents on Steam aka DLC, there's zero reason to get multiplayer DLCs. This game's intended to be played as SINGLE player. Why on earth would they be pushing MP contents into Batman I don't know. Just buy the SP DLCs and you're good to go, or wait until GOTY pops up. By that time, then, I think Arkham Knight will have been in existence. Game's on sale for 75% off quite often, so I would recommend to pick it up at that price.

And don't forget, this game's best played with controller. I have no issue with both Dinput (using x360ce) and Xinput gamepads.

So yeah, Arkham Origins is the game you either hate or love. It's a copy paste from previous game, and adds almost nothing except better combat and or navigation in city, perhaps. Well what can I say, don't fix what ain't broken? Isn't that the golden rule?

At any rate, this game is a must have if you're Batman fans.

reviewText:
If there will be another Batman game in the future i hope it won't be for another couple years as this felt like a rehash of everything. Like they took Arkham City's world, Asylum's animations and tacked on a crappy multiplayer and made the game buggy as hell.

The 'origins' storyline felt like a reason to add in the ever-popular Joker and many of the other assassins hardly added anything to the game other than a checklist to complete. The villain roster was decent but none really stood out like in Asylum or City.

Roger Craig Smith as Batman was ok. Too many of his lines were dry and his tone felt forced. Troy Baker's Joker is almost spot on and listening to his dialogue was one of the few immersive moments I've experienced in this title.

If you want the best Batman experience, play Asylum. It may not be as open-worldy, but the gameplay is tight and focused. I'm glad I only spent $15 on Origins.

6.8/10

reviewText:
To summarize: Awesome singleplayer, awful multiplayer.

To put into detail, Arkham Origins has continued to capitalize on the formula which made Arkham Asylum a very good game.  Aside from the occassional bugs that you might encounter the game's as solid as it can be.  It really immerses you and gives you the feeling that you're the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batman.

As for the story, no more Joker please.  I'm getting sick of it. Joker this, Joker that.  Batman has a lot  of good villains.  Please use them.

The multiplayer tells a completely different story, though.  Establishing a game is pretty difficult to do as it requires the room to be complete with 8 players before it would start.  Six players will be assigned to the Jokerz and Bane Thugs while the remaining two will be lucky enough to be the Dark Knight or the Boy Wonder.  Of course no one would want to play as a mook so that's already a minus point.  It would be better if the multiplayer is a complete hide-and-seek game featuring other characters from the Bat Family.  That way no one's going to be resentful that they end up as the bad guy.  The multiplayer rules are pretty much comparable to a WWE gimmick match where it can be confusing and unneeded.  Assassin's Creed multiplayer works as everyone can stealth and kill unlike this game's.

The next time they'll implement a multiplayer make it a predator game where 8 Bat Family members can duke it out.  We can have Batman, Robin, Red Hood II, Azrael, Batgirl, Spoiler, Owl Man, and Nightwing in an 8-player session.

Overall, the game is still a worth-buy especially during sales.  Don't let the poor multiplayer derail you from getting this game as it's still a masterpiece.

reviewText:
I enjoyed the game, but there were some issues with the port. There are no mouse settings to change in-game, the default layout for keybindings show a controller first and you have to click another button to find the keyboard, and you can't navigate the map with a mouse. The mouse settings can be changed in a notepad file so it's not that big of a deal. Not being able to control the map with a mouse is irritating as all hell though and is one of my biggest gripes about the game. Not that big of a deal, but constantly irritating.

Now, on to the good. The combat is just like Asylum and City, but with some changes such as the upgrade paths and some of the upgrades. There are actually more ways to counter all those things that were uncounterable in the last game so fighting is now more fluid. The absolute biggest improvement over the last games were the cinematics; they were god damn awesome.  The rest of the game was pretty much the same as the last games, but with a new story.

I didn't play the multiplayer and don't much care to. I bought this game for the single player campaign and the multiplayer is pretty much a quick gimmick you play and then leave.

reviewText:
As a fan of both Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, I definitely recommend Origins. However, some of the drawbacks that others have mentioned - filler content, uninspired gadgets, etc. - are true. Compared to the previous installments, Origins does seem to lack in the content that doesn't directly contribute to the overall story; they're bland and don't stand out.

That being said, I do feel like the main story is worth the reduced price that the game is selling at now. It's quite long (and plods somewhat in the middle), but it allows the player to get a look at a Batman that isn't the calm and collected Dark Knight which we're used to seeing.

8/10

reviewText: A decent follow-up to the Arkham series, with the trademark combat that we all know and love from the Arkham series. Though it pales in comparison when compared with its predecessors, it was still an enjoyable experience to play. Authough it was developed by Warner Bros. Montreal and not by Rocksteady, who had developed the previous Arkam games, the still got many things right. First of all, the story was captivating. I won't spoil too much, but it was pretty enjoyable. Secondly, the voice work for this game was amazing. Though I would always prefer the classic portrayal of Batman and Joker by Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill respectively, Roger Craig Smith and Troy Baker deliver an exceptional performance. Still, this game has its own fair share of cons. The world felt bleak and without much character, unlike Arkham city, where each segment of the world reflected of the personality of whichever mob was controlling it. Secondly, authough Warner Bros. Montreal tried new and innovative things, afew of them fell short, such as Electricutioner's gloves, which were too overpowered.\nOverall, I would give this game a 7.8 out of 10.\nGood game, but many flaws.

reviewText:
Fairly fun action/adventure game.  As the name implies, it takes place before Arkham Asylum and Arkham City.  Bruce Wayne has just gotten into the vigilante business and similar to the movie Batman Begins, the police don't trust him at first.

The story starts on Christmas Eve. A bounty has been put on Batman's head for $50,000,000.  That's really all I'm going to say about it -- I don't want to spoil anything.

Gameplay-wise, the game is open world (much like Arkham City).  I prefer this to the linear nature of Arkham Asylum, but this game is not as polished as Arkham City/Asylum were.  Certain button prompts don't always register and the first boss fight was glitchy.

Speaking of which, I really did not like the boss fights in this game.  The boss fights in Asylum and City were fairly fun and unique, but all of the boss fights involve either :
a) Dodge attacks, use your cape stun, and then go for a beatdown. You'll probably have to fight annoying cannon-fodder thugs too.
b) Avoid the boss and use grates/vents to sneak on them.  Attack them when prompted and then go back to hiding. Then use grates/vents again and repeat until they are defeated.

Despite those complaints, I think the game has a fairly good story.  I don't want to spoil anything, but there are some really great moments.

Overall, Arkham Origins is slightly weaker than Arkham City and Asylum, but still a fairly fun game.

reviewText: I loved this game, as I loved the previous two. Everyone seems to complain about bugs and glitches but I completed the game without encountering more than 2. The two which did come up cleared by itself within 10 seconds. The story in my opinion is the best out of the series because unlike the previous ones which seemed to almost be like a montage of Batman Adventures, this one shows Batman going through some growth. It feels more like a movie because the main character does not stay static like the previous ones. I love the new voice actors and it's a great re assurance that we will still have Batman and Joker in the future since Konroy and Hamill seem to be retiring soon. The boss fights are quite good, I really don't get what everyone is saying. Although the mechanics are pretty much the same as City's it feels just as satisying to clear a room as it always had. If it ain't broke don't fix it. The cutscenes are amazing and the soundtrack complements them better than City did. Graphics of course have been improved and the added part of Gotham is great to see since it contrasts the Old Gotham so much.\n\nTL;DR, Judge this game for yourself and not join the circle jerk of omg so many bugs" because there really aren't that many."

reviewText:
Batman , one of the most famous superheros finally stars in his 3rd game of the 21 century. Compelled by the previous games Warner Bros trys to live up the the expectations and level of gameplay of the previous games (Developed by Rocksteady Studios). To the user telling the diffrence in the studio change is quite simple and can be seen from the begining of the game. Compared to previous games this one is the worst in the series. The story is good but that is all that can be really said about it. The game also ranks in many bugs and sometimes can leave you puzzed for hours figuring out how you get out of a room. The single best game of all the Arkham games is the combat system. Superb! This game does not let you down there.

Would i recommend this game? Yes because this game offers a fun gameplay experience and the combat system alone is a great reason alone to play this game.

8.5/10 - Great Game but let down by Bugs""

reviewText: Overall, it's a good game.  If you liked Arkham City, and you want to play it again but you're tired of the dialogue, here's your chance.  There are one or two new tweaks to the combat system and gadgets, but from all the trailer content we definitely saw that coming.  The story's not bad, but actually I liked it more before the plot twist came in.  Dialogue was excellent, and I really liked watching characters bring up why Batman is not the right answer to every problem.\n\nThere's a lot more emphasis on boss fights in this entry, and some of them are cool!  But some of them are quite frustrating, especially since this game seems to be a bit buggier than the two before it.  This probably has something to do with the larger scale.  Since the only thing to do in this larger world is fight goons, and you will assuredly find more goons.  Combat is just about the same as Arkham City, so to me this more felt like padding the game's length than an actual improvement.

reviewText:
The Batman Arkham series originally developed by Rocksteady is to this day the best superhero/Batman video game series of all time, despite the mediocre reviews of Batman: Arkham Origins its not what those reviews say. I have played all the Batman Arkham games (first two on PS3) and I've loved them all including this one. Rocksteady handed the reigns over to WB Games Montreal to develop this one, which was a little worrying but the studio kept everything Rocksteady had started and expanded on it, it is very true to the other titles in the series.

Pros:
- THE BEST MELEE COMBAT IN ANY GAME EVER
- Very beautiful environments
- Open world that feels very true to the dark gritty Gotham a Batman fan expects to see
- Plenty of sidequests, DLC and storyline to keep you playing for hours
- Multiplayer has finally been added and is really good fun, there are a few different gamemodes that keep things interesting
- Voice acting is top
- Gadgets that make you feel like the most badass ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ out
- Batman
- It is challenging at parts but never to an unplayable point
- Very good stealth gameplay

Cons:
- The god damn map never fails to confuse the ♥♥♥♥ out of me, been like that through all the series and I would love to see it improved
- Sort of to do with the map again but indoor environments don't always make it clear where you are meant to go
- Loading times are a bit iffy

Great game worth the purchase and plenty of fun DLC to keep you going

reviewText: I actually liked playing as a younger Batman the voice actors are different since the game takes place before Asylum and City but I liked them.  In this game we finally get to see the Bat Cave (not the backup bat cave at Asylum).  It looks pretty awesome and you could see some technology being worked on like the bat mobile.  The map, however, is a bit bigger since they split it into two sections Old Gotham (The one in City) and New Gotham.  There's fast travel in the game to help us get to spot to spot so we don't have to glide all the way to an desination.  Solving a crime scene is fun to watch.  For some reason the Joker seems a little brighter and happier than in City and Asylum (but it could just be me so I don't know).  There are some bugs in the game but you just have to restart the checkpoint and you're good.  Get this game if you're a fan of Batman.

reviewText:
A good Arkham game. Not the best sure... But still overwhelmingly good!

The backlash at this game is surely reasonable, seeing that it's done by a new developer and as such is not a Rocksteady game. But, the backlash is unjustifiable. This game is really good and a solid addition to the Arkham series. It may not be Rocksteady, and may not be too innovative. But it does innovate and does the Batman: Arkham formula right!

The game's story is set on Christmas Eve when Black Mask decides to put a bounty on a very young Batman, who's still in his second year of crime fighting, which attracts the world's 8 deadliest assassins to track him down. The story is easily the best part about the game and is a very good Batman story. It does what other Arkham games dind't do, which is explore the dynamic between Batman and his allies, mainly Alfred, Barbara (AKA Batgirl) and Comissioner Gordon. The story is set 5 years before Asylum, but quite honestly, it should be 10. The characters are way, WAY younger than their Asylum counterparts and really, since Asylum depicts Tim Drake as being the current Robin, while Origins depicts Batman working alone. It just doesn't fit well... but that's a nitpick.

The gameplay mechanics are pretty much the same as City. Free flow combat. Stealth gameplay. Crime scene investigations. Open world gliding and grappling. Riddler trophies. It's really similar to City, but still has some twists of its own. Some new gadgets such as the Reverse Claw and the Concussion Detonator offer some cool dynamic gameplay mechanics to both Stealth and Combat. New enemy types such as the Martial Artist are also a very welcome addition that really make combat much more interesting and less repetitive.

It's easily noticeable that this isn't a Rocksteady game since the way the grappling works and the enemy AI are, really feel different... I feel like this is a nitpick, but it's just something I felt having played both other Batman games. Still, glitches and bugs were a rare occasion for me personally, yet I felt they were more than City or Asylum ever had.

Multiplayer is interesting, offering a 3v3v2 scenario. Playing as a goon in Joker and Bane's gangs is acceptable. It's a very standard 3rd person shooter. Still, the feeling of having Batman or Robin on your tail really helps you understand how the goons you beat up in singleplayer feel like. Batman and Robin themselves are the same as usual, but knowing that the goons you take out are players really change the feeling of pulling off a sucessful takedown. The assymetric aspect of the multiplayer however is its downfall. Having Batman, Robin, Joker, Bane and goons all play different is not only confusing, but also frustrating since you never seem to catch a break and play with who you want.

This is a Batman game however and what matters is the singleplayer. Thankfully Arkham Origins delivers a good Batman experience with some minor tweaks but innovations nonetheless. An amazing story and the solid gameplay from past Arkham games make it a very cool game. Just don't expect a Rocksteady game. Still, WB Montreal's first game is an amazing one for a first game.

Buy it if you want some more Batman action before Arkham Knight. It's really good but if City was just the ammount of Batman you were craving, you can skip it without missing out on too much. But, if you haven't played the others, by all means, buy this game. It's really good!

Highly recommend it.

reviewText: For a game that I remember receiving a lukewarm reception at its launch, I was really impressed with Arkham Origins. Whenever the reins of a franchise is handed over to another developer, there's always that worry of how the end result will turn out and in this case, I don't think you'd even notice any difference whatsoever. The game follows the formula of the previous games almost to a fault and while it doesn't come close to matching Arkham City, there's a few moments within the story that really stand out from the series that I think it should be remembered for. If you've enjoyed Asylum or City, you'll enjoy this. If this is your first Batman game, while there's nothing really wrong with this, I'd probably encourage you to play Asylum first.

reviewText:
First off, I must say that my opinion of this game is severely swayed by my undying love for the past two games. I was really hoping this game could match them, or get close. I can say that this game is absolutely beautiful, well optimized, and definitely worth a playthrough.

However, it absolutely does not live up to the other Arkham games. For some reason the main story feels way too rushed, not to mention short (6 Hours Tops), and the game as a whole seems to rely on the majority of the content being challenge maps. I can enjoy challenge maps, but after playing so much of two other games with the same combat, Im kind of burnt out of just fighting dudes after dudes for no reason.

There were many parts of the game in which I thought were very well done including environmental design, especially inside the buildings, although the city area as a whole seemed dull. Seeing as this is my review, Im am going to tell you why I was upset about this game because of lacking portrayals of two characters:

JOKER: I think troy baker did some good work, but honestly, it was noticeably off, and with the joker I need him to be perfect or I get really sad. His appearance reminded me of a small elf that grew some legs and put on facepaint, but the joker is the joker and I love it just the same.

HARLEEN QUINZEL: This game made me think it would deliver the gripping Harley/Joker backstory in which I love so much, and it even had a build up in the character development, but then it seems they forgot about the whole situation and left it alone. I am still upset that they didnt finish what they started, especially when it comes to my 2 favorite Batman characters.

Overall, the game is enjoyable, but certainly does not live up to its predecessors. If you are playing this game for the story, go ahead, but you may just end up feeling like something is missing. In the past two games I got 100% and for this game I just didnt feel like it was worth it. ARKHAM KNIGHT CANNOT COME SOON ENOUGH.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ok let's get this out of the way, this is the worst game in the series so far. Now you might be asking yourself: lol is dis duud on meth or sumting. Well, actually you might think that I'm gonna say some logical reason for making such a statement(not the meth thing). So le't get down to it.

The fighting and stealth are both still really fun. So what is the problem? Well the problem is that they are indeed fun, but they were also fun in Arkham city(I would acually say that they were both better in Arkham city), and they have not really been changed at all since then. Overall the gameplay is nearly identical to Arkham city. Everything that worked there, also works quite well here.They did add few neat things, but I was hoping for more. And yeah, there is that multiplayer mode....that nobody really wanted to see. There are also a lot of glicthes in the game, some are small and some are serious issues. The game does also crash quite often.

But anyway, what about the story? Well the joker has a big role in it...again. The joker is a great character, but could you give the spotlight to someone else please, he already had a huge role in 2 games! There is also that 8 assassin's hire by Black mask thing, which doesn't really get as much attention as I hoped. The boss fights that they were bragging on about are not even that special. Some of them are quite good, and some are the quite bad.

A lot of people were ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off because Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroiy are not in the game, but those new voice actors for Batman and the joker both do a good job, so no need to worry about that. But overall the story and characters are all quite good. I would even say that the story, might be the best in the series. The problem is that it lacks tension, because it's a prequel.

Ah whatever, I think that I have said all that there is to say.Even though Arkham origins is quite clearly the weakest part of the series, I still had some fun playing it, but I was left hoping for much more.So what is my final verdict? In it's current state, I simply can't give this game a higher score than 6,5 out of 10. I may have given it a 7 if it wasn't SO glitchy, but it's a little late for that now...
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
First, don't believe the bad reviews, they aren't right.
In short: I've played this game since the night it came out and enjoyed every single moment of it.
In long: What Arkham Asylum and Arkham City were, and even better. Bigger world, a great story, great combat system with other gadgets and enemies type. The game is harder, enemies attack more frequently (it gets annoying sometimes, but most of the times, you just have to time it, I know it's hard to not start striking but... well, countering is important, too! But don't worry, you'll get your chance). The story was really great (yes, I'm saying it again). Improvements? Especially the boss fights, most boss fights were enjoyable and unique. (I still hate Riddler / Enigma for making us go around collecting collectibles).

In Short once more: The game was extremely satisfying, I'll wait for the next game once again! (And replay the game quite a few times).
PS: Kevin Conroy accidentally confirmed a bigger game (?)

reviewText:
A really good game, and answers many questions prior to Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. Still riddled with some annoying bugs & glitches here and there, but doesn't take away the experience in general.

City seems to be less atmospheric than in Arkham City, however the character is usually involved in missions rather than adventuring throughout the city, in that case, i'm pretty fine with that.

The details in Arkham Origins is near-perfect (at least to me). The characters and environments are well-detailed and nothing really important seems left out.

Main story takes about 10-14 hours.

Final Verdict: 7/10

reviewText: Now that I've finished it and everyone sort of looks down on it might as well review it. I've enojoyed my time with Arkham Origins not only because of the differences it had from Asylum and City but because of its dark atmosphere. The boss fights (excluding Bane) weren't constanly being drawn out with Venom" and there were less chores to do all around. Asylum didn't have this problem but with City I saw every villian as an annoyance whereas Origins' villians threatened something I cared about. The end of this game wasn't a bulky boss fight but more so an outlet for you to taste revenge and release Batman's anger. I am absolutely satisfied with this pickup that costed about 7$ on GMG."

reviewText:
Ok let's get this out of the way, this is the worst game in the series so far. Now you might be asking yourself: lol is dis duud on meth or sumting. Well, actually you might think that I'm gonna say some logical reason for making such a statement(not the meth thing). So le't get down to it.

The fighting and stealth are both still really fun. So what is the problem? Well the problem is that they are indeed fun, but they were also fun in Arkham city(I would acually say that they were both better in Arkham city), and they have not really been changed at all since then. Overall the gameplay is nearly identical to Arkham city. Everything that worked there, also works quite well here.They did add few neat things, but I was hoping for more. And yeah, there is that multiplayer mode....that nobody really wanted to see. There are also a lot of glicthes in the game, some are small and some are serious issues. The game does also crash quite often.

But anyway, what about the story? Well the joker has a big role in it...again. The joker is a great character, but could you give the spotlight to someone else please, he already had a huge role in 2 games! There is also that 8 assassin's hire by Black mask thing, which doesn't really get as much attention as I hoped. The boss fights that they were bragging on about are not even that special. Some of them are quite good, and some are the quite bad.

A lot of people were ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off because Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroiy are not in the game, but those new voice actors for Batman and the joker both do a good job, so no need to worry about that. But overall the story and characters are all quite good. I would even say that the story, might be the best in the series. The problem is that it lacks tension, because it's a prequel.

Ah whatever, I think that I have said all that there is to say.Even though Arkham origins is quite clearly the weakest part of the series, I still had some fun playing it, but I was left hoping for much more.So what is my final verdict? In it's current state, I simply can't give this game a higher score than 6,5 out of 10. I may have given it a 7 if it wasn't SO glitchy, but it's a little late for that now...
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
First, don't believe the bad reviews, they aren't right.
In short: I've played this game since the night it came out and enjoyed every single moment of it.
In long: What Arkham Asylum and Arkham City were, and even better. Bigger world, a great story, great combat system with other gadgets and enemies type. The game is harder, enemies attack more frequently (it gets annoying sometimes, but most of the times, you just have to time it, I know it's hard to not start striking but... well, countering is important, too! But don't worry, you'll get your chance). The story was really great (yes, I'm saying it again). Improvements? Especially the boss fights, most boss fights were enjoyable and unique. (I still hate Riddler / Enigma for making us go around collecting collectibles).

In Short once more: The game was extremely satisfying, I'll wait for the next game once again! (And replay the game quite a few times).
PS: Kevin Conroy accidentally confirmed a bigger game (?)

reviewText:
Amazing!

If you have been following the Arkham series you will love this game! Hell if you havent you will probably still LOVE this game!

Origins brings everything that the other games in the series have and more. New items and weapons, massive open world play and your favorite Batman Villains and Allies. The feel of this game is deffinatley dark. The environment, the tone and the sounds all give you the feeling that you are in a total scumbags paradise.

There is nothing more gratifying than perching your caped crusader on the edge of a building, looking down on the crime riddled Gotham, feeling the whole city is out to get you but knowing you strike dread into the criminals hearts.

This game personifies Bat Man and it makes you feel like you are the Dark Knight himself.

9.5/10

reviewText: Unlike too many open world games in recent memory, Batman: Arkham games don't fall into the trap of giving you a world packed out the ears with boring menial tasks.  If you took away the world and put Batman in a room fulll of thugs, this game could still easily stand on its own.\n\nThe combat encourages timing over button mashing, improvisation over spamming, and thoughtfulness over bullheadedness.  The stealth gameplay is a rare example of one that blends in so well the action rather than taking away from it.

reviewText: THIS GAME KICKS ♥♥♥\n
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
[Semi Spoiler Alert for the Series Itself Aswell]

So as a massive fan, enjoying pretty much all Batman content, I was glad to buy this game when I could on sale and being able to play it on my heap of ♥♥♥♥ laptop which is surprising. I was somewhat impressed. Mainly story wise, although it's done so many times.

This game would of been better for the first game of the series, introducing players to Batman who're new to whole story of Batman.
(Origins > Asylum > City) that's the order it is in timeline instead of being some LotD/Star Wars releases, but that is just a minor complaint that obviously can't be dealt with.

-Combat-
The combat was the same old thing, but that isn't always a bad thing, I like to speed through gameplay and enjoy story as much as I could and with Batman games, it goes too well if you max out armour/shock gloves in Origins(same with previous games aswell) combat armour is pretty much the Jesus items of the games. The animations for some of the fighting scenes/gameplay was amazing though. 7/10

-Stealth-
Stealth parts of the game hardly happened as much (probably because I stormed in with combat armour) but there wasn't enough compared to Asylum, which was disappointment, simply because it doesn't make you feel like Batman against thugs, with the thugs, you're supposed to be intimidating, surprising and bringing fear to them. So it was quite a shame not being able to feel like side of Batman most of the time. 6/10

-Boss Battles-
Boss battles was great as it showed a lot of different pieces of combat combinations. You was introduced to 8 different types of fighters, notably Firefly, a mix of using items and taking him down, Copperhead with using shadow clone jutsu and posion and Deathstroke was personally my favourite as it took me a lot of tries to defeat him, because of those time events and counters to get right. Bane was also a ♥♥♥♥♥, not going down until like the end of the game.

-Story-

Oh boy here we go. The actual story, was pretty good, nothing amazing, it's been done before with the main story of Batman and Joker, and thats what really bugs me, as its always focused on them two? We've had THREE games based on those two, it gets old really fast, but  because Joker is dead after City, by the game lore it makes you wonder who the main villian will be.

Besides the whole Joker and Batman ship, every other character in the game was imense, Bane mainly, but I am biased as he's my favourite but besides that, I'm happy with the story, and the overall outlook on the game, I still have to try the online features.

TENOUTATEN

If you enjoy Batman, and can deal with a few nitpicking, this game is for you. :)

reviewText:
I wish, I wish, I *wish* that this game were better.  It's good in the same way all the Arkham games are good, but there is so much wasted potential.  Not least of which: if this is an origin story, why is Batman all kitted out in crazy body armor and fighting with just as many gadgets and just as effectively in the other Arkham games.

However, the gameplay is still pretty tight, and it's still fun.  Just ... not worth full price, like Asylum and City were.

Having finished it, though, I do have to say props on the story - I actually think this might be the strongest story of the Arkham games.

reviewText: Best entry in the series so far

reviewText:
If Arkham Asylum offered the thrill of becoming Batman, and Arkham City offered the thrill of exploring Gotham in free flight, and Arkham Knight will (supposedly) offer the thrill of piloting the Batmobile, then Arkham Origins seems to be offering the thrill of experiencing the genesis of Batman's most important relationships: Alfred, Gordon, and an array of his iconic nemises.

However, Arkham Origins does not, as you might think, tell the story of how Bruce Wayne became the Batman. In fact, the circumstances of Wayne's childhood tragedy, training, and return to Gotham as reborn vigilante is already in the past, before the game begins, and he is already equipped with batarangs, grapnel, and Batwing jet. Instead, the 'Origins' referenced are the seeds planted in the story that will eventually mature into the Arkham City future. Along the way, Batman grows from a shadowy rumor to a renowned crime-fighter, having already taken bites out of local threats like Penguin and Black Mask, but also starting to attract enough attention to himself to begin to tip the established balance of power that will change Gotham forever.

Unfortunately, where the previous Arkham Games have built and expanded on the fantasy of 'becoming' the Batman and living his adventure, with his gadgets, intelligence, and fortitude, Origins deviates very little from the City forumla of roaming the night, dealing justice to criminals, solving crime, and saving the city from an overarching threat. There's nothing new here, which is probably good news if you enjoyed City, but will disappoint if you're looking for the Arkham franchise to raise the ante. In a very real sense, Origins is a sort of deluxe-sized expansion pack for Arkham City that transposes that sequel's gameplay back in time.

The good is that the polish and production values are as high as ever. The animation, cinematics, voice acting, and so on are extremely immersive, and Gotham looks great as a proud, post-industrial metropolis beginning to decay from the inside out. All of Batman's gadgets return, and there are now even more districts to explore, with never a shortage of thugs to beat into unconsciousness. There is a full compliment of challenge maps to medal in, side quests to complete, and obscure objects to find and collect, as in City. The main addition to the Arkham series overall is the Crime Scene" sequences where Batman explores and reconstructs various crimes in order to solve a problem. While these are very
recommended: the actions and narrations do give the player a solid sense of being the "World's Greatest Detective"
hoursPlayed: which is often neglected in Batman movies and games.\n\nThe bad is that it will feel very much like playing Arkham City all over again

reviewText:
Being a prequel to the Arkham franchise, the game stars a younger Bruce Wayne trying to find solid footing as the Bat. This comes through in his interactions with criminals: he's much fiercer and almost homicidal in tone and actions. He lacks the distinct calm that he perpetually exudes; his actions are brasher and more impulsive. Although Batman supposedly never kills, he comes damn close in this game due to his rage, which has obviously settled in later titles. His anger is subliminally hidden in his tone of voice and the excessive use of force in cut scenes when giving beat-downs, so you might miss it if you don't understand that Batman is supposed to be calm, meticulous, and in control of his emotions.

The problem is that this is the only shot of Batman's inexperience for 60% of the game. Towards the end of the title you get a substantially larger view at a young Batman's doubts and worries. For almost half the game there is absolutely nothing to point at Batman's inexperience, nothing to tell you that he is just starting out as Gotham's knight. There's his anger, and it was done in a sublime manner, but given that there's suddenly an entire game's worth of development at the end you end up wondering what the ♥♥♥♥ you were doing for the first half. Suddenly Alfred is yelling at Batman for being reckless; Batman is having doubts about his effectiveness at saving his city; the gamer delves into the Joker's psychological profile. Yet half the game you're just doing some boring ♥♥♥ shit that doesn't amount to the development in character and story that we get at the end.

And don't get me started on the much hyped 'assassins'. They're introduced at the beginning and made to look as if they will be a significant element to the plot, but what you get is random drop-ins from people along your investigation. The drop-ins aren't even all that good: One guy you never fight, two are optional and are forgettable, and one fight is a golrified QTE where the only inputs needed are ''Attack'' and ''Counter''. The fight with the 8th assassin doesn't even make sense, as the bounty on your head (which they are all after) is completely gone. There must have been a better way to integrate the assassins into the main storyline. As it stands they seem to be an afterthought conjured up to give you a boss fight every few hours. And the boss fight's aren't even all that interesting.

'Gameplay'-wise the-ahahahahahahahaha. Why bother talking about game mechanics: it's exactly the same as the other titles. There is absolutely nothing different here, other than akward pacing. You get all of the same weapons and moves, with a few new ones that all wind up being more or less useless save for two or three. Hell, they imported Arkham City into this game, with the only addition to the overworld being a long bridge that leads to a new section of Gotham to mess around in. Granted, it's not the SAME exact area as before, as they had to downsize it to create new areas, but it's still pretty familiar territory. I'd argue that it was a change for the worse, as one of the shinning aspects of Arkham City was the character that each area had, signifying the leader of the place. That's gone, and now it's just gothic architecture.

Riddler is still there, but the quality of the trophy placement has degraded. Just like in the last title there are a bunch of trophies scattered throughout, this time in the form of 'data packs'. The odd thing is that you can actually solve a LOT of these from the very beginning, so it all feels underwhelming. That and the fact that some of them are just out in the open, waiting to be grabbed.

There are no Riddles for you to solve this time around, sadly. That means that you don't get the Batman references throughout the world, waiting to be scanned. Which means that the overworld feels more barren, because instead of:

-Harvey Dent's office in a corner
-Catwoman's home to the side of a building with graffitti sprayed on the wall
-a movie poster referencing a shape-shifting villain
-a jailcell with calendars strewn about in a peculiar manner
-a casino with a cool, Greek looking neon sign referencing a villain

you get:

-an office building
-an apartment building
-a movie poster
-regular looking jail cell after jail cell
-a generic casino

People need to understand that one of the cool things about the Arkham titles was the amount of references they tried putting into the games in the environment, which means that you got a really unique looking world with character instead of blank building after blank building. I don't even read Batman comics, but everytime I saw something unique in the overworld, which was almost always, I would scan it cause it stood out enough for me to wonder what it was. Now it's just gothic architecture that looks nice. Instead of Riddler's Riddles you get some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥ 'Anarky' tags, that are just leftist socialist dribble about the banks. I read four of those tags. Four. When he got to ♥♥♥♥ing collectivism I was like ''oh God I can't stand the ♥♥♥♥er I'm not gonna read any more of this propaganda'. Cause it's propaganda. I know for a ♥♥♥♥ing fact that some writer was typing it all up, assured that he would 'enlighten' the masses reading his garbage. Also, the villain behind the tags winds up being some 'Anonymous' inspired ♥♥♥♥♥♥ who goes on a LONG ♥♥♥♥ING SPEECH after you beat him. He's just really annoying, really political, and really really gay.

TL;DR it's like all the other games with nothing new to offer. The one thing it could have done, which was a showcase of a younger Batman, wasn't present for over half the title. When it emerges it doesn't save this from still being an otherwise plain affair. Something tells me to hit the 'no' button in the recommendation, but it's still an alright game. It's just a disappointment. Also, it wasn't made by Rocksteady, so that might explain why it doesn't try anything new. This is like a half-♥♥♥♥♥ game released before the REAL sequel to Arkham City: Arkham Knight.

And yes, I focus on a lot of the bad in the review and yet still recommend it. Mainly because despite it's flaws, I'm not regretting the purchase and it was like a C+ summer film: I could've spent my money watching a better movie, but I don't regret the experience and am fine with it.

reviewText: It's still the same old Batman experience, albeit with seemingly slower and less responsive combat. The setting should be familiar to fans of the series. What won't be familiar, however, are the bugs. I ran into a progression-blocking bug and dedcided to wait for it to be patched, until the devs said that they may or may not release bug fixing patches. However, they're still going to release paid DLC. I'm done with this game and I'm sure as hell done with this dev after just one purchase.\nStrongly recommend avoiding it. Asylum has such an amazing story and City is great in its own right, and I'm sure this game is pretty decent too, but I can't bring myself to support it in any way.

reviewText: For the eight hours of seamless gameplay I was able to enjoy, this game was surpassing my best expectations. A really well paced game, worthy of being a game of the year. If it were not for a game breaking bug on the Royal Hotel level. When I reach the 40th floor, about four or five paced in, the game crashes. Over and over again. I redownloaded the game - and still the same issue. I´m really sick of the cr***y  console ports that devs hastily make for PC. I sent each co-developer a bug report two days ago, and all i´ve received is silence. If the bugs didnt exist, I would recommend this game. A real disappointment in my opinion.

reviewText:
I got this game at a cazy deal and yet I still find this game to be such a let down. I was and am a HUGE Batman Arkham Series fan. I really loved the dark atmosphere and challenge (on hard) of the first game and the high replayability of the second game. With that said, this game in no way pushes the series forward. The raved about boss fights are lazy. This game completely exhausted the combat system (believe or not) and then compounds that with repetitious uninspired stun/beatdown boss fights. The story was also weak and spent way too long to show itself different or new. I found myself (a Batman fan!) getting more and more cynical as I played. I have about 25% of the main story left and I'm not even the slightest interested in how things turn out. (6/10)

PS: For an inspired boss reference, I think Poison Ivy with Catwoman, Killer Croc in BAA, Mr. Freeze, Solomon Grundy, and even Bane in BAA were inspiring boss fights.

UPDATE: I have now completed this game (after some reluctance) and the final fight is just about the ONLY inspird boss fight I've found in this game.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is the newest title in the Batman Arkham franchise. I noticed that it got very negative review and i thought i would write my review to clear some things up.

First of all Arkham Origins is not trying to do something new or redo a major part of the game and for a good reason if WB Montreal had added something new or redid something Rockstedy put in place they would have been blamed by fans for messing up what Rockstedy had created.

First of all the story it's really good. The first two Arkham games had an okay story but it wasn't a story i really connected with i mostly finished the game and that was that. Arkham Origins on the other hand has a story that keeps you on your toes wondering whats going to happen next. In my opinion it's way better than the past Arkham games.

One of the biggest things Origins got blamed for was the difficulty but i personally like the challenge. The first two Arkham games always felt to easy i went through them really quickly and after that it was over. Origins adds to the challenge and might have overdone it the game could be argued overly hard but once you get the hang of it it becomes pretty easy.

The boss battles are much more interesting take the firefly battle for example avoiding fire while a bridge was falling apart was really enjoyable. The boss battles also gave me something new a feeling of satisfaction when you defeat a boss. This was never really in the Arkham games.

My favorite part of the game was the Multiplayer it adds a whole new aspect of the game and can be pretty scary. You really feel what the criminals you encounter feel as you see something swoop past you and then take you out from behind. The bane and joker games are your average 3rd person shooter but playing as Batman or Robin is really fun.

While the game may not have added much it delivers in one category making an excellent Arkham game.

all in all I rate this game

7/10 it had some major glitches that should have been fixed.

reviewText:
The game itself is fine. It plays fine, the story is not bad. There are times where the game will show glitches, such as Batman falling THROUGH THE GROUND, or landing in water when he should be landing on the ground. Those, quite frankly, shouldn't bother anyone too much as they aren't too bad. Now, I am not too familiar with all the glitches, however I can tell you: STAY AWAY FROM 'MY ALIBI'.

After you fight Bane, there will be a prompt to go after someone called The Bird. There are three places you travel to in order to complete the mission. The last place is 'My Alibi.' When I played it, I did the mini-boss fight with The Bird, then I was able to walk around. I walked into an adjacent room which turned black, as if I were between layers. Then I tried to leave the building but got stuck, so I restarted the game. When I continued the game, I saw Batman stuck in limbo, completely rendering the game broken. I've checked around and I see that it is a common glitch that occurs.

I have only had this game for about a month, so whatever updates occured to fix this problem never carried over to when I bought it. I'm recommending this game because as I have said, it is fine and most of the glitches aren't too bad. All you need to do though, to be safe, is to completely avoid going into 'My Alibi.'

reviewText: Even though it says I've only played this game for five hours, I mostly played this game offline and have completed the campaign. I must say that although the game is great, it is no match to what Arkham City had. The story was great, loved the part with the refrences to the Killing Joke and Joker's origin. However, what really began to tick me off was the combat, it was much slower and not as fluid. I found myself having the slow down, which is not a good thing when facing fifteen people at once. The only way I could take down some of the later battles were the shock gloves, which were way too overpowered in my opinion. The younger Bruce Wayne does actually feel younger, he seems more arrogant and less experienced, and I loved having Alfred talk to me rather than Oracle for a change. This is not just Batman's story though, it is also a story about the Joker, whom I found intriguing. The new voice actors suprisingly fit well, but nobody can beat Kevin Conroy. Gotham City seems really like a cut and paste Arkahm City, but it has some new tricks up its sleeve. Overall, even though this game is probably the weakest in the series, it's really well done. I'm suprised it was good, as it was not Rocksteady who made this game, but WB Montreal.\n\n8.4/10

reviewText: Arkham Origins is the third Batman game from Warner Brothers but not, the company likes to point out, either a direct sequel to Arkham City nor even necessarily something that is connected to the previous two games, by external developer Rocksteady, in any particular fashion. This entry, by WB Games Montreal, is sort of like a Year Two Batman story, which immediately raises any number of questions. First, because it's clear that Jim Gordon and Batman have very little history together at this point, it's not a tale that directly follows Frank Miller's Year One. Second it's not really an origin story of anything: Batman has already been operating for some time and Arkham Asylum, as a facility that is distinct and separate from Blackgate Prison, on the other hand, does not exist at all. This is, however, very much a WB Batman game, as the new developer takes Rocksteady's work and makes no substantial alterations beyond telling a different story. For good or ill, this is indeed your father's Batman game.\n\nThe game begins on Christmas Eve with Batman going after Black Mask, who has apparently put a bounty of $50 million on his head, and this has attracted some of the most dangerous assassins in the world to Gotham. Because this is early in Batman's career he does some dumb things like forgetting his razor and neglecting to secure a subdued super"villain (the ridiculously-named and ill-fated Electrocutioner); additionally
date: half of Gotham isn't convinced that he's real and most of the police force is out to try to arrest him or put him six feet under (compare this to the deferential treatment he receives in the opening cutscene of Arkham Asylum). Also
recommended: there are quite a few other things going on during this particular December 24: a certain Mr. E Nigma hijacks Batman's navigation towers and leaves blackmail files around the city; Anarky has planted bombs on major landmarks; and the Mad Hatter does his best Jonathan Crane impression. The entirety of the main story's action takes place during this single evening so it's a very busy night for the Bat.\n\nThe main elements of the previous games return here: the free-flow combat
hoursPlayed: unlocking a succession of Bat-gadgets
voteText: side missions and collectibles. The only new facets to the game are the Team Fortress-like multiplayer
helpfulPercent: the fast-travel system needed to traverse the much-larger bit of real estate that is Gotham City
votesHelpful: and the training simulator (although this is basically a reworking of the combat and stealth room challenges from the previous games
votesTotal: which are also present).\n\nMultiplayer is disappointing
votesFunny: in some measure because it's never been a strong suit of mine in any game
commentsCount: but also because it's the first time I've ever felt like a 95-lb. weakling when playing as Batman in a game. Players are randomly assigned to teams of criminals with two random players being selected to play as Batman and Robin. The regular criminal types are loaded to the gills with gear that ensures that simply lying in wait as if you were playing a predator challenge as Batman is not a viable option
column16: as you will quickly be spotted and shot. There is also the possibility of the gang leaders
column17: Bane and Joker
column18: turning up during a match. Matches are won by holding control points in the case of criminals or filling an intimidation meter (by taking out criminals) when playing as the Dynamic Duo. It's all bog-standard stuff
column19: in other words
column20: and not something I was too interested in spending much time on.\n\nDisappointingly
column21: this and the challenge maps are the only places where one can utilize the various DLC costumes available. I'm not sure why this is. The official explanation had something to do with cutscenes being pre-rendered in such as way that the use of alternate Batman skins is not an option
column22: but this is evidently a limitation of the engine being utilized by WB Montreal because Rocksteady released a code that allowed anyone to use unlocked DLC skins at any time during Arkham City's story.\n\nThe story mode action
column23: then
column24: is very familiar to players of previous Arkham games. Is this an inherently bad thing? Not really. If you liked the Rocksteady games
column25: you'll probably like this one
column26: because it is largely more of the same.\n\nSeveral odd design decisions occurred with the production of this game
column27: which will affect your experience but not in a terribly detrimental way. For whatever reasons the corporate gods determined
column28: Warner had Montreal working on this while Rocksteady was quietly and concurrently (it would seem) creating Arkham Knight in secret. Where the latter sees the return of fan-favorite Kevin Conroy as the voice of Batman
column29: WB opted to go with a different voice cast for the roles of Batman
column30: The Joker
column31: and Harley Quinn in Arkham Origins. This is somewhat distracting at first
column32: but the Origins cast do well enough in their respective roles. Troy Baker
column33: in particular
column34: is quite good as The Joker
column35: which is a bit of a relief because Mark Hamill is probably done with the part for good. The number of Riddler collectibles was halved from Arkham City's absurd 400 to a more manageable 200. While some reviewers have said the freeflow combat doesn't feel as "tight" in this entry
column36: I can't really say that I've noticed a difference; on the other hand
column37: I'll be the first to concede that I'm not exactly a freeflow-combat master.\n\nThere are a lot of goofy aspects to the unfolding narrative here. While Arkham City presented us with the bizarre notion that an entire area encompassing dozens of city blocks would be cordoned off as a kind of "death zone" substitute for an actual penitentiary
column38: I've come to realize that this could either be viewed as something presented in a realistic fashion (in which case it is kinda batshit crazy) or as a Swiftian satire on the phenomena of white flight
column39: the "war on drugs" and an increasing reliance on the expansion of prisons in a society where the percentage of the population that is incarcerated seems to be growing exponentially. In either case
column40: it would make sense that there would be no ordinary citizens on the streets of such an Escape from New York-style dystopian penal zone. Here the only explanation provided for this incongruous phenomenon is that police have warned people to stay off the streets. At various points in the game
column41: we're introduced to Batman and Alfred's insanely-fantastic analytical equipment
column42: which can produce antivenoms to unknown neurotoxins in a matter of minutes and provide DNA matches from bodily fluids at a crime scene with equal celerity. The crowning absurdity has to be the game's naive proposal that any kind of high-voltage equipment can be used as an effective defibrillator; in fairness
column43: this is the sort of thing that one tends to see on television on an almost weekly basis
column44: but this doesn't make it any less nonsensical.\n\nThe main story will take you around 30-35 hours to knock out and you can count on an extra 10-15 hours getting the collectibles and beating challenge maps. Annoyingly
column45: the "Initiation" DLC is itself just a series of challenge maps rather than being a full-fledged story prologue. "Cold Cold Heart
column46: however, does consist of a new story, a somewhat-rehashed origin tale of classic Bat-villain, Mr. Freeze. Outside of the wintry tale, there are a few new things to do, such as finding new Anarky tags and unfreezing cops and security guards. For a completionist, the Mr. Freeze DLC will take about another 7 hours, and it's well worth a few bucks, but I wouldn't buy it at the current full asking price of $10.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is pretty okay.  Unfortunately, it still appears that it has some game-breaking glitches, despite the patches put out when the major ones were made a known issue in Nov. 2013.

The gameplay itself is pretty much the same as the last two installments in the batman series (Arkham: Asylum and City).   Bats glides, beats-up to string combos and special beatdowns, sneaks around in predator encounters (vent, grate, hanging takedowns are the same)  etc etc.
Personally I found it different in the overall feel of the game.  The previous installements seemed to pay much more homage to the comic book character's canon and story, with little touches  such as references to classic or obscure batman villains.  Arkham Origins is the beginning of Batman's career, so granted he hasn't encountered as many in this story line, but I would have preferred some of that love of the actual comic flavor as in the previous (for example: Bane is rocking what sounds to be an attempt at some Eastern European accent, despite being from Santa Presca).  Instead with Origins, we are given a storyline that only barely jives with the continuity of the previous games and gameplay that feels much more   of a beat 'em up and less of a love-letter to the batman franchise.

As to the glitches, about 56hrs into the game (and gathering every collectible possible) I experienced a clipping glitch where batman fell through the map.  Because the game has auto-save and it unfortunately saved during this, I could not load to before that. Unfortunately, it looks like I will have to restart the game.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins review. It's no Arkham Asylum or Arkham City.

Set just two years after Bruce Wayne becomes Batman, the game has our caped crusader still as yet unknown, a myth amongst criminals and a wanted man by Gotham City PD. Bruce is on his own, and Origins explores how Batman becomes protector of Gotham.

Let's start off with the bad. There are a HUGE amount of horrific bugs and control issues that really hamper the game, including a few game breaking ones. Combat flows awkwardly and haphazardly, with serious AI issues abounding all throughout. Often the gadgets can stop working, and many times it's not always clear where to go next. However, YMMV in these areas, so take that with a grain of salt.

That being said, there are flashes of pure unadulterated brilliance in Origins. The story is AMAZING, and I would put it superior to both Asylum and City, even if they played it a bit safe with the ending. Fights with Deathstroke, Deadshot (♥♥♥♥ that fight) and even Firefly are great to see and pulled off nicely. Deathstroke's fight is absolutely brilliant, requiring strategy and constant awareness to do flawlessly.

The game looks very nice, even on my middle-range system. I can only imagine what a beastly rig would make this game look like. Environments however are a little bland. Would have liked to see more greenery, but the setting of the game at Christmas does explain away that omission.

Overall, while not as tight mechanically as Asylum, or City, Origins is worth your time. A great imagining of a Batman not yet a recognisable hero, but still a threat to the criminals of Gotham.

Rating: 3.5/5

Warner Brothers has no intention of patching bugs that don't break the game, so be aware that some issues can and most likely will arise while playing.

During a number of discussions with friends over this game it has generally been; just how can you improve on a solid enough gaming engine in the first place? You could possibly only really add to what has been an almost perfect series so far.

The story itself is set ten years before the story of Arkham Asylum and you run into all the familiars, joker riddles, other things to scan and collect to get the achievement, xp and upgrade etc.Having played the first two you knew that these things were going to be included again at the very least.
