reviewText:
The strongest mechanically and yet the weakest story-wise of the Batman: Arkham series, this game is both a thing of beauty and a shame. Combat has been tightened up mechanically, there are a variety wide variety of bosses, and the game is very beautiful...

...and yet, at the same time, feels somewhat hollow. The predator sequences, where you sneak around taking out goons from the shadows, feel shallow compared to previous installments - not because they're worse, but because they are, fundamentally, the same as ever. You have done this before, and there is no real difference between what you've done and what you are doing.

Likewise, the formula with the villians has worn thin as well - you fight the Joker yet again in this game, despite having already killed him in the previous one. They went out of their way to make this a prequel just so that you can fight the Joker yet again for no good reason. And indeed, the story in the game is disappointing - you are facing down eight assassins, but you never fight more than one of them at the same time, unlike in the trailer, and a number of them are just fairly anticlimactic fights with a super-goon surrounded by a bunch of goons. The story doesn't feel as coherent as either of the previous games, and while the riddler trophies were better than they were in the second game, they're still inferior to the Riddler's mechanics in the original Batman: Arkham Asylum.

All in all, it is still a good game, but it isn't great like the first game was. Had no one ever played any of these games before, it might have been better, but as this is the third installment which uses the same game mechanics and same villain, it just isn't as fresh.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Origins is pretty okay.  Unfortunately, it still appears that it has some game-breaking glitches, despite the patches put out when the major ones were made a known issue in Nov. 2013.

The gameplay itself is pretty much the same as the last two installments in the batman series (Arkham: Asylum and City).   Bats glides, beats-up to string combos and special beatdowns, sneaks around in predator encounters (vent, grate, hanging takedowns are the same)  etc etc.
Personally I found it different in the overall feel of the game.  The previous installements seemed to pay much more homage to the comic book character's canon and story, with little touches  such as references to classic or obscure batman villains.  Arkham Origins is the beginning of Batman's career, so granted he hasn't encountered as many in this story line, but I would have preferred some of that love of the actual comic flavor as in the previous (for example: Bane is rocking what sounds to be an attempt at some Eastern European accent, despite being from Santa Presca).  Instead with Origins, we are given a storyline that only barely jives with the continuity of the previous games and gameplay that feels much more   of a beat 'em up and less of a love-letter to the batman franchise.

As to the glitches, about 56hrs into the game (and gathering every collectible possible) I experienced a clipping glitch where batman fell through the map.  Because the game has auto-save and it unfortunately saved during this, I could not load to before that. Unfortunately, it looks like I will have to restart the game.

reviewText:
If Arkham Asylum offered the thrill of becoming Batman, and Arkham City offered the thrill of exploring Gotham in free flight, and Arkham Knight will (supposedly) offer the thrill of piloting the Batmobile, then Arkham Origins seems to be offering the thrill of experiencing the genesis of Batman's most important relationships: Alfred, Gordon, and an array of his iconic nemises.

However, Arkham Origins does not, as you might think, tell the story of how Bruce Wayne became the Batman. In fact, the circumstances of Wayne's childhood tragedy, training, and return to Gotham as reborn vigilante is already in the past, before the game begins, and he is already equipped with batarangs, grapnel, and Batwing jet. Instead, the 'Origins' referenced are the seeds planted in the story that will eventually mature into the Arkham City future. Along the way, Batman grows from a shadowy rumor to a renowned crime-fighter, having already taken bites out of local threats like Penguin and Black Mask, but also starting to attract enough attention to himself to begin to tip the established balance of power that will change Gotham forever.

Unfortunately, where the previous Arkham Games have built and expanded on the fantasy of 'becoming' the Batman and living his adventure, with his gadgets, intelligence, and fortitude, Origins deviates very little from the City forumla of roaming the night, dealing justice to criminals, solving crime, and saving the city from an overarching threat. There's nothing new here, which is probably good news if you enjoyed City, but will disappoint if you're looking for the Arkham franchise to raise the ante. In a very real sense, Origins is a sort of deluxe-sized expansion pack for Arkham City that transposes that sequel's gameplay back in time.

The good is that the polish and production values are as high as ever. The animation, cinematics, voice acting, and so on are extremely immersive, and Gotham looks great as a proud, post-industrial metropolis beginning to decay from the inside out. All of Batman's gadgets return, and there are now even more districts to explore, with never a shortage of thugs to beat into unconsciousness. There is a full compliment of challenge maps to medal in, side quests to complete, and obscure objects to find and collect, as in City. The main addition to the Arkham series overall is the Crime Scene" sequences where Batman explores and reconstructs various crimes in order to solve a problem. While these are very

reviewText:
First off, I must say that my opinion of this game is severely swayed by my undying love for the past two games. I was really hoping this game could match them, or get close. I can say that this game is absolutely beautiful, well optimized, and definitely worth a playthrough.

However, it absolutely does not live up to the other Arkham games. For some reason the main story feels way too rushed, not to mention short (6 Hours Tops), and the game as a whole seems to rely on the majority of the content being challenge maps. I can enjoy challenge maps, but after playing so much of two other games with the same combat, Im kind of burnt out of just fighting dudes after dudes for no reason.

There were many parts of the game in which I thought were very well done including environmental design, especially inside the buildings, although the city area as a whole seemed dull. Seeing as this is my review, Im am going to tell you why I was upset about this game because of lacking portrayals of two characters:

JOKER: I think troy baker did some good work, but honestly, it was noticeably off, and with the joker I need him to be perfect or I get really sad. His appearance reminded me of a small elf that grew some legs and put on facepaint, but the joker is the joker and I love it just the same.

HARLEEN QUINZEL: This game made me think it would deliver the gripping Harley/Joker backstory in which I love so much, and it even had a build up in the character development, but then it seems they forgot about the whole situation and left it alone. I am still upset that they didnt finish what they started, especially when it comes to my 2 favorite Batman characters.

Overall, the game is enjoyable, but certainly does not live up to its predecessors. If you are playing this game for the story, go ahead, but you may just end up feeling like something is missing. In the past two games I got 100% and for this game I just didnt feel like it was worth it. ARKHAM KNIGHT CANNOT COME SOON ENOUGH.

reviewText:
First, this game is no Arkham City, although it tries too hard to be be.
It's not bad but nor great either. The story is fantastic has explore the begining of the relationships that Batman builds during his career. The Joker scenes are probably the best part of the game.
But the gameplay is not innovative. The boss fights are easier, probably the easiest in all the series so far. Especially the Deathstroke fight is too early in the game and the Bane fights (except for the last one) are too rinse and repeat.
The puzzles are ok but easier compared to the previous games.
The extra costumes are awesome. The online multiplayer is down, but then again I bought this game for the single player campain.
Get this game on discount. Don't buy it on full price.

reviewText:
I had my doubts about this game after seeing a swapping of hands for developers and the metacritic scores, in comparison to the previous games (not that the metacritic was all that bad, its just lower than the previous titles.), but after picking this game up for $7.50, I can say that I got my money's worth and left satisfied. Although we saw the departure of Rockysteady on this title, presumably because Arkham Knight is quite resource consuming, WB Studios stepped in and did a fair job. They kept the good stuff (combat, open world, gadgets) and added a few nice features. Were you not aware of the change in studios, the only differences that might alert you to the fact would be the WB Studios logos and the new look interface. Otherwise, this game plays very much like the previous Arkham games. In my opinion, thats a good thing because it signals the developers knew what worked and didn't try to butcher it. For others, that is the inherit problem with this game; the fact that it is pretty much a clone of Arkham City. Were it not for a few changes, this game would be an exact clone. I really didn't have too much of a problem with this, seeing as its only the 3rd game in the installment and I'm not quite sick of doing the same thing over and over again yet. While its true that there isn't much innovation here, I'm glad that the new developers stuck with a route that worked and not one that tarnished the series. For that, we should all be proud.

The story in this game is fits well in the universe and unravels the beginnings of several overarching plot points in the series, mainly the beginning of the Batman-Joker conflict and early versions of Harley Quinn before she goes evil, for example. On that note, it was interesting to see the beginnings. Sure, they could have been fleshed out a bit more, but I'm not complaining. The story was good until the end, and I really didn't have any qualms about it. Like I said, gameplay is more or less the same, save for a few reskinned gadgets with slightly different (although still true to core functionality) uses, as well as some new enemies to fight. Combat is the same, with perhaps some new moves down the line when you level-up. The world is still open, and it plays very similar to Arkham City with a myriad of things to do. One thing I really liked, however, is they definitely fleshed out the detective mode here. While its still a very minor part of the game, you can analyze the crime scenes more by reanacting the crime and investigating more clues to solve the crime. Sure it holds your hand and it doesn't feel like it should, but its a welcomed addition that was missing from Arkham City that made me happy to see. In addition, the boss fights have been improved in my opinion, and overall, were a bit more satisfying than the previous game.

This game is not free of issues, however. I found that the counter key/button was only responsive 75%-80% of the time, causing large fights (10+ enemies) or counter heavy battles to be frustrating at times, as the counters would just not work at all some of the times. This also applied to ground takedowns. It just seemed like the key/button wasn't registering for me at times. There are also some combat bugs, such as enemies flying off the screen when hit or enemies clipping into buildings (still fightable even if you couldn't see them), but nothing gamebreaking here. A major issue, however, is the crashing. It shares a similar crashing issue with Arkham City. While this game crashing didn't seem to lock up my PC, it did seem to crash more often than the last game. I'd say it crashed once every 3-4 hours, and sometimes more often.

If you are looking for a new Batman game that innovates the series, you'll have to look elsewhere, but if you are looking for a solid and faithful prequel to the last two games, look no further. While this game is nowhere near perfect thanks to some bugs and such, it is a game worth playing and is enjoyable from start to finish. Recommened. 8.5/10

reviewText:
I really wanted to love this game.  I'm a huge fan of both Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, and was hoping that Arkham Origins would live up to the legacy.

It does not.

It is buggy, crashy, and unpolished.  The DNA of a great game is in there, but the result was rushed and disappointing.  Give the franchise back to Rocksteady and let them work their magic.

reviewText:
Howdy, ya'll.

I'll throw up a short review here and a link (if it'll let me) to a longer one.

Long story short, this is the weakest entry in the Arkham series.  The core of the game is still here, so the fighting and stealth sections remain.  Wonky controls, weaker graphics, and ridiculous boss fights are paired with a story that makes little sense outside of the core Joker/Batman meetup.

Still, though, the fighting is great and the stealth is at least as good - if not a bit better - than it has been before.  As a full priced entry, I just don't think it would measure up, but given its reduced sale price, and the reality that it will probably only get cheaper in the future, you can give this one a whirl if you want more Batman.

If you'd like to read a longer review, give it a shot here.  Thanks![midnightninja.net]

reviewText: Pros: Take the reviews of this game with a grain of salt in the most. Its a classic addition to the Arkham series. I enjoyed that the developers also took their time with this PC edition and it ran beautifully with my EVGA 780. the story was solid, gameplay was fun, and the entire experience was never dull. Not to forget all of the side activities in this game. (i never touched the multiplayer as i do not play batman games for multiplayer.)\n\nCons: it was lack of anything really new. outside of the story and bosses everything had a been there done that" type of experience. that knocked it down from being the best one. imo AA still holds the crown."

A must have for Batman fans and anyone who just can't wait for the next Rocksteady developed Arkham game.

reviewText: It's still the same old Batman experience, albeit with seemingly slower and less responsive combat. The setting should be familiar to fans of the series. What won't be familiar, however, are the bugs. I ran into a progression-blocking bug and dedcided to wait for it to be patched, until the devs said that they may or may not release bug fixing patches. However, they're still going to release paid DLC. I'm done with this game and I'm sure as hell done with this dev after just one purchase.\nStrongly recommend avoiding it. Asylum has such an amazing story and City is great in its own right, and I'm sure this game is pretty decent too, but I can't bring myself to support it in any way.

reviewText: For the eight hours of seamless gameplay I was able to enjoy, this game was surpassing my best expectations. A really well paced game, worthy of being a game of the year. I redownloaded the game - and still the same issue. I´m really sick of the cr***y  console ports that devs hastily make for PC. I sent each co-developer a bug report two days ago, and all i´ve received is silence. If the bugs didnt exist, I would recommend this game. A real disappointment in my opinion.

reviewText:
I got this game at a cazy deal and yet I still find this game to be such a let down. I was and am a HUGE Batman Arkham Series fan. I really loved the dark atmosphere and challenge (on hard) of the first game and the high replayability of the second game. With that said, this game in no way pushes the series forward. The raved about boss fights are lazy. This game completely exhausted the combat system (believe or not) and then compounds that with repetitious uninspired stun/beatdown boss fights. The story was also weak and spent way too long to show itself different or new. I found myself (a Batman fan!) getting more and more cynical as I played. I have about 25% of the main story left and I'm not even the slightest interested in how things turn out. (6/10)

PS: For an inspired boss reference, I think Poison Ivy with Catwoman, Killer Croc in BAA, Mr. Freeze, Solomon Grundy, and even Bane in BAA were inspiring boss fights.

UPDATE: I have now completed this game (after some reluctance) and the final fight is just about the ONLY inspird boss fight I've found in this game.

reviewText: Overall the game is very very good the combat has depth and is not too complex, maling it really feeling like one of the only games that feels like it can stand on combat alone if needed but with the platfroming/ puzzle solving mechanics that give it a balance of fun that I feel that only this and the orgional price of persia series has accomplished in the 3d relm. The story is engaging and gritty while keeping the plot simple and is meant to give of a feeling of determination to stop what is going on rather than putting 50 plot twists in or going down so deep in Batman lore that you have to read years worth of Batman comics or stop the game to search in wikipedia to understand (thats is not saying there will be no charcters that people will not know before getting into the game but rather the game does a very good job explaining who they are through both the cut scenes and gameplay styles and areas that you interact with them in). Thank being said I think there is two things holding the game back. The main one is that the city in the single player just feels so....... empty you end feeling like your saving a city with nobody in it. Now, the games excuse is that everyone is staying in their homes due to a huge storm, but in reality there are still some people out and about even in snow storms (now saying that is smart or not, that is a different subject) so could had a least a couple of people out and about in the streets, something like saving a woman when those sudden crime reports come up? Even a few npcs would make it feel that your in a living city and not an apocalytic one. (and for any of those that will say that the world is more for collecting, the orgional Crackdown was a collect-a-thon in almost the same exact way and still managed to create a livelier city than this AND was released in 2007) the other promlem is that the multiplayer is boring, which I know is a very common complaint and is really not the reason people buy this game but it still dosen't change the fact that it could be done better than a generic thrid person shooter with batman combat, what makes it frustrating is that all it need to be good was a endless oneline mode with friends similar to the single player challenges or some online co-op.  Don't let the negatives deter you though this game is good just could have been better if Wb interactive wasn't trying to release a new game every year  like it is the combat version of call of duty which I am very afraid that it is becoming like that with the new game announced for this year.
